questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding Argemone mexicana, except that _____.

choices.text: Its oil is used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

questions.solution:
The entire Argemone mexicana plant is poisonous, not only the seeds.

Argemone mexicana grows all over India. The plant has spiny leaves and yellow flowers. The seeds are contained in prickly oblong capsules.

The oil is extracted from argemone seeds and contains the toxic alkaloids sanguinarine and dihydrosanguinarine. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Poisoning leads to epidemic dropsy, characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, edema of the feet, and generalized anasarca. Some patients may develop diminished vision due to glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Treatment includes a healthy diet and supportive treatment of the heart.

The image below shows Argemone mexicana:

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text: A 15-month-old child who is posted for a minor surgical procedure is brought by his mother for preoperative evaluation. What would be the recommended period of fasting for this child?

choices.text: 6 hours for light meal, 2 hours for clear fluids
6 hours for fried foods, 2 hours for clear fluids
6  hours for light meal, 4 hours for clear fluids
6 hours for fried foods, 4 hours for clear fluids

questions.solution:
The recommended preoperative fasting period for this child is 6 hours for a light meal and 2 hours for clear fluids.

Recommended preoperative fasting periods for all above 1 year of age are 2 hours for clear fluids, 6 hours for a light meal, and 8 hours for fried, fatty food.

Recommended preoperative fasting periods for neonates and infants are 6 hours for solids/ formula feeds/ cow's milk, and 4 hours for breast milk.

The goal of recommending preoperative fasting periods is to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: A patient presents with persistent, intense pruritic lesions on his hands for 7 weeks. The lesions appear as shown in the image and he is diagnosed with chronic hand eczema. Which of the following is recommended systemic treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Alitretinoin is the only recommended systemic therapy for chronic hand eczema. The image shows scaly, fissured, hyperkeratotic patches on the palms and little fingers. 

Eczema is a condition characterized by itching, dryness, erythema, fissuring, hyperkeratosis, lichenification, scaling, and vesiculation of the affected areas. Eczema persisting for more than 6 weeks is called chronic eczema.

Predisposing factors:

  • Atopy
  • Idiopathic
  • Naturally dry skin
  • Allergic or irritant dermatitis - chromate, epoxy glues, and rubber
  • Filaggrin gene mutations are predisposing factors

The patients present with pruritus and painful fissuring in the affected areas. 

Management of chronic hand eczema involves hand care advice, the use of emollients, and the avoidance of irritants. Topical corticosteroids are used for the majority of the cases. If the lesion does not respond to topical corticosteroids, then topical calcineurin inhibitors like tacrolimus can be used. Alitretinoin, the retinoid is the only licensed systemic therapy for chronic hand eczema.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: A man comes to the doctor because of a rash and headache. You diagnose him with Rocky Mountain spotted fever. He has a severe allergy to tetracycline.  A drug that can cause fatal aplastic anemia is prescribed. The bacteriostatic effect of this drug is most likely due to which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Inhibition of transpeptidase crosslinking at the cell wall
Inactivation of prokaryotic topoisomerase II and IV

questions.solution:
Since the drug is prescribed for Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) and it has the potential to cause fatal aplastic anemia, the prescribed drug in this case is most likely to be chloramphenicol. The mechanism of action of chloramphenicol is that it binds at the 50S ribosomal subunit. This prevents protein synthesis.

Chloramphenicol is now only used to treat individuals with life-threatening illnesses who are unable to take safer options due to resistance or allergies because the medication can induce serious and fatal blood dyscrasias.

It can be used in

  • Typhoid fever
  • Bacterial meningitis: Patients with severe β-lactam allergies and those living in developing nations are still administered chloramphenicol as treatment for meningitis brought on by Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Rickettsial diseases: Tetracyclines are frequently used as the primary treatment for rickettsial disorders. Chloramphenicol is an alternate treatment for people who are allergic to these medications, for pregnant women, and for kids under the age of 8 years, who need prolonged or repeated sessions of therapy. Chloramphenicol is effective against epidemic typhus, Q fever, murine typhus, and spotted fever of the Rocky Mountains.

Adverse effects:

The drug affects the hematopoietic system in the following ways:

  • Dose-related toxicity that presents as anemia, leukopenia, or thrombocytopenia
  • Idiosyncratic response that includes aplastic anemia, leading to fatal pancytopenia in many cases. Patients who receive prolonged therapy, especially those who are exposed to multiple courses of the drug, are more likely to develop pancytopenia.

Hypersensitivity reactions include skin rashes. Angioedema may also develop.

Gray infant syndrome is a dangerous condition that may occur in newborns, especially if they are premature. Neonates become ashen gray in color, flaccid, and hypothermic.

Chloramphenicol can cause nausea, vomiting, an unpleasant taste, diarrhea, and perineal discomfort; in rare cases, it may cause vision fuzziness and digital paresthesias.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A patient presenting with lightheadedness and syncope was admitted to the emergency department. The ECG obtained is shown below. His symptoms did not resolve with carotid sinus massage or adenosine. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the changes marked by the blue arrows?

choices.text: P wave causing normal sinus beat

questions.solution:
The given ECG shows ventricular tachycardia, and the blue arrows indicate fusion beats, which are caused by the fusion of 2 independent electrical impulses. 

Ventricular tachycardia (VT) is a type of ventricular arrhythmia characterized by a ventricular rate exceeding 100 beats per minute, for three or more consecutive beats. It may be caused either due to the automatic origin of impulses from the Purkinje cells, myocardial cells, or reentry of the impulses to the ventricles through the scarred tissues. 

Patients will present with palpitations because of increased heart rate. Ineffective contractions of ventricles lead to dizziness, exercise intolerance, episodes of lightheadedness, and syncope.

ECG findings are characterized by the presence of atrioventricular dissociation, that is, atria and ventricles have different rates of contraction. This is because the ectopic impulses originating in the ventricles cause them to contract independent of the impulses transmitted from the atria. Ventricular impulses give rise to the broad QRS complexes (>120 msec) as seen in the ECG given.

In some instances, when a P wave is conducted down the AV node to the ventricles, it fuses with the impulse originating from the ventricle. This gives rise to the classic fusion beat, as seen in the image below:

Other options:

Option A - In ventricular tachycardia, a normal sinus impulse reaches the atrioventricular node and the ventricle during a gap between 2 ectopic ventricular impulses. It produces a beat with a normal QRS duration. This is called capture beat (as the atrial impulse 'captures' the ventricles during ventricular tachycardia).

The image below shows a capture beat:

Option B - Hypokalemia gives rise to QT interval prolongation. This change predisposes to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia known as torsades de pointes (TDP). It is characterized by wide QRS complexes of varying amplitude that twist around the isoelectric line (shown below).

Option D - Ventricular preexcitation is commonly seen in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which is characterized by the presence of accessory atrioventricular pathways. These pathways are responsible for the early conduction of electrical impulses to the ventricles.

The characteristic ECG changes (shown below) are consistent with

  • Short PR interval (<120 msec)
  • Wide QRS complex (>120 msec)
  • Slurred upstroke of the QRS complex- delta wave 
  • Secondary ST-T wave changes

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: An adult patient presents with massive proteinuria, edema, and hematuria. The biopsy image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and biopsy image showing uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall are suggestive of membranous glomerulonephritis.

Membranous nephropathy is a chronic immune complex–mediated disease characterized by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to the accumulation of deposits containing immunglobulin. Immunofluorescence microscopy demonstrates that the granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement, as shown below.

It will present as nephrotic syndrome with massive proteinuria, generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, and lipiduria. Most of the cases are primary. Some of the secondary causes include

  • Drugs (penicillamine, captopril, NSAIDs, gold),
  • Malignant tumors - Lung, colon, and melanoma
  • SLE
  • Infections - Chronic hepatitis B, hepatitis C, syphilis
  • Autoimmune disorders 

Minimal change disease has negative immunofluorescence. In rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) type I and Goodpasture syndrome, immunofluorescence reveals a linear pattern (as shown below), which is a classic feature of anti–glomerular basement membrane disease (anti-GBM) disease.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with fever, weight loss, and diarrhea. Several investigations were done, including an intestinal biopsy, which appears as shown below. Which among the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows a non-caseating granuloma. Among the given options, Crohn’s disease is the most likely condition in the given case.

Non-caseating granulomas can be seen in

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Berylliosis
  • Crohn's disease

Granulomas are generally not seen in ulcerative colitis and irritable bowel syndrome. Tuberculous granuloma is an example of caseating granuloma, which has central necrosis with amorphous granular debris and a cheese-like macroscopic appearance. The given image does not show a necrotic center, making it unlikely to be tuberculosis.

The image below shows a tuberculous granuloma with a necrotic center.

questions.text: An Rh-negative primigravida has a second-trimester abortion. An indirect Coombs test done on the maternal serum is negative. According to ACOG guidelines, which of the following is to be done to prevent Rh isoimmunization?

choices.text: Repeat indirect Coombs test after 2 weeks
No treatment needed as patient is unsensitized
Administer 300 mcg of anti-Rh antibody within 72 hours
Administer 50 mcg of anti-Rh antibody within 72 hours

questions.solution:
The ACOG recommends the administration of 300 μg of anti-Rh antibody within 72 hours of all second and third-trimester abortions in unsensitized Rh-negative females.

This dose can also be administered in other events with the risk of fetomaternal hemorrhages such as abdominal trauma, obstetric hemorrhage, external cephalic version, as well as invasive procedures such as cordocentesis or amniocentesis and intrauterine fetal death.

The recommended dose for first-trimester abortions is 50 μg. This also applies to molar pregnancies, ectopic pregnancies, and invasive procedures such as chorionic villus sampling.

For Rh-negative women with an ongoing pregnancy, an indirect Coombs test is done at 28 weeks of gestation. If negative, it means that the mother is unsensitized and 300 μg of anti-Rh antibody is administered.

After delivery, Rh typing of the newborn is done. If the newborn is found to be Rh positive, another 300 μg dose of anti-Rh antibody is administered to the mother within 72 hours.

Related Pearl: Indications of Amniotic Fluid Color

Amniotic fluid colour Inference
Colourless Early pregnancy
Straw yellow  Term pregnancy (exfoliated lanugo, epidermal cells from fetal skin)
Meconium stained (green) Fetal distress (other than breech / transverse)
Golden  Rh incompatibility (excessive hemolysis of fetal RBC, excess bilirubin)
Greenish yellow (saffron) Post maturity
Dark red Concealed accidental hemorrhage (contamination of blood)
Dark brown (tobacco juice) Intrauterine death (presence of old HbA)

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presented with active contractions at 25 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history is uneventful. She is started on tocolytic therapy. A few hours later, she complains of headache, difficulty in breathing, and palpitations. Her vitals and chest x-ray are given below. Which tocolytic agent was most likely administered?

Pulse rate - 122/minute
Respiratory rate - 21/minute
BP - 90/60 mmHg
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of preterm labor. The symptoms of tachycardia, pulmonary edema (batwing appearance on chest x-ray), hypotension, and hypokalemia (palpitations) in the mother after administration of a tocolytic are most likely to have been caused by ritodrine.

Preterm labor and delivery (labor starts before the 37th completed week, counting from the first day of the last menstrual period) can be delayed by drugs in order to improve the perinatal outcome. A short-term delay of 48 hours allows the use of corticosteroids that can reduce perinatal mortality and serious morbidity significantly.

Complications of common tocolytics are as follows:

Salbutamol/ Terbutaline/ Isoxsuprine		 Maternal- Headache, palpitation, tachycardia,  hypotension, cardiac failure,  pulmonary edema, ARDS, hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia,

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with criminal responsibility in mental illness?
questions.solution:
Nysten's rule is not associated with insanity, it describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis.

Tests to determine criminal responsibility in persons with mental illness:

Durhams's rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

Curren’s rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law as a result of mental disease or defect.

The American Law Institute test states that a person is not responsible for criminal conduct, if at the time of such conduct, as a result of mental disease or defect, he lacks adequate capacity either to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to adjust his conduct to the requirements of the law.

Other such tests include:

  • Mc Naughten rule, also called the right or wrong test
  • The irresistible impulse test, also called as New Hampshire Doctrine

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity/death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours.

Muscles are affected in the given order:

  1. Involuntary muscles: Heart (left chamber of the heart is affected first)
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

Related Pearl: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

questions.text:
An alcoholic man is admitted to a rehabilitation center for alcohol deaddiction. After three days, he develops visual hallucinations. His vital signs are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Pulse rate: 124 bpm
Blood pressure: 140/90 mmHg
Temperature: 101ºF
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an alcohol-dependent patient with tactile hallucinations, tachycardia, hypertension and fever following alcohol withdrawal indicates a likely diagnosis of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs within a week of a person stopping or reducing the intake of alcohol. Acute infection, hepatitis, and pancreatitis predispose a person in withdrawal to develop delirium tremens. Clinically, patients present with confusion, agitation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness. Visual or tactile hallucinations are also seen, along with features of autonomic hyperactivity like tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever, insomnia, and hypertension. 

Delirium tremend is managed with benzodiazepines such as lorazepam (intravenously) or chlordiazepoxide (orally every 4 hours). It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Wernicke encephalopathy is an acute encephalopathy caused due to thiamine deficiency in alcohol-dependent patients who tend to have micronutrient deficiencies. Patients present with a characteristic triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and global confusion. Treatment includes immediate administration of a high dose of 500 mg intravenous thiamine.

Option B: Korsakoff psychosis is an amnestic syndrome that occurs due to thiamine deficiency in alcohol-dependent patients. The clinical features include impairment of memory, confabulations, and disordered temporal sequencing. Treatment includes 100 mg of oral thiamine daily for 3-12 months.

Option D: In alcohol intoxication, there is a history of recent ingestion of alcohol. Patients present with slurred speech, incoordination, unsteady gait, and nystagmus. Impairments in attention and memory are also seen.

questions.text: A one-and-a-half-year-old baby is brought to the emergency ward with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that has lasted for 20 mins without regaining consciousness. The baby is stabilized and then administered intravenous lorazepam. Despite 2 doses, the seizure continues. Which drug is to be given next?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is that of status epilepticus (SE). The drug that is to be administered after lorazepam is IV fosphenytoin.

SE is characterized as ongoing convulsive activity or recurring generalized convulsive seizure activity without recovering consciousness. According to the new definition of SE, two time frames have been defined for each type of seizure. They are called t1 and t2. t1 is the time to reflect as to when the treatment should be initiated and t2 is the time at which continuous seizure activity will lead to long-term complications.

In generalized tonic-clonic seizures, t1 is 5 min and t2 is 30 min. The initial choice of therapy is a benzodiazepine, which includes either of the following:

  • Intravenous lorazepam
  • Intravenous diazepam 
  • Intramuscular midazolam- If IV access is not available

If the seizure still continues, we can repeat the above dose once again. If there is no response even after repeat doses, then a single dose of either of the antiepileptics can be given,

  • Intravenous fosphenytoin 
  • Intravenous valproic acid 
  • Intravenous levetiracetam 

The image given below depicts the management of this condition in a flowchart:

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man, who has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, now presents with left hemiparesis without any speech problems. His symptoms resolve while he is being evaluated. Which of the following statements about his condition is correct?

TIA - Transient ischemic attack

choices.text: Single antiplatelet therapy with aspirin is most effective in preventing stroke
A normal brain imaging rules out TIA
CHADS2 score determines risk of developing future stroke
The risk of stroke is highest in the period immediately following a TIA

questions.solution:
The patient has a transient ischemic attack (TIA) in the above case. TIAs are episodes of stroke symptoms that last only briefly, the standard definition of duration is <24 h, but most TIAs last <1 h. This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina, or cochlea. There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA.

It is a prognostic indicator for stroke, with approximately 10-15% risk of developing stroke in the following 3 months after a TIA. A stroke can occur as soon as 2 days after a TIA.

Risk stratification of stroke in patients with TIA can be done using the ABCD2 score.

A normal brain imaging study following a TIA does not rule out the TIA; the medical symptoms are diagnostic.

There is no room for observation in the management of patients with TIA, but the improvement characteristic of TIA contraindicates thrombolysis. In a significant trial, it was discovered that aspirin and clopidogrel together prevented stroke after TIA better than aspirin alone.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man is brought to the hospital due to diarrhea since 3 days. Laboratory values are as follows. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?

pH = 7.2

PCO2 = 30 mmHg

HCO3 = 7 mEq/L

Cl = 120 mEq/L

Na = 135 mEq/L

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap
Respiratory acidosis with an  increased anion gap

questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. Normal pH is 7.35-7.45

Step 2: Bicarbonate (HCO3) level of 7 mEq/L (normal = 22-28 mEq/L) together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate (i.e. base). Hence, this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- [(Cl-)+(HCO3-)]

= 135-(120+7)

= 8 mEq/L

The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. Hence anion gap is within the normal range.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A patient presented to the clinic with the lesions shown in the image below. The pathogenesis of this condition involves the binding of which of the following pairs of viral oncoproteins and target genes?
questions.solution:
The given image shows condyloma acuminata/genital warts, which are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). The pathogenesis of this condition involves binding of the viral oncoproteins E6 and E7 to the target genes p53 and p21, respectively (Option B).

Condyloma acuminata is a benign, sexually transmitted, wart caused by HPV. It commonly occurs due to infection from low-risk HPV serotypes -HPV 6 and HPV 11. High-risk HPV serotypes cause cervical cancer, of which HPV 16 and HPV 18 account for the majority of cases.

The ability of HPV to act as a carcinogen depends on the viral E6 and E7 proteins, which interfere with the activity of the key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and RB, respectively.

The E7 protein of HPV binds to hypophosphorylated RB (representing active state) and promotes its degradation via the proteasome pathway. It also binds and inhibits cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors p21 and p27.

The E6 protein binds p53 and promotes its degradation. It also upregulates the expression of telomerase, leading to cellular immortalization. 

The image given below shows the functions of the E6 and E7 oncoproteins of HPV.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male patient came with back pain and stiffness. He was found to have sacroiliitis on imaging and was diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis. He is positive for an HLA marker. This marker positivity is also seen in _____.
  1. Psoriatic spondylitis
  2. Reactive arthritis due to Shigella
  3. Rheumatoid arthritis
  4. Behcet’s disease
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario of ankylosing spondylitis (AS), there will be positivity for HLA-B27. This marker positivity is also seen in psoriatic spondylitis (1) and reactive arthritis (2) due to Shigella.

HLA-B27 is also found to be positive in the following conditions:

  • Psoriatic spondylitis: Some patients with psoriatic arthritis have axial joint involvement without peripheral involvement, which presents similarly to AS.
  • Reactive arthritis: Acute non-purulent arthritis occurs a few days after a systemic infection or an infection elsewhere in the body. It is usually seen following enteric or urogenital infection. Organisms causing these infections are Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, and Chlamydia.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and strongly associates with HLA-B27.

Clinically, patients present with recurring backache, which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with exercise. Later, they develop fatigue, pain, joint swellings, and heel pain.

Extra-articular manifestations include uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis.

X-ray findings:

  • Erosion of sacroiliac joints - sacroiliitis
  • Squaring of vertebrae and bamboo spine appearance

Other options:

  • Behcet's disease - HLA-B51 positive
  • Rheumatoid arthritis - HLA DR4 positive

questions.text: An elderly primigravida presented at 26 weeks of gestation. A 75 gram two-hour oral glucose tolerance test revealed a blood sugar level of 175 mg/dL. A diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus was made. Which of the following hormones is not responsible for the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of an elderly primigravida in her second trimester with a 75 gram 2-hour plasma glucose level of >153 mg/dL is diagnostic of gestational diabetes mellitus. The reason for developing gestational diabetes mellitus is insulin resistance, in which hCG has no role.

Maternal blood glucose levels increase in the second half of pregnancy to facilitate increased glucose transfer from the mother to the fetus. As feedback, there is hyperplasia and hypertrophy of the beta cells of islets of Langerhans in the maternal pancreas, causing hyperinsulinemia (especially in the third trimester) and a decrease in the levels of glucose available to the fetus. To ensure a continuous supply of glucose to the fetus, the placenta secretes certain hormones that increase insulin resistance in the mother.

Pregnancy being a state of low-grade inflammation is marked by factors like IL-6 and C-reactive proteins that also contribute to insulin resistance. Insulin resistance is seen maximally between 24 to 28 weeks. The hormones responsible for insulin resistance in pregnancy include,

  • Human placental lactogen 
  • Progesterone and estrogen
  • Placental growth hormone 
  • Cortisol
  • Prolactin

The screening method for GDM recommended in India is a 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) irrespective of the last meal timing. A value of ≥140 mg/dL after 2 hours is considered a positive test, indicating GDM. Universal screening is done for all pregnant women. The first testing should be done during the first antenatal contact as early as possible in pregnancy. The second testing should be done during 24-28 weeks of pregnancy if the first test is negative (as in this case).

questions.text: A 2-day-old infant is brought with yellowish discoloration of the skin and rash. The mother gives a history of fever and pharyngitis during her pregnancy. On examination, chorioretinitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions were noted with no cardiovascular abnormality. On a non-contrast CT scan, the following image is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above non-contrast CT image shows periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly. The above clinical vignette and the CT image are suggestive of the diagnosis of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

The most common congenital infection is congenital CMV infection. It is mostly asymptomatic, but symptoms may occur in cases of primary maternal infection in pregnancy. 

The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. They can also develop hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions due to dermal erythropoiesis giving the appearance of a blueberry muffin baby. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Laboratory findings include direct hyperbilirubinemia, elevated hepatic transaminases, and thrombocytopenia. A non-contrast CT scan shows periventricular calcifications, ventriculomegaly, and hypoplastic cerebellum. Diagnosis can be made prenatal or postnatal. Prenatal diagnosis includes the detection of IgM antibodies in the mother along with observing for fetal abnormalities through ultrasound. Antibody positivity in the mother along with abnormalities in the baby highly suggests intrauterine infection. Detection of fetal infection can also be done by the detection of the virus through the amniotic fluid polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Postnatal diagnosis involves the isolation of the virus from the urine or saliva via the DNA PCR or culture within the first 3 weeks of life.

Histopathological detection will reveal characteristic owl eye inclusion–bearing cells.

Below is the image showing the blueberry muffin baby.

Option A- Congenital rubella syndrome is due to the rubella virus. It is characterized by cataracts, salt and pepper retinopathy; sensorineural deafness; microcephaly; blueberry muffin baby; and congenital heart diseases like patent ductus arteriosus, ventricular septal defect, and pulmonary artery stenosis. Sensorineural deafness is the most common single complication in patients with congenital rubella syndrome.

Below is the image showing salt and pepper retinopathy.

Option B- Congenital syphilis is due to Treponema pallidum. It can be differentiated into early signs at <2 years of age and late signs during the first 2 decades. Early signs are characterized by painful osteochondritis resulting in pseudoparalysis of Parrot, periostitis, mucocutaneous rash characterized by maculopapular rash or vesiculobullous lesions, snuffles (persistent rhinitis), and condylomatous lesions. Radiographs show demineralization of the medial proximal tibial metaphysis called Wimberger lines. Late signs are characterized by dental anomalies like Hutchinson's teeth, saddle nose, interstitial keratitis, and Clutton's joints (unilateral or bilateral painless joint swelling especially the knee joint).

Below is the image showing Hutchinson's teeth.

Option C- Congenital toxoplasmosis is due to Toxoplasma gondii. It is characterized by a classic triad of chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and intracerebral calcifications. Blueberry muffin baby appearance is also seen in this condition. On a CT scans of the brain, there are calcifications around caudate nucleus and basal ganglia, choroid plexus, and subependyma.

questions.text:
An elderly woman presents to the doctor with a 3-month history of easy fatiguability while performing day-to-day activities. On examination, she has pallor. Her hemoglobin level is 10 g/dL. Her laboratory test reports are given below. Which of the following is true regarding the nutrient deficient in this patient?
  Patient
report		 Normal
values
Serum iron
(μg/dL)		 23 50-150
TIBC 
(μg/dL)		 390 300-360
Transferrin saturation
(%)		 19  25-50
Serum ferritin 
(μg/L)		  13

 

30

(females)

choices.text: It is predominantly absorbed from the duodenum
Its uptake is mediated by divalent metal transporter type 2

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly woman presenting with easy fatiguability with pallor and laboratory features of decreased hemoglobin, serum iron, transferrin saturation, serum ferritin, and increased TIBC (total iron binding capacity), suggest iron-deficiency anemia. Iron is predominantly absorbed from the duodenum.

Iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in its absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the enterocyte, the ferric form is converted to the ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1 (DMT-1).

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin. The iron in plasma is transported to the required tissues by the protein transferrin. 

Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of the electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed. Several factors can increase or decrease iron absorption. Ascorbic acid increases iron absorption whereas, phytates (in bran, oats, rye fiber), polyphenols (in tea), calcium, and soy protein decrease its absorption.

Therefore, a patient with anemia must be advised to consume red meat and oranges/lemons and to avoid coffee, tea, and calcium tablets while taking iron tablets.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased

In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: A college-going student presents to you with the rapidly increasing power of glasses due to progressive myopia. You also noticed Vogt’s striae on slit-lamp examination, along with Fleischer's rings. These Fleischer's rings are seen due to ______.

choices.text: Copper deposition in corneal Descemet's membrane
Iron deposition in corneal Descemet's membrane

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient showing Vogt’s striae and Fleischer's rings on slit-lamp examination is suggestive of keratoconus.

Fleischer's rings occur due to the deposition of iron in the corneal epithelium. These are seen as brownish rings at the base of the cone of keratoconus, best seen under cobalt blue light.

Keratoconus is a progressive disorder in which central or paracentral corneal stromal thinning occurs, accompanied by apical protrusion and irregular astigmatism.

Other signs seen in keratoconus:

  • Direct ophthalmoscopy from a distance of half a meter shows a fairly well-delineated oil droplet reflex
  • Vogt’s striae: Vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane
  • Munson’s sign: V-shaped deformity of the lower lid on downward gaze
  • Scissoring reflex in retinoscopy

The image below shows Fleischer's ring (indicated by the arrow) under cobalt blue light:

 

Note: Kayser-Fleischer rings are caused by copper deposition in Descemet's membrane of the cornea and are indicative of Wilson's disease.

The image below shows Kayser-Fleischer ring:

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complained of low mood, decreased appetite, and loss of weight for the past 2 months. He mentions that he feels worthless and has decreased interest in activities. He also complains of great difficulty falling asleep. He has past history of atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs should be preferred for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given clinical scenario has major depression with insomnia, decreased appetite, and weight loss. The preferred drug for this patient is mirtazapine as it is an antidepressant with sedative and appetite-stimulating properties.

Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant (a noradrenergic-specific serotonin antagonist). It blocks the presynaptic α2 receptors and postsynaptic 5HT2 and 5HT3 receptors. The antagonism at serotonin receptors helps relieve anxiety and insomnia and stimulates appetite. It has a sedative property as it blocks the H1 receptors. Mirtazapine is used in the treatment of major depression with long-standing insomnia.

Adverse effects include sedation, increased appetite, weight gain, and rarely agranulocytosis. Sexual dysfunction is not a known side-effect of mirtazapine.

Atypical anti-depressants are those that act by unique mechanisms other than those of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), serotonin-noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), MAO inhibitors, and tricyclic antidepressants. It includes drugs like trazodone, mianserin, bupropion, mirtazapine, and amoxapine.

Other options:

Option A: Fluoxetine is an SSRI used in the treatment of major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia and anorexia nervosa, and generalized anxiety disorders. It may cause insomnia, and hence, it is avoided in this patient. Other adverse effects include anxiety, irritability, and decreased libido.

Option B: Venlafaxine is an SNRI used in the treatment of major depression, generalized anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. It may cause insomnia, and hence, it is avoided in this patient. Other adverse effects are nausea, sexual dysfunction, and sustained elevation of blood pressure.

Option C: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant used in the treatment of major depression and nocturnal enuresis. Its use should be limited in heart diseases as it has quinidine-like effects on cardiac conduction, and hence, it is avoided in this patient.

Related Pearl: Adverse effects of specific antidepressants

Drug

Side effect

Fluoxetine

Copper T 380A (Image 2) 10 Contains copper wire with a total surface area of 380 mm2 wound around the vertical stem and each arm.
Multiload 375 (Image 3) 5 375 mm2 of copper wire wound on the vertical stem.
Copper T 200 (Image 4) 3 200-250 mm2 of copper wire wound on the vertical stem.

 Mechanism of action of intrauterine devices:

  • Biochemical and histological changes in the endometrium - Non-specific inflammation causing a gametotoxic, spermicidal effect; macrophage-induced phagocytosis of the spermatozoa is also responsible for contraceptive effect.
  • Increased tubal motility- prevention of fertilization 
  • Endometrial inflammation decreases sperm motility and inhibits fertilization 
  • Copper-containing devices cause enzymatic interference preventing implantation by producing cytokines.
  • Hormone-releasing devices induce strong and uniform endometrial suppression and decrease cervical mucus. It may also cause anovulation and a luteal-phase insufficiency adding to its contraceptive effect.

questions.text: The resolving power of the given microscope is primarily limited by_____

choices.text: Stain used to visualise the object

questions.solution:
The resolving power of a light microscope, shown in the image, is limited by the wavelength of the light.

Resolving power is the ability to discriminate between 2 closely located objects. Human eye can discriminate 2 objects if they are 200micrometer apart. With a light microscope in the best possible magnification, the resolving power becomes 300nm (0.3 micrometer). In order to discriminate or delineate an object, it should have a minimum size of more than or equal to half the wavelength of light.

 

Below are parts of a light microscope

questions.text: A 55-year-old post-menopausal woman with a family history of breast cancer presents with persistent lower backache. Her bone mineral density is measured, and the T-score is -2.6. She is prescribed raloxifene. Which of the following effects of this drug should the patient be informed about?
questions.solution:
This post-menopausal patient with a family history of breast cancer, with osteoporosis (low back pain, a T-score of -2.6), has been recommended to take raloxifene. Raloxifene causes a 3-fold increase in deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) with the following actions-

Agonist actions:

  • Bone: Increases bone mineral density and reduces the risk of vertebral fractures
  • Lipids: Reduces total cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein. However, it does not increase HDL cholesterol.
  • Increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. 

Antagonist action:

  • Breast: Incidence of breast carcinoma is reduced (option D). Raloxifene has an antiproliferative effect on ER-positive breast tumors and significantly reduces the risk of ER-positive but not ER-negative breast cancer.
  • Uterus: does not stimulate endometrial proliferation (option B)

Note: Raloxifene does not help with vasomotor symptoms, and some people might experience hot flashes (option A).

SERM Effect on breast  Effect on endometrium Effect on bone
Tamoxifen Inhibits proliferation Stimulates proliferation Antiresorptive
Raloxifene Inhibits proliferation Inhibits proliferation Antiresorptive

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for osteoporosis:

Risk factor for osteoporosis
Low BMI
Family history of osteoporosis
Old age
Previous fragility fracture
Chronic use of glucocorticoids
Family history of hip fractures
Smoking and alcohol intake
Drugs like anticonvulsants, anticoagulants and thyroid replacement therapy
Hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, and malabsorption syndrome

questions.text: All the following drugs and their response with the receptors are correctly paired, except _______.

choices.text: Graph 4- succinylcholine at Nicotinic ACh Receptor

questions.solution:
All the following statement is correct, except option C. Graph 4 depicts the action of the inverse agonist. Whereas, succinylcholine exhibits agonism at the nicotinic ACh Receptor.

Graph 1 represents the agonist: An agonist is an agent which initiates the normal physiological response when combined with a receptor. Example: Salbutamol is a beta-2 receptor agonist.
 
Graph 2 represents a partial agonist: An agent which produces a submaximal or partial effect when combined with a receptor. Example: Buprenorphine and butorphanol are partial agonists at opioid receptors.
 
Graph 3 represents the competitive antagonist: An agent which blocks or reduces the action of an agonist on a receptor, but does not have any effect of its own. Example: Naltrexone and naloxone are antagonists at opioid receptors.
 
Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist: An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist. Example: β-Carboline is an inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor.

The image given below shows the action of various types of selective receptor modulators:

questions.text: Given below is the histological structure of an endocrine gland. The blood supply to this gland arises from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the histology of the parathyroid gland. It is supplied by the inferior thyroid artery which is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk. 

It can be identified by the presence of acidophilic and principal cells. The principal cells have pale staining cytoplasm while the acidophilic cells are larger than principal cells and have acidophilic cytoplasm. The principal cells produce parathormone. The function of the oxyphil cells is unknown. 

Other options:

Option B- External carotid artery gives a branch called the superior thyroid artery which supplies thyroid gland. The thyroid gland can be identified by the presence of epithelium-lined thyroid follicles. The center of each follicle has a lightly staining colloid. 

Below image shows thyroid gland

 

Option C- The internal carotid artery supplies the pituitary gland via hypophyseal arteries. Section of the pituitary gland can be identified by the presence of pars distalis, pars tuberalis, and pars intermedia. Pars distalis contains chromophils having hormones stored in cytoplasmic granules. Pars tuberalis contains gonadotrophs and pars intermedia is a region between pars distalis and pars nervosa.

Below image shows pituitary gland

 

Option D- Superior mesenteric artery supplies pancreas. Pancreas can be identified by the presence of islets. The islet cells are polygonal or rounded, and more lightly stained than the surrounding acinar cells.

Below image shows pancreas

questions.text: Which of the following acts as an RNA-directed nuclease?
questions.solution:
CRISPR-Cas9 acts as an RNA-directed nuclease.

Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats-associated gene 9, or CRISPR-Cas9, is a DNA editing/gene regulatory system. It involves two essential components: Cas9, an endonuclease that causes a double-stranded DNA break, allowing modifications to the genomic DNA to be made; and a synthetic single-guide RNA, or sgRNA, responsible for guiding Cas9 to its target.

Once the sgRNA has directed the Cas9 to the section of the genomic DNA to be edited, the 3’ end of the sgRNA comes to lie across a specific sequence of DNA adjacent to the editing side called the protospacer adjacent motif or PAM. The Cas9 now causes a double-stranded break in the DNA at the PAM site, which is then repaired by a non-homologous end-joining.

The following image shows CRISPR-Cas9 system:

Some important enzymes used in recombinant DNA research

Enzyme 

Reaction 

Primary Use 

Phosphatase

Dephosphorylates 5′ ends of RNA and DNA
  • Removal of 5′-PO4 (phosphate) groups prior to kinase labeling
  • Prevent self-ligation 

DNA ligase 

Catalyzes bonds between DNA molecules 
  • Joining of DNA molecules 

DNA polymerase I 

Synthesizes double-stranded DNA from single-stranded DNA 
  • Synthesis of double-stranded cDNA
  • DNA labeling and nick translation
  • Generation of blunt ends from sticky ends 

Thermostable DNA polymerases 

Synthesize DNA at elevated temperatures (60-80°C) 
  • Polymerase chain reaction (DNA synthesis)
  • Mutagenesis 

DNase I 

Produces single-stranded nicks in DNA, under appropriate conditions
  • Nick translation
  • Mapping of hypersensitive sites
  • Mapping protein-DNA interactions 

Exonuclease III 

Removes nucleotides from 3′ ends of DNA 
  • DNA sequencing
  • ChIP-Exo
  • Mapping of DNA-protein interactions 

RNAse H 

Degrades the RNA portion of a DNA–RNA hybrid 
  • Synthesis of cDNA from mRNA 

S1 nuclease 

Degrades single-stranded DNA 
  • Removal of “hairpin” in synthesis of cDNA
  • RNA mapping studies 

CRISPR-Cas9/C2c2 

RNA-targeted DNA-, or RNA-directed nuclease 

Genome editing and variations modulation

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient who had been to a movie theatre came to the emergency room with complaints of ocular pain and blurring of vision. She gives a history of being on prophylactic medications for migraine. On examination, her intraocular pressure is elevated with a shallow anterior chamber. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of her presentation?
questions.solution:
Topiramate is the most likely cause of her presentation.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma characterized by the precipitating factors i.e., female gender and movie theatre (movie in a darkened hall) and increased intraocular pressure with a shallow anterior chamber.

Topiramate causes ciliochoroidal effusion, leading to acute angle-closure glaucoma. Other sulfa-derived drugs like sulfonamides can also cause angle-closure glaucoma. The treatment would consist of reducing the intraocular pressure and stopping the causative drug.

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that blocks the voltage-gated Na+ channels. Apart from that, it activates hyperpolarizing K+ channels, increases GABA activity, and blocks glutamate AMPA-kainate receptors. It is also a weak carbonic anhydrase inhibitor due to which it may precipitate renal stones.

Topiramate is used in the treatment of refractory focal, refractory generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and prophylaxis of migraine. It is also effective in drop-attacks and seizures in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. This drug can cause weight loss and renal stones.

Other options: 

Option A - Sodium valproate is an antiseizure drug that acts by prolonging the recovery of inactivated Na+ channels and decreasing T-type Ca2+ channel currents. It is used in the treatment of focal, tonic-clonic, absence, and myoclonic seizures. It is also used as a prophylaxis in migraine headaches. 

Option C - Propranolol is a non-selective β-blocker. It is the most common and most effective first-line drug for migraine prophylaxis. Some of the common adverse effects include dizziness, decreased exercise tolerance, and depression. Contraindications include severe asthma, peripheral vascular disease, severe bradycardia, and heart blocks.

Option D - Gabapentin is used in focal onset seizures, neuropathic pains like post-herpetic neuralgia, and neuropathic pain. The most common adverse effects seen with gabapentin are increased drowsiness, ataxia, and fatigue.

questions.text: A young female patient presented to the outpatient department with burning micturition and greenish-frothy vaginal discharge. Her past history revealed that she underwent mechanical heart valve replacement surgery and is currently undergoing warfarin therapy for transient ischemic attacks. She was started on a drug for her current complaints. The next day, she presents with complaints of excessive bleeding after a trivial injury. Which of the following drugs was most probably prescribed?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman with a mechanical valve undergoing warfarin therapy presenting with excessive bleeding is most likely due to the administration of the antibiotic metronidazole. The greenish, frothy vaginal discharge is characteristic of trichomoniasis.

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs that inhibit the CYP2C9 enzyme, like metronidazole, reduce the metabolism of warfarin, enhancing its anticoagulant effect, which increases the risk of bleeding. Interactions with warfarin can be caused due to alterations in the absorption and metabolism of the drug, the circulating levels of clotting factors, and the state of the epithelial surface.

Reduced efficacy of warfarin:

  • Decreased absorption - Conjugation with cholestyramine
  • Increased clearance - CYP2C9 activation by drugs (barbiturates, carbamazepine, rifampin)
  • Reduced circulating volume - Nephrotic syndrome
  • Resistance - High vitamin K consumption, High circulating clotting factor levels in pregnancy

Increased efficacy:

  • Drugs causing CYP2C9 inhibition:
    • Amiodarone
    • Azole antifungals
    • Cimetidine
    • Clopidogrel
    • Cotrimoxazole
    • Disulfiram
    • Isoniazid
    • Metronidazole
    • Fluoxetine
    • Zafirlukast

Nystatin, amoxicillin, and clindamycin do not alter the effect of warfarin.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about CAMP and reverse CAMP tests?

choices.text: Reverse CAMP is used to identify Streptococcus agalactiae; CAMP is used to identify Clostridium perfringens
Reverse CAMP is used to identify Staphylococcus aureus; CAMP is used to identify Clostridium perfringens
Reverse CAMP is used to identify Staphylococcus aureus; CAMP is used to identify Streptococcus agalactiae
Reverse CAMP is used to identify Clostridium perfringens; CAMP is used to identify Streptococcus agalactiae

questions.solution:
CAMP is used to identify Streptococcus agalactiae; reverse CAMP is used to identify Clostridium perfringens.

CAMP test: 

The Christie-Atkins-Munch-Peterson (CAMP) test is used to identify group B,  β-streptococci based on their ability to form CAMP factor, which causes synergistic hemolysis with β-hemolysin formed by Staphylococcus aureus.

When Streptococcus agalactiae is inoculated perpendicular to Staphylococcus aureus grown on blood agar, a characteristic arrowhead zone of hemolysis is seen. The group B streptococci hydrolyze sodium hippurate and give a positive CAMP test.

Reverse CAMP test:

The test is called the reverse CAMP test because the CAMP factor produced by Streptococcus agalactiae is used for the differentiation of C. perfringens from other Clostridium species.

  1. A CAMP-positive group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is streaked in the center of sheep blood agar, and Clostridium perfringens is streaked perpendicular to it.
  2. Following incubation at 37°C for 24-48 hours in anaerobic conditions, an arrowhead zone of enhanced hemolysis pointing towards Streptococcus agalactiae is seen.
  3. This is because the alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens interacts with CAMP factor and produces synergistic hemolysis.

questions.text: As a part of your clinical rotation, you are posted in the department of transfusion medicine and blood bank for fifteen days. At the phlebotomy room, you notice the senior resident flushing the freshly collected blood bags through this machine, storing the output in separate blood bags, and refrigerating them. Which of the following is an advantage of this method?

choices.text: Prevention of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR)
Prevention of febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR)
Prevention of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)
Prevention of bacterial contamination of platelets

questions.solution:
The image shows a leukoreduction filter, which is used for filtering out donor WBCs. Leukoreduction filters help in reducing the incidence of febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). They also remove microaggregates. 

These synthetic-fiber filters remove WBCs by a combination of mesh density, chemical attraction, and active adhesion. Leucocyte reduction of RBC components is most often performed by blood collection centers within the first few days after collection using an integral or sterilely connected filtration system. Filtration prior to storage reduces WBC breakdown products in the blood component. The optimum time for performing leukoreduction is before storage, although a less effective option is to perform leukoreduction after storage, just before transfusion. 

The rate of alloimmunization in patients receiving products that are leukoreduced, by either filtration or irradiation, is significantly lower than that in patients receiving non-leukoreduced products.

Potential benefits of leukoreduction include reduced risk of 

  • Sensitization to HLA antigens (important for transplant patients and preventing platelet refractoriness)
  • Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR)
  • CMV transmission

Leukoreduction may also reduce the risk of

  • Transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease (TA-GVHD) 
  • Transfusion-related immunomodulation (TRIM)
  • Transmitting variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

Bacterial contamination of platelets, transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), and acute hemolytic reactions (due to ABO incompatibility) cause more morbidity and mortality that would not be significantly helped by leukoreduction. 

Methods of leucodepletion:

  • Washing
  • Freezing
  • Buffy coat removal
  • Micro-aggregate filtration
  • Specific leucodepletion filters (most efficient)
  • Low leucocyte apheresis devices

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: A female patient with no relevant past or medication history presents to you with a rash on the cheeks and nose, oral ulcers, and multiple joint pains. Investigations showed low serum complement level. Antibody testing for which of the following is least likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The antibody test least likely to be positive in this scenario is the anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA). 

ANCAs are a group of autoantibodies involved in noninfectious vasculitis, such as microscopic polyangiitis, Churg-Strauss syndrome, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis. They are useful diagnostic markers and can also be used to predict disease recurrence. The two most important ANCAs are anti-proteinase 3 and anti-myeloperoxidase.

SLE is an autoimmune disease that is seen more commonly in women. The abnormal immune response leads to the production of various forms of nucleic acids, proteins, and self-antigens. This, in turn, leads to the production of autoantibodies. In most cases, autoantibodies can be detected years before the start of clinical symptoms. The antibody deposition is then followed by complement-mediated destruction, resulting in tissue damage.

The most common rash seen in SLE is a slightly elevated, photosensitive rash seen around the cheeks and nose (butterfly rash). A few other clinical features include oral ulcers, non-scarring alopecia, and synovitis involving more than two joints. Some immunological features include ANA values more than reference negative values, the presence of Anti-Smith antibodies, low serum complement level, and positive direct Coombs test. 

The presence of at least four criteria with one from each category is a must for diagnosis of SLE, according to the 2012 Systemic Lupus International Collaborating Clinics (SLICC) classification system. 

Other options: 

Option A: The presence of anti-nuclear antibodies is the best screening test for SLE. It is seen in 98% of the cases. Repeated negative tests help to rule out the diagnosis. It has high sensitivity but poor specificity for SLE. 

Option B: Anti-ds DNA antibodies are seen in 70% of the cases. High titers are SLE specific. In a few patients, it indicates disease activity, nephritis, and vasculitis.

Option C: Anti-Smith antibodies are specific for SLE. It is seen more commonly in blacks and Asians than in whites.

More common in black & asians than white

questions.text: A 35-year-old man files a medical negligence case against a surgeon who operated on him for inguinal hernia three and a half years ago. Which of the following defenses against negligence will be applicable in this case?
questions.solution:
Res indicata is the defense against negligence that will be applicable in this case. 

Res indicata specifies that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed as being beyond the period of limitation. Legal action may still be brought up to three years after the alleged negligent act where a patient and doctor have entered into a specific contract that requires the provision of care.

Other defenses against negligence

  • No duty owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Misadventure - This may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental. Therapeutic misadventure is a situation in which a patient has suffered harm or has died as a result of an error made by a doctor or agent of the doctor or the hospital.
  • Error of judgment
  • Contributory negligence - the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant
  • Res judicata (S.300, CrPC) -If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same in another legal proceeding, based on the same set of facts. Multiple appeals cannot be made. 
  • Limitation (Res indicata) - A suit for damages for negligence must be filed within 2 years from the date of alleged negligence against the doctor. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action may be undertaken for up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Other options:

'Res ipsa loquitur' means 'the thing or fact speaks for itself'. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed, such as swabs left in the abdominal cavity post laparotomy.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of sphingolipidoses and deficient enzymes is incorrect?

choices.text: Sandhoff disease - Hexosaminidase A and B

questions.solution:
Fabry disease is due to the deficiency of α-galactosidase. β-Galactosidase deficiency results in Krabbe disease.

Fabry disease is an X-linked, multisystem, lysosomal storage disorder caused by the deficiency of α-galactosidase. This leads to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. It is seen in both men and women (less severe). It usually manifests in childhood or adolescence, with symptoms of severe agonizing pain in the palms of hands, soles of feet, and proximal extremities called acroparesthesia.

Angiokeratomas, as seen in the image below are present, which are lesions that are dark-red to blue-black, flat or slightly raised, punctate, and usually seen between the umbilicus and the knees (called the 'bathing suit area') and the trunk.

Late presentations include renal failure, and cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease, which are the leading causes of death in these patients. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and Maltese cross structures. An enzyme assay, genetic testing, or a skin or kidney biopsy showing glycolipid deposits helps establish the diagnosis. Treatment is with enzyme replacement therapy (recombinant alpha-Gal A or migalastat).

Krabbe disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and the presence of globoid bodies in white matter. It is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy due to the deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase. β-galactosidase helps in the catabolism of galactocerebroside to ceramide and galactose.

As a result, an alternative catabolic pathway shunts galactocerebroside to galactosylsphingosine. Elevated levels of these compounds are cytotoxic and cause the destruction of oligodendroglia. The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. They often do not survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

The aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels is the characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease.

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a patient with an intertrochanteric fracture of the femur was treated with the implant shown below. Identify the implant.
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows an extramedullary implant called a dynamic hip screw.

Intertrochanteric fractures of the femur can be treated by:

  • Extramedullary implants - dynamic hip screw
  • Intramedullary implants - proximal femoral nail and gamma nail.

Dynamic hip screws are used in undisplaced intertrochanteric fractures, whereas proximal femoral nails are used in displaced intertrochanteric fractures.

The below image shows a dynamic hip screw.

Advantages of using a proximal femoral nail over a dynamic hip screw include:

  • Smaller incisions
  • Reduced blood loss
  • Decreased femoral neck shortening
  • Decreased risk of infection

The below image shows a proximal femoral nail with locking and stabilization screws.

Austin Moore's implant is an older implant used in unipolar hemiarthroplasty. It can be identified by the fenestrations on the shaft of the prosthesis, as shown below.

Herbert screw is cannulated and threaded at both ends. It is designed for use in fractures of small articular bones such as carpals and scaphoid.

questions.text: Injury to the nerve marked by the red arrow in the given image results in loss of which of the following sensations of the tongue?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the lingual nerve. Injury to the lingual nerve results in loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

Points of identification: The nerve runs downwards and forwards on the surface of the medial pterygoid muscle.

In the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, general sensations are carried by the lingual nerve, and the taste sensation is carried by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

In the posterior one-third of the tongue, both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Hypoglossal nerve innervates all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except for palatoglossus, which is supplied by the vagus nerve.

Valleculae are supplied by the internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

questions.text:
You are posted as an intern in the medicine ward where your consultant asks you to make a list of all the patients who require strict therapeutic drug monitoring. All the following patients will be included in your list, except ______.
  1. Epileptic patient on phenytoin
  2. Hypertensive patient on long-term thiazide
  3. Bipolar patient on lithium
  4. Parkinsonism patient on levodopa
  5. Diabetic patient on metformin
questions.solution:
Option B is correct. Thiazide, levodopa, and metformin do not require therapeutic drug monitoring. However, phenytoin and lithium will require strict therapeutic drug monitoring because of their narrow therapeutic window.

Therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) is individualizing drug dosage by maintaining plasma or blood drug concentrations within a targeted therapeutic range or window.

Indications for TDM:

  1. Drugs with low safety margins i.e. narrow therapeutic window (e.g. digoxin, anticonvulsants, antiarrhythmics, theophylline, aminoglycosides, lithium, TCAs, immunomodulators)
  2. Drugs with high individual variations (e.g. lithium, antidepressants)
  3. Drugs with potential toxicity used in renal failure patients (e.g. aminoglycosides, vancomycin)
  4. Poisoning
  5. Drug therapy failure (e.g. failure of response to antibiotics)
  6. To check patient compliance (e.g. psycho-pharmacological agents)

TDM is not necessary for

  1. Drugs whose response is easily measured (eg. antihypertensives, anti-diabetic agents, oral anticoagulants, inhalational general anesthesia)
  2. Prodrugs (e.g. levodopa)
  3. Drugs that have long-lasting effects -Hit and run drugs e.g. reserpine, guanethidine, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, omeprazole)
  4. Irreversible action of drugs (eg. organophosphates, phenoxybenzamine)

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Asperger's syndrome?

choices.text: More common in boys than girls
Diagnosis is usually after 3 years of age

questions.solution:
Patients with Asperger's syndrome have no delay in language development.

Asperger's syndrome is an autistic spectrum disorder characterized by a wide range of impairments in social communication and restricted and repetitive behaviors.

Features of Asperger's disorder include:

  • Impairment in social interaction and development:
    • markedly abnormal nonverbal communicative gestures
    • failure to develop peer relationships at the expected level
  • Restricted interests and patterns of behavior
  • No significant delay in language, clinically significant cognitive delay, or adaptive impairment
  • Intellectual disability is not seen, IQ is normal.
  • Delayed clinical diagnosis, often at age 11 or even later

Related Pearl: Autism Spectrum Disorder

 

  Autism Rett syndrome Asperger syndrome Heller syndrome
Onset Before 3 years After 5 months After 3 years After 2 years
Gender predilection Boys Girls Boys Boys
Intellectual disability Present in 30% of the cases Present Absent Present
Language Mostly poor Mostly poor Normal Mostly poor
Remarks ---

Normal head circumference at birth.

Regression of milestones

 ---

Normal head circumference at birth.

Regression of milestones

NOTE: Rett's syndrome has been removed from DSM-5 because it was found to have a clear genetic basis.

  • Failure to develop peer relationships

  • Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors

  • Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity

interests/behaviors
