  • Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines

  • Highly restricted, fixated interests.

  • Hyper- or hyporeactivity to sensory input

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the use of cardiac biomarker troponin for the workup of a patient with suspected myocardial infarction is false?

choices.text: Troponin should be measured at presentation
Troponin assay at 2-3 hours after symptom onset has poor negative predictive value
Troponin should be repeated at 3–6 h using conventional troponin assays
Troponin should be repeated at 1–3 h using high-sensitivity troponin

questions.solution:
Troponin assay at 2-3 hours after symptom onset has an excellent negative predictive value. This means that more than 2-3 hours after symptom onset, a negative troponin is sufficient to exclude a diagnosis of myocardial infarction.

In patients with suspected ACS, troponin is:

  • Measured at presentation
  • Repeated at 1–3 h using high-sensitivity troponin
  • Repeated at 3–6 h using conventional troponin assays

Additional measurements of troponin beyond 3–6 h may be warranted when the clinical condition still suggests possible ACS or if there is diagnostic uncertainty. 

Cardiac-specific troponin T and cardiac-specific troponin I are the preferred biomarkers for detection of MI.

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text: All the following statements are correct regarding cyclophosphamide, except _______.

choices.text: It is given in cases of Burkitt lymphoma
Patients with renal impairment can take full doses of cyclophosphamide
Phosphoramide mustard is responsible for cyclophosphamide's antitumor effects

questions.solution:
All the given statements are correct regarding cyclophosphamide except option B. The active metabolite of cyclophosphamide is 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide. 

Cyclophosphamide is a nitrogen mustard that acts by alkylating DNA. Alkylation leads to cross-linking of nucleic acids with each other or with proteins leading to impaired function. 

After oral administration, cyclophosphamide is converted to 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide and aldophosphamide. Aldophosphamide gets further converted to phosphoramide mustard and acrolein. Phosphoramide mustard is responsible for the anticancer effects, while acrolein is responsible for hemorrhagic cystitis.

As cyclophosphamide is eliminated by hepatic metabolism, people with renal impairment can use it in full doses. Reduced doses should be given to patients with severe liver disease.

It is used as a combination treatment for non-Hodgkin lymphomas, other lymphoid malignancies, breast and ovarian cancers, as well as solid tumors in children. Cyclophosphamide can be used as a single treatment and complete remission is seen in Burkitt lymphoma. Cyclophosphamide has been used to treat autoimmune disorders such as Wegener granulomatosis, rheumatoid arthritis, and nephrotic syndrome due to its strong immunosuppressive properties.

To prevent hemorrhagic cystitis, patients should get vigorous intravenous hydration. Cystitis caused by cyclophosphamide is treated by systemic administration of mesna and by irrigating the bladder with acetylcysteine.

Related Pearl: Classification of antineoplastic drugs

questions.text:
A young boy who underwent an ileal resection developed bilateral centrocecal scotomas. Which of the following enzymes are dependent on the vitamin that is deficient in this condition?

1. Methylmalonyl CoA mutase
2. Cystathionine synthase
3. Folate reductase
4. Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
The clinical stem of bilateral centrocecal scotomas in a patient who had an ileal resection is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase and methionine synthase (1 and 4) are vitamin B12–dependent enzymes.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed by the terminal ileum. Thus, after ileal resection as in this patient, the development of vitamin B12 deficiency is likely. 

The vitamin B12–dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): It catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine.
  • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase: It catalyzes the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. The activity of this enzyme is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonyl-CoA and urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid, which is used to assess vitamin B12 nutritional status.

Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Other options:

Option 2- Cystathionine synthase is involved in the production of cystathionine from homocysteine and serine. Pyridoxal phosphate (the active form of vitamin B6) is required for this reaction. Hence, in vitamin B6 deficiency, homocysteine levels are elevated.

Option 3- Dihydrofolate reductase catalyzes the conversion of dihydrofolate and tetrahydrofolate. It is an NADPH-dependent reaction.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

Related Pearl: Neurological Manifestations in Deficiency Diseases

Neurological
manifestations

 Associated nutritional deficiencies
Dementia, encephalopathy Vitamin B12, nicotinic acid, thiamine, folate 
Seizures Pyridoxine
Myelopathy Vitamin B12, vitamin E, folate, copper
Myopathy Vitamin D, vitamin E
Peripheral neuropathy Thiamine, vitamin B12, and many others
Optic neuropathy Thiamine, vitamin B12, and many others

questions.text: A male patient was diagnosed with an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery. He has ocular symptoms suggestive of third cranial nerve palsy. Which of the muscles marked in the given image is not supplied by this nerve?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked as '3' in the image is superior oblique, which is innervated by the trochlear nerve (4th cranial nerve). The other muscles marked in the image, i.e., 1- superior rectus, 2- levator palpebrae superioris, and 4- inferior oblique, are supplied by the oculomotor nerve (3rd cranial nerve).

Muscles present around the eye:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

Levator palpebrae superioris originates from the lesser wing of the sphenoid, anterior to the optic canal. It inserts into the tarsal plate, superior conjunctival fornix, and skin. 

The four recti muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera in the anterior half of the eyeball.

The superior oblique originates from the body of the sphenoid, superior and medial to optic canal. The inferior oblique originates from the medial floor of the orbit and maxilla. They are inserted into the sclera of the outer posterior quadrant of the eyeball in the superior surface and inferior surface, respectively.

All the extraocular muscles (including the inferior oblique) are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus, which is innervated by the abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique, which is innervated by the trochlear (IV) nerve

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text:
Match the following causative organisms with their respective systemic mycoses.

 

1. Histoplasma a. Valley fever
2. Blastomyces b. Darling's disease
3. Coccidioides c. Brazilian blastomycosis 
4. Paracoccidioides d. North American blastomycosis
questions.solution:
The correctly matched causative organisms with their systemic mycosis is 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

1. Histoplasma-  Darling's disease
2. Blastomyces- North American blastomycosis
3. Coccidioides- Valley fever
4.Paracoccidioides Brazilian blastomycosis 

Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis/Darling's disease/reticuloendotheliosis. It has tiny oval yeast cells with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response. Patients present with fever, cough, anorexia, and lymphadenopathy. X-ray of the chest shows focal infiltrates and patchy opacities. Aspiration from lymph nodes shows the presence of intracellular yeast.

Blastomyces dermatitidis causes North American blastomycosis. It has thick-walled round yeast cells with single broad-based budding, resembling figure 8 in appearance. It is mostly seen in North America and is contracted through the inhalation of contaminated soil. Primary infection usually presents as pneumonia. Disseminated disease may lead to multiple abscesses. Cutaneous lesions present as papules and nodules which progress into large ulcerative lesions.

Coccidioides immitis causes valley fever. Spherules, which are large sac-like structures filled with endospores, are seen. Patients present with fever, cough, and severe fatigue. They may complain of night sweats and pleuritic chest pain. Chest x-ray shows mediastinal lymphadenopathy. It is most commonly seen in travelers to the southwestern USA.

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes Brazilian/South American blastomycosis and paracoccidioidal granuloma. It has round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferentially, giving rise to a Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance. Patients present with fever, fatigue, and weight loss. On examination, multiple oral lesions and hepatosplenomegaly are noted. Granulomas are seen on a biopsy of the affected tissues.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: An HIV positive patient presents with profuse, watery diarrhea and abdominal cramping for the past 2 weeks. Kinyoun staining of a stool sample is shown below. What is the likely organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
Watery diarrhea and abdominal cramping in an HIV patient with a Kinyoun-positive oocyst of the size of 25 μm in the stool sample suggest a diagnosis of a coccidian parasitic infestation by Cystoisospora.

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Cystoisospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6 μm, round,  contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round, contains 2 sporocysts, each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval, contain two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites
Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid fast Variable acid fast Uniformly acid fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

 

The below image shows oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis in the modified acid-fast stain. 

 

The below image shows oocysts of Cryptosporidium parvum in the modified acid-fast stain.

questions.text: You are performing a cardiotocograph on a woman in labor, and your findings are shown below. What could be the possible cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
The given cardiotocograph shows decelerations that are variable with respect to the size, shape, depth, duration, and timing of uterine contractions. This is indicative of variable decelerations, and the likely cause among the given options is umbilical cord compression.

Baseline variability is observed in many conditions such as:

1. Acceleration: Transient increase in fetal heart rate (FHR) by 15 bpm or more, lasting for at least 15 seconds. It denotes intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular activity and, therefore, a healthy fetus.

2. Deceleration: Transient decrease in FHR below the baseline by 15 bpm or more and lasting ≥15 seconds. Three basic types of deceleration are early, late, and variable:

  • Early deceleration/ Type I Dips: Slowing of FHR and in most cases, the phases of the deceleration (onset, nadir, and recovery) coincide with those of the uterine contraction (beginning, peak, and ending). It is due to head compression (vagal nerve activation).

 

  • Late deceleration/ Type II Dips: that begins after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak and end of the uterine contraction respectively. It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia (50%). Causes of late deceleration: (i) Placental pathology (postmaturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption); (ii) Excessive uterine contractions; (iii) Injudicious use of oxytocin; (iv) Regional anaesthesia (spinal or epidural)

 

  • Variable deceleration: The most common type of deceleration. Here the decelerations are variable, with varying parameters of size, shape, depth, duration, and timing with respect to uterine contractions. They indicate cord compression and may disappear when the patient's position is altered. Accelerations often precede and follow this type of deceleration.

 

3. Prolonged deceleration is the abrupt decrease in FHR to levels below the baseline, and it lasts for >3 min but <10 min. If it lasts for >10 min, it is a baseline change.

4. Lag period: It is the time taken for the FHR to reach the nadir (the lowest point of the FHR dip) from the apex of the preceding uterine contraction. In deceleration, the lag period is >30 seconds.

5. Sinusoidal pattern: It resembles a sine wave. It has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting >20 min. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anaemia and fetomaternal haemorrhage. It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother. Such FHR patterns are called pseudo-sinusoidal as the fetus is well-oxygenated.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient with a history of type-1 DM has not taken her insulin for three days. She is diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis. Which of the following oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves would be similar to that of the patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient with diabetic ketoacidosis, who would have a low blood pH, the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve would show a right shift, as seen in graph 1.

Hemoglobin exists in 2 forms in the blood. The deoxyhemoglobin form is called the taut or T form. This hemoglobin has a low affinity for oxygen. The oxyhemoglobin form is called the relaxed or R form. This hemoglobin has a high affinity for oxygen. 

In deoxyhemoglobin, the globin units are tightly bound in a tense (T) configuration, which reduces the affinity of the molecule for O2. When O2 is first bound, the bonds holding the globin units are released, producing a relaxed (R) configuration, which exposes more O2-binding sites. The net result is a 500-fold increase in O2 affinity. This increasing affinity is called positive cooperativity. In other words, the combination of the first heme in the tetramer with O2 increases the affinity of the second heme for O2, and oxygenation of the second increases the affinity of the third, thereby resulting in the characteristic sigmoid shape of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

If the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less, which favors O2 delivery. This means a higher P50, means higher PO2 is required to maintain 50% saturation (R - right shift releases oxygen).

If the curve is shifted to the left, it means that affinity has increased for O2 (which favors O2 binding) i.e. lower P50 value. (L-Left shift Leashes oxygen).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the clinical trials?
  1. Phases I and II are randomized controlled trials.
  2. Safety and tolerability are tested in phase I.
  3. Adverse events are determined mainly in phase III.
  4. Healthy volunteers are tested in phase I.
  5. Phase IV is regarded as a multi-site trial.
questions.solution:
Statements 2 & 4 are correct regarding clinical trials. Safety and tolerability are tested in healthy volunteers in phase I of clinical trials.

  • Statement 1- Phases II and III are randomized controlled trials.
  • Statement 3- Adverse events are determined in phase II of clinical trials. Adverse events are confirmed in phase III.
  • Statement 5- Phase III is regarded as a multisite trial and phase IV is postmarketing surveillance.

The below pearl explains the various phases of clinical trials.

Related Pearl: Phases of Clinical Trials

Phase I

(First in human)

Phase II

(First in patient)

Phase III

(Multi-site trial)

Phase IV

(Post-marketing)

10 – 100 

50 - 500 

500 - 3000

Large or according to study

Usually healthy volunteers

Patients with the target disease

Patients with the target disease

Real-world patients

Open-label study

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Usually the observational or open-label

Human pharmacology and safety: To determine safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetic parameters

Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging: To determine efficacy and dose-ranging

 

Therapeutic confirmation and comparison: Indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. Monitoring of adverse reactions is done. 

Postmarketing surveillance: To monitor drug interactions, compliance and long-term or rare side effects

Extends from months to 1 year

1–2 years

3–5 years

Unending, after drug approval

questions.text: All the following statements about Wilkie's syndrome are true except:

choices.text: It is also known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome.
It is most commonly seen in elderly obese women.
Compression occurs at third part of duodenum.
One of the surgical treatment includes duodenojejunostomy.

questions.solution:
Wilkie's syndrome is usually seen in young asthenic women. 

Wilkie's syndrome is also known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome (SMA). It is a rare condition that occurs due to the compression of the third part of the duodenum between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. 

Normally, the angle between the superior mesenteric artery and aorta (aortomesenteric angle) ranges from 38° to 65°. However, decreasing to an angle of less than 25° causes compression of the third part of the duodenum. 

This syndrome is most commonly seen in young, asthenic women. The main predisposing factors are rapid weight loss, supine immobilization, anorexia nervosa, and placement of body cast. So, it is also called cast syndrome.

Symptoms include profound nausea and vomiting; abdominal distension; weight loss; and postprandial epigastric pain, which varies from intermittent to constant, depending on the severity of the duodenal obstruction.

A barium study of the upper gastrointestinal tract demonstrates cessation of the flow of barium from the duodenum to the jejunum. A CT scan can be used to confirm SMA by measuring the aortomesenteric angle. The surgical treatment includes duodenojejunostomy, gastrojejunostomy, and duodenal derotation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida presents with a one-week history of tingling and burning sensations in her hand, which worsens at night. Examination reveals bilateral wasting of muscles in the thenar eminence and positive Phalen's test. All the following findings can be seen in this patient except:

choices.text: Positive Tinel's sign by percussion of median nerve
Loss of thumb abduction tested by pen test

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of tingling and burning sensation worsening at night, bilateral thenar muscle wasting, and positive Phalen's test in a pregnant woman suggests a diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In this condition, paresthesia is not seen over the thenar eminence as the sensory supply of this region is by the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve, which passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum. 

Carpal tunnel syndrome is a common entrapment mononeuropathy. It is a condition in which the median nerve gets entrapped in the fibro-osseous carpal tunnel while passing beneath the flexor retinaculum.

Usually, the condition is idiopathic. But it can be caused due to soft tissue thickening (myxedema, acromegaly, obesity, pregnancy), arthritic changes in the carpal bones (rheumatoid arthritis, gout), and thickening of the synovial sheaths of the flexors tendons (tenosynovitis) due to stress injury, etc. 

Patients usually present at an age of 40-50 years with complaints of burning pain, paresthesia, and numbness of the first three digits, and the lateral half of the fourth digit (ring finger). The symptoms are worse at night and are relieved by shaking the arm or hanging it over the side of the bed. It may progress to weakness and clumsiness of the hand, especially when carrying out fine movements. In advanced cases, there is wasting of the thenar muscles, weakness of thumb abduction, and decreased sensations in the median nerve territory.

Signs seen in carpal tunnel syndrome are - 

  • Ape-like hand due to wasting of the thenar eminence. 

 

  • Ape thumb deformity is characterized by the inability to abduct the thumb due to paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle supplied by the median nerve. The thumb remains in the same plane as the wrist. 

 

  • Pen test tests the abductor pollicis brevis muscle which is supplied by the median nerve. The hand must remain flat with palm facing upwards; a pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb - Positive sign is unable to touch the pen. 

 

  • Durkan's test is positive where direct median nerve compression elicits paresthesias and pain.
  • Phalen's test is elicited by holding the wrist fully flexed. The appearance of sensory symptoms within 60 seconds implies a positive test.

 

  • Tinel's sign - Sensory symptoms (burning pain, tingling and numbness) are reproduced by percussing over the median nerve implying a positive test.

The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies are done to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome.

In cases of mild clinical symptoms, splinting or glucocorticoid injections may be first tried. Surgical division of the transverse carpal ligament is recommended for severe CTS or if non-surgical management fails.

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Syndrome 

Nerve involved

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenburg syndrome)

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Median nerve (at wrist)

Guyon's canal syndrome

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Thoracic outlet syndrome

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

Posterior tibial nerve

Piriformis syndrome

Sciatic nerve
Meralgia paresthetica Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Mortons Metatarsalgia Interdigital plantar nerve 
Notalgia Paresthetica Superficial sensory neuropathy in the infrascapular area (Pruritus + Dysaesthesia)

questions.text: A man is brought to the emergency with a head injury following a motorcycle accident. His wife reports he was unconscious for around 5 minutes and vomited thrice. On examination, he is drowsy, with fixed and dilated pupils. CT scan of the head is shown below. What is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?

choices.text: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery

questions.solution:
The given scenario of a man with a head injury, unconsciousness, vomiting, dilated and fixed pupils, and the CT finding of a lenticular hemorrhage is characteristic of an extradural or epidural hemorrhage. The most likely cause is the rupture of the middle meningeal artery.

Epidural hemorrhage or hematoma is an intracranial hemorrhage in which the hemorrhage is between the dura and the skull. It classically occurs due to a tear of the middle meningeal artery, following a fracture of the temporal bone. 

Clinically, patients with extradural hemorrhage typically present with an initial transient loss of consciousness. A lucid interval is then seen, which may be minutes to hours during which the patient usually presents. Neurological deterioration then occurs following the lucid interval as the hematoma expands. Reduced consciousness, ipsilateral pupillary dilatation, and hemiparesis can be seen. 

CT scan shows a characteristic hyperdense biconvex or lenticular-shaped hematoma. 

Management is by surgical evacuation of the hematoma or by ligation of the damaged middle meningeal artery. 

Other options:

Option B: Chronic subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a type of intracranial hemorrhage that occurs between the dura and the arachnoid layer. It is due to the shearing of bridging veins and appears as a crescentic clot on a CT scan. Symptoms like drowsiness, headache, confusion, or mild hemiparesis occur days or weeks after the injury.

Options C and D: Subarachnoid hemorrhage can occur due to the rupture of small cortical arteries or veins due to trauma and the rupture of saccular aneurysms. Clinically, patients present with sudden and severe headaches, commonly called thunderclap headaches. It can be associated with seizures, unresponsiveness, and vomiting. CT scan shows blood in basal cisterns and rounded lesions suggesting aneurysms.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A young man is brought to the emergency room with breathlessness and shock following a steering wheel injury to his chest. Which of the following examination findings will help you differentiate tension pneumothorax from cardiac tamponade?
questions.solution:
Breath sounds help differentiate tension pneumothorax from cardiac tamponade since they are absent in tension pneumothorax.

Tension pneumothorax is characterized by absent breath sounds and hyperresonance on percussion on the affected side. These signs are not observed in a patient with cardiac tamponade. 

The three most important findings to diagnose tension pneumothorax are respiratory distress, hyper-tympany on percussion, and decreased lung sounds. 

Other classic findings in tension pneumothorax are hypotension, jugular venous distension, and shift of mediastinal structures to the unaffected side with tracheal deviation. Tracheal deviation is a late finding of tension pneumothorax.

The definitive treatment for tension pneumothorax is tube thoracostomy preferably in the fourth intercostal space at the anterior axillary line.

Cardiac tamponade must be diﬀerentiated from tension pneumothorax in a patient with hemodynamic instability and distended neck veins.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by Beck’s triad:

  • Muffled heart sounds- But they are difficult to assess in the noisy emergency rooms.
  • Distended neck veins
  • Hypotension

Diagnosis of cardiac tamponade can be done by eFAST, which shows fluid in the pericardial sac. 

Management of cardiac tamponade:

  • Emergency management - ultrasound-guided needle pericardiocentesis via subxiphoid route 
  • Definitive management - emergency thoracotomy or sternotomy
 

Related Pearl: Causes of Pulsus Paradoxus

Physiological causes

Obesity

Pregnancy

Cardiovascular causes

Cardiac tamponade – most common cause

Constrictive pericarditis ( in 1/3rd cases )

Massive pulmonary embolism

Severe CCF

Hypovolemic shock

Respiratory causes

Severe obstructive lung disease

Acute severe asthma

Severe emphysema

Tension pneumothorax

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: You receive a patient for resuscitation following a road traffic accident and a huge amount of blood loss. The patient presents with features of hypovolemic shock. In your hospital, only the following 4 cannulas are available. Which of them would you use in the fluid resuscitation of this patient?
questions.solution:
For trauma patients who require a high volume of fluid replacement and multiple blood transfers, large-sized, wide-bored cannulas are preferred. Among the given options, 16G size grey cannula would be appropriate.

Ideally, in cases where there is a requirement for a massive transfusion, 2 peripheral 14G-orange cannulas are indicated. Larger cannulae have a smaller gauge number.

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae

Size Color Coding Flow Rate Uses
14G Orange 270ml/min Trauma Patients, Rapid, Large Volume replacement
16G Grey 236ml/min Trauma Patients, Major Surgery, Intra Partum/Post Partum, GI bleeds, Multiple blood transfers, High volume of Fluids
17G White 125ml/min Newly added
18G Green 103 ml/min Blood products, delivery of irritant medications, major surgery, contrast study
20G Pink 67ml/min General use IV maintenance, IV antibiotics, IV analgesics
22G Blue 42 ml/min Small or Fragile veins, Cytotoxic Therapy
24G Yellow 20ml/min For pediatric Usage
26G Violet 13ml/min Newly added

questions.text:
A young male patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. At the time of admission to casualty, his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was E2V2M4. After a few hours, it became E1V1M3. His CT brain was normal and an MRI of the brain is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

E- Eye opening
V- Verbal response
M- Motor response
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and a susceptibility-weighted MRI image (SWI) demonstrating hypointense foci of microhemorrhages are suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse axonal injury (white matter shearing) is the result of shearing forces, typically from acceleration, deceleration, or rotational forces. This causes damage in the microvasculature and disruption of axons in the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, corpus callosum, and midbrain.

Most commonly, it occurs in automobile accidents. Patients are usually unconscious from the moment of impact and remain the same until death.

Diffuse axonal injury is characterized by multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution:

  • CT may be normal.
  • MRI is the modality of choice for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury even in patients with entirely normal CT of the brain. It detects the micro-bleeds within the brain.

Other options:

Option B - Intraventricular hemorrhage occurs as a result of bleeding from the choroid plexus or rupture of germinal matrix hemorrhages into the ventricles. The germinal matrix is a site of neuronal proliferation during fetal development and disappears at term. Therefore, these hemorrhages are more common in babies. CT images showing intraventricular hemorrhages are given below.

 

Option C- Subdural hemorrhage is often due to the rupture of bridging veins that crosses the subdural space. In subdural hemorrhage, the CT shows crescentic opacity. 

The image below shows a CT of a subdural hemorrhage.

 

Option D- Extradural hemorrhage is mostly due to the rupture of the middle meningeal artery. Since the dura matter tends to adhere to the skull, the hemorrhage is seen in CT as a biconvex dense area. They usually do not cross cranial sutures.

The image below shows a CT of an extradural hemorrhage.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

Image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red:

questions.text:
The image below shows the effect of various factors on the levels of a hormone. Identify the correct statements regarding the hormone.
  1. It is regulated by GHRH and ghrelin.
  2. Its action on sodium is mediated by IGF-1.
  3. It can be suppressed by the administration of oral glucose.
  4. Its secretion decreases after a protein meal.
  5. Its secretion is increased by ghrelin.
questions.solution:
The hormone depicted in the graph shows pulsatile secretion, with an increase during strenuous exercise and early period of sleep, indicating that it is the growth hormone (GH). The correct statements regarding GH are 1, 3, and 5 (option B).

Growth hormone is secreted from the somatotropes located in the anterior pituitary. Its main role is the growth of the human body.

The levels of growth hormones show diurnal variation as well as variation across different age groups. Adolescents have the highest circulating levels of growth hormone, followed by children and adults. The levels are relatively low during the day and the pulsatile release of this hormone occurs during sleep.

Important regulators of growth hormone:

  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone- stimulates the production of the hormone
  • Somatostatin- inhibits the release of GH
  • Ghrelin- increases the GH release

Stimuli that increase GH secretion:

  • Hypoglycemia, deoxyglucose, fasting
  • Exercise
  • Protein meal, infusion of arginine
  • Glucagon
  • Deep sleep
  • Estrogens and androgens
  • Stressful stimuli

Stimuli that decrease GH secretion:

  • Glucose
  • Cortisol
  • Free fatty acids
  • Growth hormone and IGF-1
  • REM sleep
  • Medroxyprogesterone

GH can act directly on the cells or mediate its actions through insulin-like growth factors (IGF). The functions which are mediated through IGFs are insulin-like activity, anti-lipolytic activity, protein synthesis, and epiphyseal growth. Direct actions of GH are sodium retention, decreased insulin sensitivity, lipolysis, protein synthesis, and epiphyseal growth.

Actions of growth hormone:

  • Growth of cartilage, bones, and organs.
  • Increases amino acid uptake and protein synthesis in the cells and decreases protein breakdown.
  • Diabetogenic action: Increases the hepatic glucose release and decreases the glucose uptake by muscles and fat.
  • Increases fat utilization. It is ketogenic and increases circulating free fatty acid levels.

Since somatostatin inhibits the release of GH, somatostatin analogs like octreotide and lanreotide are used in the treatment of acromegaly.

questions.text: While prescribing which of the following antidiabetic drugs should you warn the patient about the risk of weight gain?
questions.solution:
While prescribing the antidiabetic drug glyburide, a sulfonylurea, the doctor should warn the patient about the risk of weight gain.

By inhibiting the activity of a specific location on the β cell K ATP channel complex in the cell, sulfonylureas promote the release of insulin. Inhibiting KATP channels results in cell membrane depolarization and the series of events that trigger the production of insulin.

First-generation sulfonylureas: tolbutamide, tolazamide, and chlorpropamide (rarely used now in the treatment of diabetes) 

Second-generation sulfonylureas: glyburide (glibenclamide), glipizide, and glimepiride

Important side effects are hypoglycemia and weight gain. They can induce a disulfiram-like reaction.

Other options:

Option A: Metformin is considered weight neutral. Other advantages of this drug are that it does not cause hypoglycemia and is inexpensive. Side effects may include diarrhea, nausea, and lactic acidosis. Prolonged use leads to vitamin B12 deficiency.

Option B: Empagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor and is known to cause mild weight loss. It also causes blood pressure reduction and does not cause hypoglycemia. They increase the risk of urinary tract infections and can increase the risk of fractures.

Option C: Pramlintide is an amylin agonist. It reduces postprandial glycemia and leads to weight loss.

questions.text: A 51-year-old diabetic male patient presented with headaches and eye pain for a few months. He also reports difficulty in driving at night and frequent changes in presbyopic glasses. On examination, his intraocular pressure (IOP) was 22 mmHg, and fundoscopy showed the laminar dot sign. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the other fundus changes seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the finding of the laminar dot sign and raised IOP, is suggestive of primary open-angle glaucoma, and a cup:disc ratio of less than 0.5 is not seen in this condition.

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is chronic, progressive optic neuropathy. It is mostly seen in more than 40 years of age, and it runs in family. The major risk factors are diabetes mellitus and myopia.

Most often patients having POAG present with headaches, frequent changes in presbyopic correction, and difficulty in dark adaptation. 

The fundus examination in glaucoma shows a cup:disc ratio of more than 0.5 and an asymmetry between the cup:disc ratio of two eyes of more than 0.2. 

Other changes:

  • Narrowing and notching of the neuroretinal rim (NRR)
  • Disc hemorrhages extending from the NRR onto the retina
  • Bayoneting sign due to the double angulation of a blood vessel
  • Loss of nasal NRR is characterized by developing space between the NRR and the central retinal vasculature
  • The laminar dot sign is the grey dot-like fenestration in the exposed lamina cribrosa as the NRR recedes.

Patients with affected first-degree relatives, diabetics, and myopes should be examined regularly after the age of 40 years to rule out glaucoma.

Medical Management includes:

Prostaglandin derivatives enhance the uveoscleral aqueous outflow and decrease IOP more than the other alternatives. They are preferred over beta-blockers as the first-line treatment for glaucoma because of the latter's potential systemic side effects. Some of the agents used are:

  • Latanoprost
  • Bimatoprost
  • Travoprost

Beta-blockers reduce IOP by decreasing aqueous production. They cause bronchospasm and can be fatal in asthmatics. In predisposed individuals, they can cause heart block, bradycardia, and worsening of heart failure. Agents include timolol, betaxolol, and levobunolol.

Alpha-2 agonists reduce IOP by decreasing the aqueous formation and increasing uveoscleral outflow. They can potentiate vascular insufficiency. Therapeutic agents used are brimonidine and apraclonidine.

Topical carbonic acid inhibitors reduce IOP by decreasing aqueous formation. They are slightly less effective than beta-blockers and contraindicated in patients with allergies to sulfa drugs. Some of the agents used are dorzolamide and brinzolamide. 

Miotics like pilocarpine were formerly used for open-angle glaucoma. 

Medical, laser, or surgical therapies can be used to achieve a target pressure of 16-18 mmHg, which results in the stabilization of POAG in most patients. Laser therapy for POAG consists of laser trabeculoplasty and is indicated only if the patient is refractory to medications and not compliant for surgery. 

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

Related Pearl: Important adverse effects of anti-glaucoma drugs

Anti-glaucoma drug The adverse effects
Beta-blockers

Corneal hypoesthesia

Systemic side effects
Sympathomimetics

Lid retraction

CNS depression and apnea in infants and children (<2 years)
Prostaglandin analogs

Eyelash hypertrichosis

Macular edema

Iris pigmentation (Heterochromia iridis)

Peri-orbital fat depletion
Miotics

Retinal detachment

Cataract
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Systemic side effects

Corneal edema

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman underwent a Pap test, which showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, as per the Bethesda system of classification. This is the first Pap test she has undergone. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In a 26-year-old woman with a pap test showing atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance, the next step is reflex HPV testing.

Reflex HPV testing refers to HPV testing that is done in response to a specific result (such as abnormal cytology in this case). It is not performed if cytology is negative.

Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASC-US) is the most common cervical cytologic abnormality. They represent cells that suggest squamous intraepithelial lesions but do not fulfill all the criteria for them. The risk of progression to CIN 2 or 3 is low, but it may occur.

Management of ASC-US:

  • Women aged 21 to 24 years: Repeat cytology in 1 year. If the repeat Pap test result is abnormal, colposcopy should be done. Reflex HPV can be done in this age group. If the result is negative, they are followed up with cytology.
  • Women 25 years and older: Reflex HPV testing.
    • Reflex HPV test result is positive: Further evaluation with colposcopy.
    • Reflex HPV test result is negative: Follow up with a cotest (HPV test+ cytology) in 3 years.

Bethesda system of cytology reporting for squamous cell abnormalities:

  • Atypical squamous cells (ASC)
    • ASC-US - atypical cells of undetermined significance
    • ASC-H - cannot rule out a high-grade lesion
  • Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL)- includes CIN I
  • High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL)- includes CIN II, III
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text:
A patient is brought with altered sensorium and seizures. The attender shows a laboratory report, which reveals elevated levels of transaminases. Which of the following can be used in this patient?
  1. Alprazolam
  2. Temazepam
  3. Diazepam
  4. Oxazepam
  5. Lorazepam
questions.solution:
Temazepam, oxazepam, and lorazepam can be used in the give case.

Hepatic CYPs like 3A4 and 2C19 extensively metabolize the majority of benzodiazepines. Certain benzodiazepines, including oxazepam, lorazepam, and temazepam, undergo phase 2 conjugation, rather than being broken down by CYPs. Therefore, these drugs do not get accumulated in case of liver function impairment.

The metabolism of diazepam and alprazolam is significantly decreased in liver impairment, and therefore, these drugs are not suitable for use in this scenario.

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Intoxication features

Tremors, delirium, seizures
Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech
BZD
Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.
Opioid/ Heroin
Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.
Nicotine/ Tobacco
Increased appetite
Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.
Cocaine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.
LSD/ Haluccinogen
Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.
Phencyclidine (PCP)
Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

questions.text: A 70-year-old disabled paraplegia patient from rural area with no family was admitted to a tertiary health center for pneumonia. Which of the following is true regarding the benefits this patient would receive under the Ayushman Bharat - National Health Protection Mission?

choices.text: Treatment for pneumonia would be covered, but treatment for paralysis would not be covered under this program.
Being a disabled citizen with no family, he would be automatically included in the scheme.
The maximum age limit to avail the benefits under this programme is 65 years, so he would not receive any benefits.
A registration fees of rupees 2000 is mandatory before enrolling into the program.

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is a disabled citizen with no family so would be automatically included in the National Health Protection Mission which is a component of Ayushman Bharat.

Out of the total 7 deprivation criteria for rural areas, PM-JAY covers all such families who fall into at least one of the following 6 deprivation criteria and automatic inclusion criteria:

  • D1- Only one room with kucha walls and kucha roof
  • D2- No adult member between ages 16 to 59
  • D3- Households with no adult male member between ages 16 to 59
  • D4- Disabled member and no able-bodied adult member
  • D5- SC/ST households
  • D7- Landless households deriving a major part of their income from manual casual labour

Automatically included:

  • Households without shelter
  • Destitute/ living on alms
  • Manual scavenger families
  • Primitive tribal groups
  • Legally released bonded labour

 For Urban:

  • Occupational Categories of Workers
  • Rag picker
  • Beggar
  • Domestic worker
  • Street vendor/ Cobbler/hawker / Other service provider working on streets
  • Construction worker/ Plumber/ Mason/ Labour/ Painter/ Welder/ Security guard/
  • Coolie and another head-load worker
  • Sweeper/ Sanitation worker / Mali
  • Home-based worker/ Artisan/ Handicrafts worker / Tailor
  • Transport worker/ Driver/ Conductor/ Helper to drivers and conductors/ Cart puller/ Rickshaw puller
  • Shop worker/ Assistant/ Peon in small establishment/ Helper/Delivery assistant /Attendant/ Waiter
  • Electrician/ Mechanic/ Assembler/ Repair worker
  • Washer-man/ Chowkidar

Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission:

Beneficiary Level: 

  • The government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • More than 10.74 crore poor and vulnerable families (approximately 50 crore beneficiaries) are covered across the country.
  • All families listed in the Socio-economic caste census (SECC) database as per defined criteria will be covered. 
  • It covers up to 3 days of pre-hospitalization and 15 days post-hospitalization expenses such as diagnostics and medicines.
  • There is no restriction on the family size, age or gender.
  • All pre-existing conditions are covered from day one.
  • Benefits of the scheme are portable across the country i.e. a beneficiary can visit any empanelled public or private hospital in India to avail cashless treatment.
  • Services include approximately 1,393 procedures covering all the costs related to treatment, including but not limited to drugs, supplies, diagnostic services, physician's fees, room charges, surgeon charges, OT and ICU charges etc.
  • Public hospitals are reimbursed for the healthcare services at par with the private hospitals.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with multiple erosions on the skin and oral mucosa. She has a history of similar lesions in the past. The histopathology image of her skin biopsy is shown below. Which of the following autoantibodies are seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette, with the characteristic row-of-tombstones appearance, is seen in pemphigus vulgaris. It is also showing suprabasal split. The characteristic pattern seen in the direct immunofluorescence study of such lesions is the fish-net pattern/ chicken-wire appearance. Anti-desmoglein antibodies are positive in pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic immunobullous disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins expressed in the skin and mucosa. In the skin, desmoglein 1 is mostly seen in all layers, while desmoglein 3 is more in the lower layers. In the oral mucosa, desmoglein 3 is seen in all layers and desmoglein 1 is present in lower layers.

Clinically, the patients present with ill-defined, irregular, slow-to-heal oral lesions and erosions. Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid may arise on normal skin or an erythematous base. The rupture of such blisters produces painful erosions and heals without scarring. Lesions may also involve the mucosa of the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, esophagus, urethra, vulva, or cervix. 

Nikolsky's sign is positive, which is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing erosion.

Direct immunofluorescence is considered the most accurate confirmatory test of this condition. It shows intercellular IgG and C3 deposition on the surface of keratinocytes throughout the epidermis in normal, perilesional skin, in a characteristic fishnet/ chickenwire appearance, as seen below.

Histology shows a suprabasal split of the epidermis with a characteristic row of tombstone appearance, as seen below.

Systemic corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for controlling the disease, improving the quality of life, and reducing disease activity.

Other options:

Option A: Anti-transglutaminase antibodies are positive in dermatitis herpetiformis. Patients present with erythematous papules and vesicles on the extensor aspect of elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. Histopathology demonstrates subepidermal blister formation with neutrophils located at the tips of the dermal papillae. Direct immunofluorescence will reveal the deposition of IgA in the papillary dermis in a granular or fibrillar pattern.

Option B: Anti-desmoplakin antibodies are positive in paraneoplastic pemphigus. It is most commonly associated with non-Hodgkin lymphoma.  Patients will present with severe stomatitis and conjunctivitis which may be scarring and esophageal, genital mucosal, and flexural involvement together with bullous and erosive lesions. The histopathology shows a lichenoid pattern.

Option D: BP180 and NC16A antibodies are positive in bullous pemphigoid. Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by tense blisters, erosions, and intense pruritus with no predominant mucosal involvement in elderly patients. 

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: A patient presents with cystocele and rectocele. Which level of uterine support is likely to be damaged as per the DeLancey classification?
questions.solution:
Damage to DeLancey level II structures results in cystocele and rectocele.

Level II supports mainly consist of pubocervical fascia anteriorly, rectovaginal fascia (along with septum) posteriorly, and paracolpos (vascular and connective tissue structures present beside the cervix). As the name suggests, pubocervical fascia connects the cervix to the posterior surface of the pubic bone. The rectovaginal septum separates the rectum from the vagina and cervix of the uterus. Together, these structures form a supportive sling that helps maintain the position of the bladder and rectum. Therefore, damage to these structures results in cystocele and rectocele.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Perineal Body

The perineal body is not a structure but an aggregation of fibromuscular tissue located in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangles, just ventral to the anal sphincter.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body.

Category Muscles
Two unpaired
  • Fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Fibres from External anal sphincter
Four Paired
  • Bulbospongiosus
  • Superficial transverse perenei
  • Deep transverse perenei
  • Levator ani

Note: In females, sphincter urethrovaginalis is also attached here.

questions.text: A patient presents with anemia, weight loss, and fever. A peripheral blood smear was done, and the findings are shown below. Which among the following will indicate a poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm are suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (ALL). Among the given options, translocations t(9,22) and t(4;11) are indicators of a poor prognosis in ALL.

Related Pearl: Prognostic Factors in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

Good prognostic markers  Bad prognostic markers 
Age between 2 and 10 years 

Age younger than 2 years 

Presentation in adolescence or adulthood
Low white cell count  Peripheral blood blast counts greater than 100,000,
Female  Male 
Hyperdiploidy  Hypodiploidy  
Trisomy of chromosomes 4, 7, 10 & 17  Pseudodiploidy or t (9;22)  or t (8;14) or t (4;11) 
 t (12;21)  MLL gene rearrangements 
Early precursor B cell phenotype  T cell phenotype

questions.text: The cut section of the forearm is shown. Identify the type of joint labeled with a question mark.
questions.solution:
The given cross-section of the forearm with the visible tendon of the brachialis and biceps brachii shows the proximal radioulnar joint. The proximal radioulnar joint is an example of a pivot synovial joint.

The radius and ulna are united with each other by three joints: The proximal (superior) radioulnar joint, middle radioulnar joint, and distal (inferior) radioulnar joint. 

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm. A section at the level of the distal radioulnar joint can be identified by the presence of pronator quadratus, extensor retinaculum, ulnar nerve, medial nerve, etc.

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses, an oblique cord, and an interosseous membrane. A section at the level of the middle radioulnar joint can be identified by the presence of major muscles of the forearm like flexor digitorum profundus, flexor digitorum superficialis, extensor digitorum, and extensor carpi ulnaris.

 Based on the structure, joints are classified into three types:

  • Fibrous joints
    • Sutures- Skull
    • Syndesmosis- bones are connected by the interosseus ligament. e.g. inferior tibiofibular joint
    • Gomphosis- peg and socket type of joint. e.g. teeth
  • Cartilaginous joints
    • Primary cartilaginous joints or synchondrosis- These joints are united by hyaline cartilage and later they are replaced by bone. They are present in growth plates
    • Secondary cartilaginous joints or symphysis- These joints are mainly united by fibrocartilage, and they persist throughout life. e.g. manubriosternal joint, intervertebral joints, and the symphysis pubis.
  • Synovial joints
    • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
    • Sellar or saddle joints
    • Condylar or bicondylar joints
    • Ellipsoid joints
    • Hinge joints
    • Pivot or trochoid joints
    • Plane joints

The illustration below depicts the types of fibrous joints.

The illustration below depicts the types of synovial joints.

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text:
During the antenatal assessment of a mother, you would suspect probable fetal asphyxia if the biophysical profile score is ________.

AFI- Amniotic fluid index
questions.solution:
Fetal asphyxia would be suspected when the biophysical profile (BPP) score is 4/10.

BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency. It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30-minute time period.

Components of BPP: (Mnemonic: BATMaN)

  • B - Breathing movements of the fetus
  • A - Amniotic fluid volume (AFI)
  • T - Tone of the fetus
  • M - Movements of the fetus
  • N - Non-stress test (NST)

Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and a minimum score of 0. So the total maximum score will be 10. A score of 4 or less indicates fetal acidemia.

Interpretation of the BPP scores and the corresponding management:

BPP score Fetal asphyxia Management
10
No

Repeat test weekly 

8 
with
normal
AFV

 No

Repeat test weekly 
8
with decreased AFV		 Suspicion of chronic asphyxia Deliver, if 
≥36 weeks
6
with 
normal
AFV		  Equivocal Deliver, if ≥37 weeks,
if <37 weeks, repeat test in 24 hours
6
with decreased AFV
 Possible

Deliver, if 36-37 weeks
4 Probable  Deliver, if 
≥32 weeks
0-2 Almost certain  Delivery 

 

BPP is directly related to fetal pH and fetal outcome. A lower BPP score is associated with a poor outcome (stillbirth, perinatal mortality) and lower APGAR scores at birth.

A score of 8-10 is associated with a normal pH and a score of 0 is associated with significant fetal acidemia.

Note: The modified biophysical score has only 2 components i.e NST and amniotic fluid index only. It is considered abnormal (nonreassuring) when the NST is non-reactive and/or the AFI is <5.

Related Pearl: Change in the amniotic fluid volume through gestation

Period of gestation   Amniotic fluid volume
10 weeks 10-20 mL
16 weeks 250 mL
33 weeks 800 mL
38-39 weeks plateaus at 1000 mL
40 weeks  800

Note: The average volume increases with gestational age, peaking at 800-1000 mL, which coincides with 36-37 weeks' gestation.

questions.text: During an autopsy of a man with a suspected case of poisoning, you observe the presence of a bitter almond odor. Which of the following electron transport chain (ETC) complexes may have been inhibited by this poison?
questions.solution:
Complex IV of the electron transport chain (ETC) is blocked by cyanide, which has a characteristic bitter almond odor in case of poisoning.

Complex IV: Cyt c oxidase Hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide
 ATP synthase Oligomycin

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman nearing her due date was admitted on presenting with labor pain. The resident doctor examined the patient and told the intern that the head is at +3 station. Where is the exact position of the head?
questions.solution:
The exact position of the head when it is at +3 station is 3 cm below the ischial spine.

The station of the head is described in relation to ischial spines as they are the most prominent bony projections felt on internal examination.

The level of ischial spines is halfway between the pelvic inlet and outlet. This level is known as station zero (0). The levels above and below the spines are designated based on centimeters, 1 cm away from station 0 is either +1 or -1 station. If the presenting part is above the spines, it is stated with a minus sign (such as -1 cm, -2 cm) and if it is below the spines, it is stated with a plus sign (such as +1 cm, +2 cm).

Related Pearl: Functional divisions of labor

Preparatory division Dilatational division Pelvic division
Latent phase + acceleration phases The phase of maximum slope Deceleration phase + the second stage of labor

Little cervical dilatation

The most rapid rate of dilatation

 Cardinal fetal movements of cephalic presentation occur

Sedation and conduction analgesia can arrest this division

 Unaffected by sedation  --

questions.text: A 55-year-old hypertensive man presents with a dry cough and severe chest pain. Two months ago, he had an inferior wall myocardial infarction and was treated with stenting of the right coronary artery. He is febrile and hemodynamically stable, and cardiac examination shows a high-pitched scratching sound. The ECG is shown below. The troponin I level is 0.2 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-myocardial infarction (MI) patient presenting with pleuritic chest pain, fever, malaise, pericardial rub on auscultation, and the ECG given above showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with upward concavity are suggestive of postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome).

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome), a type of postcardiac injury syndrome, usually occurs 1–6 weeks after MI due to immune-complex mediated damage in the pericardium. Patients typically present with features of acute pericarditis such as fever, tachypnea, chest pain that is worse during inspiration and lying down, a pericardial rub, increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST elevations on ECG. Dressler syndrome may also cause pericardial effusion.

Treatment:

  • First-line therapy consists of high-dose aspirin
  • Colchicine enhances the response to NSAIDs and prevents recurrence in patients with severe disease.
Other complications of Myocardial infarction
  1. Myocardial rupture
  2. Contractile dysfunction
  3. Arrhythmia:
    • Ventricular fibrillation is the most common arrhythmia within the first 24 hours of MI
    • Supraventricular tachycardia
    • Heart block
  4. Pericarditis: occur even 48 hrs after MI
  5. Dressler syndrome or post-MI syndrome: usually 2–3 weeks after a transmural MI
  6. Ventricular aneurysm
  7. Progressive late heart failure (chronic IHD)
  8. Infarct expansion associated with mural thrombus
  9. Papillary muscle dysfunction

Option A: Ventricular aneurysm occurs weeks to months after an MI and presents with congestive heart failure, arterial embolisms, or ventricular arrhythmias. They present with a double diffuse apical pulse on examination due to apical aneurysms.

Option C: Cardiac wall rupture results in cardiac tamponade. Patients with cardiac tamponade would have features such as dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, pulsus paradoxus, and increased jugular venous pressure, unlike this patient, who is hemodynamically stable.

Option D: Pulmonary embolism may present with cough, low-grade fever, chest pain, and ST elevations, but patients would also have hemodynamic instability, risk factors of immobility, or clinical features of deep vein thrombosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following cyanotic heart diseases cause decreased pulmonary blood flow?
  1. Ebstein anomaly
  2. Tetralogy of Fallot
  3. Simple transposition of the great arteries
  4. Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication
  5. Transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
questions.solution:
The cyanotic congenital heart diseases that cause decreased pulmonary blood flow are Ebstein anomaly, Tetralogy of Fallot, and transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis.

Classification of cyanotic congenital heart diseases based on pulmonary blood flow is as follows:

Decreased pulmonary blood flow:

  1. Tetralogy of Fallot
  2. Pulmonary atresia with an intact ventricular septum
  3. Ebstein anomaly
  4. Transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
  5. Tricuspid atresia with pulmonary stenosis
  6. Double-outlet right ventricle with pulmonary stenosis
  7. Isolated right ventricular hypoplasia

 Increased pulmonary blood flow:

  1. Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) with intact ventricular septum also called simple TGA
  2. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR)
  3. Truncus arteriosus

Related Pearl: Classification of congenital heart disease

Acyanotic
Cyanotic (5TE²VP)
Left to right shunts:

Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

Atrial septal defect (ASD)

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Obstructive lesions:

Coarctation of aorta

Infundibular stenosis

Pulmonary valve stenosis

Congenital mitral & tricuspid regurgitation
