questions.text: A physiologist studies a chemoreceptor that detects elevated sodium levels and decreases the glomerular filtration rate. In the given image of the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which of the marked structures represents this chemoreceptor?
questions.solution:
The chemoreceptors that detect elevated sodium and decrease the glomerular filtration rate are the macula densa cells in the distal convoluted tubule. These are marked as '1' in the given illustration.

Macula densa cells are chemoreceptors that detect sodium and chloride concentrations of the tubular fluid. In response to elevated sodium and chloride, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, resulting in decreased flow of blood to the glomerulus and reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This vasoconstriction is mediated via increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity leading to increased adenosine formation resulting in calcium release. 

The given illustration shows:

1- Macula densa: These are specialized cells at the start of the distal convoluted tubule form the macula densa. 

2- Granular cells/JG cells: These are modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole; these are mechanoreceptors that secrete renin in response to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn, increases the blood pressure. 

3- Lacis cells: These are extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. 

4- Proximal tubular cells: These are involved in sustaining glomerulotubular balance, a mechanism by which the percentage of the reabsorbed solutes is maintained at constant levels. This is achieved by increasing the reabsorption of the solutes and water in the proximal convoluted tubule in response to increased GFR.

questions.text: Identify the procedure for which the given instrument tray is used.
questions.solution:
The given tray contains the Jamshidi biopsy needle which is used to perform bone marrow biopsy.

Jamshidi bone marrow biopsy needle, instrument number 3, is the key identifier.

Equipment: 

  1. Stylet
  2. Cap
  3. Jamshidi Biopsy needle-wide bore.
  4. J-shaped obturator for removing the biopsy core from the needle
  5. No. 11 blade to give a stab at the selected site
  6. Glass slides
  7. Drapes
  8. Sponge holder
  9. Disposable syringes - to give local anesthesia and then to collect samples
  10. Needles - to give local anesthesia and then to collect samples
  11. Bowl for antiseptic solution
  12. Kidney tray
  13. Gauze pieces
  14. Injectable lidocaine 2% for local anesthesia

Indications of bone marrow biopsy:

  • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia.
  • Evaluation of polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis.
  • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors.
  • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias.
  • Evaluation of suspected infiltrative and storage diseases.
  • Evaluation of fever of unknown origin suspected mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections or granulomatous diseases.

Contraindications of bone marrow biopsy: 

  • Severe hemophilia.
  • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.
  • Severe bleeding disorders.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presented with a complaint of lower backache. The MRI of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Her bone mineral density is measured, and her T-score is -2.8. She is given oral drugs, but she develops esophagitis. Which of the following intravenous treatment plans would be useful in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray depicts the ballooning of disc spaces, leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body, which is known as the ‘codfish' appearance. Along with a T-score of -2.8, it is diagnostic of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Zoledronate 5 mg intravenous annually is used in the management of postmenopausal osteoporosis. It belongs to a class of drugs called bisphosphonates.

Bisphosphonates inhibit bone resorption and thus are very effective for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. They get concentrated at sites of active remodeling and remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

Routes of administration - Certain bisphosphonates like etidronate, alendronate, risedronate, and tiludronate may be administered orally, while others like zoledronate, ibandronate, and pamidronate can be given intravenously. Intravenous formulations are given when oral formulations cannot be taken due to side effects like esophagitis.

Zoledronate: It can be administered via intravenous infusion for over 15 minutes. It is given once a year, and the dose given is 5 mg for osteoporosis in postmenopausal females. A single 5-mg infusion of zoledronate is also used for the treatment of Paget disease, lowering bone turnover markers for 6 months without losing its therapeutic impact. For patients with hormone-treated prostate and breast cancer, zoledronate is frequently given to prevent osteoporosis. Both vertebral and nonvertebral fractures are decreased by it. For the treatment of multiple myeloma, bone metastases from solid tumors, or hypercalcemia of malignancy, a 4-mg formulation is offered for intravenous administration. 

Other options:

Options A and B - Teriparatide is a recombinant parathormone analog that has an anabolic effect on bone homeostasis when given intermittently. It acts by increasing osteoblastic activity. It increases bone mineral density and decreases the risk of fractures in postmenopausal women. It is administered as a subcutaneous injection of 20 μg once daily.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for osteoporosis:

Risk factor for osteoporosis
Low BMI
Family history of osteoporosis
Old age
Previous fragility fracture
Chronic use of glucocorticoids
Family history of hip fractures
Smoking and alcohol intake
Drugs like anticonvulsants, anticoagulants and thyroid replacement therapy
Hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, and malabsorption syndrome

questions.text: A study was done to investigate whether three new antibiotics used for urinary tract infections cured the disease or not. Which of the following statistical tests can be used to test the significance of this study?
questions.solution:
The statistical test used to test the significance of this qualitative data, also known as categorical data, is the chi-square test.

The Chi-square statistic is a test designed to analyze group differences when the dependent variable is qualitative. This statistical test can be used to determine whether the antibiotic was effective or not.

The outcome of this study would be either "the antibiotics cured the disease" or "the antibiotics did not cure the disease." Hence, this study has two qualitative variables. Sometimes the results of a study are grouped by characteristics, and the groups are named accordingly. This type of data is called categorical data. An example of this is categorizing patients into "high or low BP" groups. Sometimes the data is not categorized and is expressed numerically, like SBP readings of "120, 121, 122, etc." This is called qualitative data.

If this researcher were to study the effect of antibiotics in terms of the growth of bacteria in culture, such as the number of colony-forming units grown with each antibiotic, the study would have quantitative/ numerical variables. Then other tests like t-test or ANOVA would be used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with a mass at the anus associated with painless bleeding. Examination revealed the following findings. Identify the correct pair of involved veins and their tributaries in this condition.

choices.text: Inferior rectal vein→ Inferior mesenteric vein
Superior rectal vein→ Inferior mesenteric vein
Middle rectal vein→ Inferior mesenteric vein

questions.solution:
The given scenario and image are suggestive of internal haemorrhoids. The correctly involved veins and tributaries are superior rectal veins draining into the inferior mesenteric vein. In the image, the mass is appearing to arise above the level of the dentate line, and prominent enlargement can be found at the 3 o’clock, 11 o’clock, and 7 o’clock positions.

Internal haemorrhoids arise from the hemorrhoidal plexus consisting of 3 soft engorgements, referred to as anal cushions or haemorrhoids. Upright posture, the absence of valves in the portal venous system, and raised abdominal pressure contribute to venous plexus engorgement and the development of varicosities. 

Patients will present with painless bleeding per rectum and mass near the anal orifice.

The venous plexus and its drainage are as follows:

The upper part of the anal canal, including the internal hemorrhoidal plexus:

  • The superior rectal vein draining into the inferior mesenteric vein- Portal vein tributaries
  • The middle rectal vein draining into the internal iliac vein- Systemic veins

The lower part of the anal canal, including the external haemorrhoidal venous plexus:

  • The inferior rectal veins into the internal pudendal veins (later into the internal iliac vein)- Systemic veins

The rectal venous plexus is, therefore, a site of communication between the portal and systemic venous systems. Hence, patients with portal hypertension develop rectal varices that should not be confused with haemorrhoids.

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

Internal hemorrhoids External hemorrhoids
Located proximal to the dentate line

Located distal to the dentate line
Covered by transitional and columnar epithelium Covered by richly innervated squamous epithelium
Caused by pressure on superior rectal veins Caused by pressure on inferior rectal veins
Painless, can be ligated Painful, not ligated
Banding is preferred Excision is done

questions.text: Which of the following ECG findings are seen in a patient with hypokalemia?

choices.text: Prolonged PR interval with ST elevation
Decreased PR interval with ST depression
Decreased QT interval with tall T waves
Prolonged QT interval with flat T waves

questions.solution:
Prolonged QT interval with flat T waves is seen in hypokalemia.

Hypokalemia prolongs ventricular repolarization. The ECG changes seen are as follows:

  • Flattening of T wave
  • ST-segment depression
  • Prolongation of QT interval
  • The appearance of U wave

questions.text: A patient recovered from hepatitis B infection. Which of the following curve represents antibodies seen 4 weeks post-recovery?
questions.solution:
The serological marker marked in the image is anti-HBs antibody. In typical cases of resolving hepatitis B, HBsAg becomes undetectable 1-2 months after the appearance of clinical features. After this, anti-HBs becomes detectable in the serum.

After a person is infected with the hepatitis B virus (HBV), the first serologic marker to increase in level is HBsAg. It becomes detectable in the serum between 1-12 weeks. It becomes undetectable 1–2 months after the onset of jaundice and rarely persists beyond 6 months. Once the HBsAg becomes undetectable, anti-HBs antibody starts rising in serum and remains detectable indefinitely thereafter. The gap between the disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBs antibodies is called the window period. 

HBcAg is located inside the cells and is usually enclosed within an HBsAg coat when present in the serum. As a result, HBcAg is not commonly detectable in the serum of patients with HBV infection since naked core particles are not found in the bloodstream. Conversely, anti-HBc can be detected in the serum shortly after the emergence of HBsAg, usually within 1-2 weeks. Anti-HBc may be the only serologic marker useful for the identification of HBV infection during the window period. 

HBeAg appears shortly after the appearance of HBsAg. Its appearance correlates with high levels of virus replication. Anti-HBe correlates with a period of lower infectivity.

questions.text: The life cycle of a parasite is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this parasitic infection?

choices.text: The parasite belongs to the phylum Nematoda
Feces examination is not commonly used in diagnosis
The alimentary canal of the parasite is incomplete, without an anus
The eggs of the parasite are  colorless and non-bile stained

questions.solution:
The given life cycle is indicative of Enterobius vermicularis, and the incorrect statement is its alimentary canal is incomplete, without an anus.

The nematode Enterobius vermicularis has an alimentary canal that is complete till the anus. It causes perianal pruritis. Eggs are present in the feces only in a small proportion of patients, so feces examination is not useful in diagnosis. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens. This involves pressing an adhesive cellophane tape against the perianal region early in the morning and transferring it to a glass slide under the microscope to demonstrate eggs.

Pinworm eggs are planoconvex with a double-layered eggshell that is relatively thick and transparent. The are colorless, non-bile stained. They float in the saturated salt solution. Treatment includes albendazole.

The life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis is given below.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes for a routine examination. He is on ramipril for hypertension and metformin for diabetes. On evaluation, he is found to have hyperkalemia and acidemia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

RTA- Renal tubular acidosis
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is RTA type IV.

The above clinical features of diabetes, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ramipril), hyperkalemia, and acidemia are suggestive of type IV renal tubular acidosis. 

Type IV renal tubular acidosis (hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism) occurs in type 1 or 2 diabetes mellitus. It is more commonly seen in diabetic nephropathy-induced destruction of juxtaglomerular apparatus, drugs like ACEI/ARBs, potassium-sparing diuretics, calcineurin inhibitors, NSAIDs, and heparin.

The clinical features seen in Type IV RTA are as follows:

  • Hyperkalemia: Hypoaldosteronism results in an increase in potassium concentration. 
  • Metabolic acidosis: The important buffers in urine are ammonia and phosphate. Hyperkalemia impairs ammonia production in the proximal tubule, which reduces the buffering of hydrogen ions. This results in decreased hydrogen ion excretion. 
  • Urinary pH<5.5: Due to the decreased production of ammonia in the proximal tubule, excess protons are excreted in the renal tubules, thus decreasing the urinary pH.

Other options:

Option A- RTA type I (distal RTA) is seen in autoimmune diseases like Sjogren's syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, medullary sponge kidney disease, cirrhosis, drugs like amphotericin B, lithium, etc. The patients develop hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis with alkaline urine (urinary pH >5.5). 

Option B- RTA type II (proximal RTA) is seen in Fanconi syndrome, Wilson's disease, heavy metals ingestion, etc., The patients develop hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis with acidic urine (urinary pH <5.5). There is also the excretion of glucose, urate, and amino acids.

Option C- RTA type III (mixed RTA) is seen in inherited mutations of carbonic anhydrase II. A combined pathology of type I and type II RTA is seen in this type. It results in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following are not sporicidal agents?
  1. Isopropyl alcohol
  2. Formaldehyde
  3. Chlorhexidine
  4. Silver sulfadiazine
  5. Ionizing radiations
questions.solution:
The compounds isopropyl alcohol, chlorhexidine, and silver sulfadiazine are not sporicidal (option A- 1, 3, 4).

Non-sporicidal chemical biocides include

  • Alcohols 
  • Phenols
  • Chlorhexidine
  • Silver sulfadiazine 

Isopropyl alcohol and other alcohols have antimicrobial activity against vegetative bacteria, viruses, and fungi. These are bactericidal but are not sporicidal.

Formaldehyde or glutaraldehyde is used for the sterilization of various surgical instruments and endoscopes. They have both bactericidal and sporicidal activity. Sporicidal activity is seen when these compounds are used as a 2% solution. 

Chlorhexidine is a disinfectant and preservative, commonly used in products for hand and oral hygiene. It is bactericidal but not sporicidal.

Silver sulfadiazine is a combination of silver and sulfadiazine, two antibacterial agents. It is not sporicidal.

Ionizing radiations (gamma or x-ray) leads to the formation of free radicals that damages biological molecules like proteins, DNA, etc. These radiations have both bactericidal and sporicidal activity.

Phenols are used for their antiseptic and disinfectant properties. These are not sporicidal.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old multipara presents with a blood picture showing hypersegmented neutrophils and typical pencil cells. MCV is normal. This condition is managed by supplementing:

1- Folic acid
2- Iron
3- Vitamin B12
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation most likely indicates a case of dimorphic anemia, and such cases are managed by supplementation with iron, folic acid, and vitamin B12. 

From the given description of the histopathological picture:

  • Pencil cells indicate iron-deficiency anemia
  • Hyper-segmented neutrophils indicate folic acid/vitamin B12–deficiency anemia.

MCV is generally low in iron-deficiency anemia, while it is high in cases of megaloblastic anemia secondary to folate and cyanocobalamine deficiency. Thus, a normal MCV excludes both these conditions individually and is more likely to favor a combination of both. This patient most likely has dimorphic anemia due to coexisting iron and folic acid deficiency. 

Nutritional anemia, which is an important cause of dimorphic anemia, is a significant problem worldwide.

Blood pictures in dimorphic anemia will have features of both iron-deficiency anemia and folic acid–deficiency anemia.

Blood picture in iron-deficiency anemia:

  • Microcytic hypochromic RBCs
  • Presence of poikilocytosis in the form of characteristic pencil cells

Blood picture in folic acid/Vit B12–deficiency anemia:

  • Hypersegmented neutrophils
  • Macrocytic RBCs

questions.text: Laryngeal spasm is the primary cause of death in which of the following types of drowning?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal spasm is the primary cause of death in cases of dry drowning. 

Dry drowning occurs when an inrush of water into the nasopharynx/larynx in a submersion victim leads to an immediate sustained laryngeal spasm, resulting in death. In this type of drowning, water does not enter the lungs. Thick mucus may form a plug.

This type of drowning is usually seen in children and adults under the influence of alcohol/sedative-hypnotics and constitutes <20% of cases of immersion. 

Wet drowning occurs when water enters the lungs of a submersion victim. The person experiences severe chest pain and death occurs within minutes.

Hydrocution occurs when cold water stimulates the nerve endings on the body, eardrum, pharynx, etc in a person who falls/dives into water.

Secondary drowning is seen in resuscitated submersion victims who survive for 24 hours. Death may occur hours after resuscitation.

The table below summarizes the cause of death in different types of drowning:

Type of drowning  Cause of death

Wet drowning/
Primary drowning

Cardiac arrest/ ventricular fibrillation

Dry drowning

 Immediate laryngeal spasm/vagal inhibition

Hydrocution/
Immersion syndrome/ Submersion inhibition

Cardiac arrest due to vagal inhibition
Secondary drowning/
Post-immersion syndrome /
Near drowning

Hypoxemia leading to electrolyte imbalance, cerebral edema, pulmonary edema, sepsis, metabolic acidosis, etc.

 

Related Pearl: Difference between freshwater and seawater drowning.

  Freshwater drowning Seawater drowning
Mechanism of death Disruption of surfactant - causes surfactant denaturation Disruption of surfactant - causes dilution of surfactant

Hyponatremia

Hyperkalemia

questions.text: While performing two-point discrimination test in a patient, the normal stimulus is primarily sensed by:
questions.solution:
While performing a two-point discrimination test in a patient, the normal stimulus is primarily sensed by Meissner’s corpuscles.

Two-point discrimination tests the integrity of the dorsal column (medial lemniscus) system, the central pathway for touch and proprioception. Meissner's corpuscles are encapsulated mechanoreceptors present mainly in the dermis of non-hairy skin, particularly in the fingertips and lips. They have small receptive fields and are rapidly adapting which helps in two­ point discrimination. 

Other mechanoreceptors:

Pacinian corpuscles (Option A) are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors present in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They are composed of nerve endings encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue, giving them an onion-like appearance. These receptors respond to fast vibration and deep pressure and adapt very rapidly.

 

Merkel discs (Option C) are seen in the epidermis of glabrous skin. They are slowly adapting receptors and have very small receptive fields. These receptors detect vertical indentations of the skin. They are expanded dendritic endings.

 

Ruffini corpuscles (Option D) are capsulated, enlarged, dendritic endings. They are located in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin, and in joint capsules. They are slowly adapting receptors. They detect stretch and joint rotation.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: A patient with a known history of peptic ulcers comes with hematemesis. The urea breath test is positive. The patient's gastric biopsy is taken, and the slide is shown below. The patient is at the highest risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and gastric biopsy showing curved bacteria filling the lumen of a gastric foveola is indicative of Helicobacter pylori infection. This patient is at the highest risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma.

H. pylori is a gram-negative bacillus that lives in gastric mucus and duodenum. It is acid-resistant and motile due to its spiral shape and flagella.

H. pylori is a known risk factor for peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, gastric adenocarcinoma, and gastric lymphoma. However, the risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma is much more than the risk of developing gastric lymphoma.

Many studies have shown H. pylori is protective against peptic esophageal diseases, including esophageal adenocarcinoma and GERD. It is due to H. pylori-induced hypochlorhydria. 

Diagnosis of H. pylori is by:

  • Tests based on endoscopic biopsy - biopsy urease test, histology, and culture of the biopsy specimen.
  • Non-invasive tests - 13C Urea breath test and stool antigen test is useful for follow-up after treatment. H. pylori contains an enzyme called urease. It splits urea into carbon dioxide and ammonium ions. In urea breath test, 13C is ingested by the patient. If H. pylori is present, the urease activity generates 13C-labeled CO2 that then can be detected in the patient’s exhaled breath.

The given image shows Helicobacter pylori on gastric mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain.

questions.text: Which of the following is true with regards to a greenstick fractures?
questions.solution:
In greenstick fractures, the inner cortex (concave) bends and the outer (convex) cortex breaks. 

A greenstick fracture is a partial thickness fracture where only cortex and periosteum are interrupted on one side of the bone, while they remain uninterrupted on the other side. 

In children, the bones are more resilient and hence, greenstick fractures are more common. It is commonly seen in the shaft of forearm bones.

The given X-ray shows a greenstick fracture.

Note: In a torus fracture, compression on one side causes the other side to be buckled. Distinct fracture lines are not seen and both cortices are intact as seen below.

questions.text: Which of the following patients is most likely to develop thyroid storm?

choices.text: A 45-year-old man with Graves' disease and pneumonia
A 32-year-old woman with toxic nodule and no complaints
A 27-year-old woman with long-standing Hashimoto's thyroiditis on treatment
A 56-year-old man with TSH-secreting adenoma and no complaints

questions.solution:
Thyroid storm occurs most commonly in patients with underlying Graves' disease, usually due to an acute elevation in catecholamine levels during infection, surgery, cessation of antithyroid medication, or any form of stress.

A thyroid storm refers to the abrupt onset of severe hyperthyroidism. It is characterized by fever, CNS agitation or depression, GI disturbances, and cardiovascular dysfunction.

The condition may be triggered by the abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications, infection, thyroid or non-thyroid surgery, and trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of the room spinning when his head is in one particular position. His diagnosis was confirmed by performing the Hallpike maneuver. The physician performs another maneuver to relieve the patient's symptoms. Arrange the following in the proper sequence of the therapeutic maneuver.
  1. Affected ear is facing up at 90° rotation
  2. Head turned 45° to the affected side and head in hanging position
  3. Head turned forward and chin brought down to 20°
  4. Whole body and head rotated to a lateral recumbent position
  5. Sitting position with head turned to unaffected side by 45°
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Epley's maneuver is performed, which follows the sequence b, a, d, e, c.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1 min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. 

A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. In this maneuver, the patient begins sitting up with their head turned 45 degrees toward the ear to be tested. Then the patient is made to lie down quickly with their head past the end of the bed. Then, the patient's neck is extended 20 degrees below the horizontal. The clinician then watches the patient's eyes for torsional and up-beating nystagmus, which should persist for no more than one minute. This would indicate a positive test.

The findings seen in the Dix-Hallpike maneuver are due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle.

Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the macula from the posterior semicircular canals. This is only a temporary cure, and there is a high rate of recurrence.

Epley's maneuver consists of five positions:

 Step Maneuver
Position 1 Head turned 45°

Patient is to lie down in a head-hanging position
Position 2

The head is turned so that the affected ear is facing up at 90° rotation
Position 3 Whole-body and head rotated away from the affected ear in a 90° rotation face-down position
Position 4 Head still turned to unaffected side by 45°

Patient is brought to the sitting position
Position 5 Head turned forward with chin brought down 20°

The illustration given below shows the different positions used in Epley's maneuver:

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of the clinical course of a patient admitted to the medicine ward with a fever. Which of the following would not be seen in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical course shown in the given image is suggestive of leptospirosis. Conjunctival suffusion is a feature of leptospirosis, not conjunctivitis. Conjunctival suffusion refers to the redness of eyes without inflammation, which would be seen in conjunctivitis.

The image shows leptospirosis, a zoonotic disease with two phases of illness after an incubation period of around 20 days. The organism can be present in the blood, CSF, or urine, depending on the phase of the illness. Leptospirosis is caused by contact with the urine or blood of an infected organism. It is a zoonosis and can affect all mammalian species; rats are well-known reservoirs. 

Illness is classically biphasic after an incubation period of up to 1 month. Clinical distinction between the 2 phases may not be seen, as shown by the overlap of phases in the graph.

  • Acute leptospiremic phase - the organism can be cultured from blood, as seen in the graph.
  • Resolving immune phase - the organism can be cultured from urine. Antibodies can be detected using a microscopic agglutination test. 

Fever, conjunctival suffusion (red-eye), jaundice, relative bradycardia (Faget sign), and meningeal signs (neck rigidity and Kernig's sign positive) are features of leptospirosis.

Most cases are asymptomatic. However, a few may present with severe manifestations called Weil's disease, which is a triad of bleeding, jaundice, and acute kidney injury.

Diagnosis:

  • Microscopy -
    • Examination of blood - Leptospires may be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence. The organism disappears from the blood after 1 week.
    • Examination of urine: Leptospires appear in the urine in the second week of the disease. Centrifuged deposits of the urine may be examined under dark ground illumination.
  • Culture - With semisynthetic media like Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris (EMJH) medium or Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media.
  • Serotype-specific tests: 
    • Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)
    • Macroscopic agglutination test  
    • A rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospira-specific IgM antibody in human sera.

The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone. Doxycycline 200 mg orally, given once a week, is effective in prophylaxis.

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: The researchers conducted an ecological study, which showed that communities with large numbers of fast food outlets have higher rates of diabetes. The researchers assign the results of this study to individuals in the community. What is the type of bias seen in this situation?
questions.solution:
In the above question, the study may show that communities with large numbers of fast food outlets have higher rates of diabetes, but it cannot be concluded that an individual’s food choices relate to his or her risk of diabetes. Thus, in this study, the characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals. This type of bias is called an ecological fallacy. 

An ecological study is any kind of study in which data is collected about a population and is analyzed at that level. Unlike the case with cohort studies, in these studies, no data is available or analyzed about individuals.

Examples would include

  • Study of the diabetic rates in countries with different levels of automobile ownership
  • Study of lung cancer rates in places with different taxes on tobacco

Ecological fallacy occurs when the study was done in a whole population (a large group or community), and the characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals. 

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a progressive blurring of vision in his left eye. He said that a branch of a plant injured his eye 1 week ago while working in his field. On examination, an ulcer is seen in his cornea with feathery margins. Microscopy of the ulcer scraping showed branched septate hyphae. He was started on natamycin 5% eye drops. Which adjuvant drug can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer. The adjuvant drug that can be given to this patient is atropine sulfate eye drops.

Fungal corneal ulcers are usually caused due to injury to the eye with vegetable matter. The signs are more pronounced but the symptoms are mild. 

Examination findings include:

  • Dry-looking ulcer with feathery margins
  • Sterile circular corneal infiltrates - Wessely's immune ring due to the deposition of immune complexes
  • Satellite lesions
  • Thick, non-sterile hypopyon

Specific treatment of fungal corneal ulcer:

  • Topical drugs: Natamycin, voriconazole, or amphotericin B drops against Aspergillus and Fusarium and nystatin against Candida.
  • Systemic drugs: Oral ketoconazole or voriconazole for ulcers that are severe with hypopyon, perforated, or with suspicion of endophthalmitis.

Non-specific supportive treatment:

  • Atropine (1%) drops or ointment should be instilled in the affected eye two or three times a day to prevent complications like ciliary spasm posterior synechiae formation.
  • Local heat

Steroids are contraindicated in the treatment of fungal corneal ulcers because fungi, which are usually symbiotic saprophytes under normal conditions, become facultative pathogens in the presence of steroids and can cause perforation.

Image showing a fungal corneal ulcer with feathery margins and a non-sterile hypopyon:

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text:
Identify the correct sequence of steps in HIV replication.
  1. Integration of viral DNA
  2. Translation
  3. Cleavage of polyproteins
  4. Reverse transcription
  5. Transcription
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of steps in HIV replication is 4→1→5→2→3.

  • Reverse transcription
  • Integration of viral DNA
  • Transcription
  • Translation
  • Cleavage of polyproteins

The human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) virus is a spherical, enveloped RNA virus. The nucleocapsid has an icosahedral shell and a cone-shaped core, enclosing the ribonucleoproteins. The genome comprises two identical single-stranded, RNA copies, with the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is a characteristic feature of retroviruses.

The image below shows the structure of HIV:

 

Replication process: The viral reverse transcriptase (RNA-directed DNA polymerase) enzyme uses the viral RNA genome to synthesize viral DNA. This DNA (provirus) is integrated into the host cell chromosome by integrase. Transcription occurs to create new viral RNA. RNA undergoes translation to make viral proteins. The viral protease cleaves new polyproteins to create a mature infectious virus.

The image below shows the life cycle of HIV:

questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker presented with miosis, ptosis of the right eye, and anhidrosis of the right side of the face. He also has occasional chest pain along with fever and weight loss for the past month. A pancoast tumour is suspected. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of a Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor) and the investigation of choice is MRI.

Investigations in Pancoast tumor:

  • MRI (MRI > CT) is the investigation of choice for superior sulcus tumor/ Pancoast tumor as the associated soft tissue infiltration, the extent of which can be best visualized using an MRI.
  • FDG-PET scan shows high uptake by the tumor cells. FDG is taken up by all metabolizing cells but more avidly by cancer cells.
  • Bronchoscopy can be done in endobronchial tumors to obtain a tissue diagnosis.

Pancoast syndrome/ superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots, stellate ganglion, and the chest wall.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs.

Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread can cause

  • Tracheal obstruction
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis)

The below images show chest x-ray, FDG-PET images, and management of the Pancoast tumor.

 

Related Pearl: Investigation of Choice in Respiratory Diseases

Disease Investigation of choice
Interstitial lung disease HRCT
Bronchiectasis HRCT
Pulmonary embolism CT Pulmonary Angiography > Ventilation-Perfusion Scan
Calcification CT
Solitary pulmonary nodule CT > PET
Lung Malignancy CT scan
Superior sulcus tumor MRI scan > CT scan

questions.text: A post-COVID patient, who is a known diabetic, develops unilateral facial pain and loosening of teeth. He also has black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. What is the treatment of choice?

choices.text: Intravenous antifungal and hyperbaric oxygen therapy

questions.solution:
The given scenario of a post-COVID diabetic patient with facial pain and loosening of teeth is suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. Management comprises amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues. 

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus. The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. It can later spread to the brain's frontal lobe and cavernous sinus. 

A definitive diagnosis is done with a biopsy and histopathologic examination. It is the most sensitive and specific method. It reveals aseptate fungi with thick-walled, ribbon-like, hyphae branching at right angles.

Among the imaging techniques used for diagnosis, MRI is more sensitive to detecting orbital and nervous involvement than CT. Contrast-enhanced MRI is the imaging technique of choice. 1,3 beta D-glucan assay, which is helpful for the identification of most fungi, cannot be used for the diagnosis of mucormycosis.

Management: The underlying cause and risk factors should be addressed.

  • Aggressive surgical debridement of involved tissues should be considered as soon as the diagnosis of any form of mucormycosis is suspected. 
  • Initial therapy with amphotericin B as the drug of choice.
  • Posaconazole and isavuconazole are broad-spectrum azoles that can be used as step-down therapy after response to amphotericin B.

The benefit of hyperbaric oxygen has not been proven yet and is not considered a standard treatment.

questions.text: Identify the abdominal incision labeled X.
questions.solution:
The incision marked X is the Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision made for appendicitis. The incision is made 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. 

Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results, with reduced scarring.

The major anterior abdominal incisions have been illustrated below:

  • 1 is Kocher incision - a subcostal incision used to gain access for gallbladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - the most common incision for laparotomy; a vertical incision that follows the linea alba and is particularly favored in diagnostic laparotomy, as it allows wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney incision (also called gridiron incision) - an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point; it is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is battle incision - a lower right paramedian incision, but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision; it is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 6 is a paramedian incision - this incision runs 2-5 cm away from the midline used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure to the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morison incision - an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to the sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients, when the midline is scarred due to previous surgery; it is useful if the appendix is fixed paracecal or retrocecal in location.
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - an infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding varenicline?

choices.text: It is an antagonist at α4β2 receptor
It interacts with nicotinic ACh receptors
Its use is associated with mood and behavioral changes
It is useful in decreasing craving

questions.solution:
Varenicline is a partial agonist at the α4β2 receptor, not an antagonist.

Nicotine is the principal constituent of tobacco responsible for its addictive behavior. One of the newest agents introduced to aid in smoking cessation is varenicline.

Varenicline works by blocking the effects of nicotine on the brain. It blocks α-4, β-2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor subtypes.

It inhibits dopaminergic activation produced by smoking through its partial agonism and decreases the craving and withdrawal syndrome that occurs with cessation attempts. It prevents nicotine stimulation of the mesolimbic dopamine system associated with nicotine addiction, thus helping to occlude the "rewarding" effect of smoking.

Varenicline is prescribed only to patients 18 years or older. Varenicline is taken orally at a starting dose of 0.5 mg once daily on days 1 to 3, which is increased to 0.5 mg twice daily on days 4 through 7, followed by 1 mg twice daily after day 8 for 11 weeks. Therapy should start one week before the target quit date. It can be continued for another 12 weeks (1 mg BD) to maintain abstinence.

The adverse effects include nausea, which can be mitigated by starting at lower doses and gradually increasing the dose. Other symptoms include disturbed sleep, sleepwalking, agitation, drowsiness, and constipation; it may also increase the risk of pancreatitis. Varenicline has also been implicated in specific skin syndromes such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome, erythema multiforme, and photosensitivity. Varenicline can cause renal failure and kidney stones, and therefore, renal function must be monitored.

The FDA has issued a warning about mood and behavioral changes associated with its use, and there is some evidence of increased cardiovascular risk.

questions.text: All the following drugs act via G-protein-coupled receptors, except _______.
questions.solution:
All the following drugs act via G-protein-coupled receptors, except nicotine. Nicotine acts via ion-channel-coupled receptors.

Ion-channel-coupled receptors are activated by a change in voltage, ligand binding, or membrane stretching. Activation of an ion channel receptor changes the flux of ions through it. This causes depolarization or hyperpolarization of the cell and brings about downstream effects via secondary messengers. A variety of physiological ligands and drugs act through this type of receptor. 

They are also classified as voltage-activated, ligand-activated, store-activated, stretch-activated, and temperature-activated channels.

The ligand-gated nicotinic acetylcholine receptor is an example of an ion channel coupled receptor. It is pentameric and consists of 4 different subunits (α, β, γ, and δ). The structure of nicotinic ACh is different in autonomic ganglia and neuromuscular junction. This difference is essential because rocuronium, an antagonist of this channel binds specifically to the neuromuscular junction receptor, causing only muscle relaxation without any autonomic side effects.

The table shows examples of different drugs and physiological ligands binding to different receptors.

receptors		 Ligand-gated Ach (M2)

Drugs in other options act via G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). They are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times, hence called seven helix or serpentine receptors. G proteins have 3 subunits (α, β, and ɣ). In its resting state, the α subunit is bound to GDP. Upon ligand binding to GPCR, it undergoes a conformational change that activates the G protein within the cell. The α subunit dissociates and in turn alters the activity of second messengers such as cAMP, cGMP, or Ca2+.

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: An autopsy is being performed on a victim who sustained a gunshot injury from a revolver.  The image of the wound is given below.  What is the likely distance between the gun and the victim?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a circular wound with no evidence of muzzle end imprint, burning, blackening, or tattooing appearance of the entry wound of a revolver. Therefore, it was most likely a distant shot and the likely distance between the revolver and the victim is > 60 cm.

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for primary postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Polyhydramnios is a risk factor for primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as a loss of more than 500 mL of blood after the completion of the third stage of labor in vaginal delivery and more than 1000 mL in cesarean delivery.

Postpartum hemorrhage can be subdivided into primary PPH and secondary PPH. Primary PPH is bleeding that occurs within 24 hours of the delivery of the baby. Secondary PPH is bleeding that occurs beyond 24 hours of delivery and during puerperium. It is also known as delayed or puerperal hemorrhage.

Causes of primary PPH are atony, trauma, coagulopathy, and retained tissues. The atonic uterus can be caused by numerous factors that interfere with the contraction and retraction of the uterus.

The contributing risk factors for atonic hemorrhage are grand multipara, overdistension of the uterus due to multiple pregnancies or polyhydramnios or a big baby, anemia, antepartum hemorrhage due to placenta previa and abruption, prolonged labor, uterine fibroid, and placental implantation on the uterine septum of a septate uterus.

The causes of secondary PPH include retained membranes or placental cotyledons, infections like endometritis, and subinvolution of the placental site. Rare causes of secondary PPH are carcinoma cervix, chorioepithelioma, placental polyp, uterine arteriovenous fistula, and puerperal inversion of the uterus.

During labor, active management of 3rd stage of labor is known to decrease the risk of PPH by 60%. Carbetocin 100 micrograms IV can be used to prevent PPH.

Complications of PPH include shock, puerperal sepsis, pulmonary embolism, thrombosis, thrombophlebitis, Sheehan’s syndrome, and diabetes insipidus rarely.

questions.text: In the following left ventricle (LV) pressure-volume loop diagram, the aortic valve will open at point ________.
questions.solution:
The aortic valve will open at point 3.

  • 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • 4 - Aortic valve closes

Pressure-volume diagram during the cardiac cycle:

The pressure-volume diagram plots the changes in the pressure and volume in the left ventricle that occur during the cardiac cycle. The X-axis shows the changes in ventricular volume, while the Y-axis shows the changes in ventricular pressure.

 

It has the following phases.

Phase I- This phase is called the period of filling and extends between points A and B. Point A is at the end of systole when the ventricular volume is about 50 mL. This volume is called end-systolic volume. The pressure at this point is about 2 to 3 mmHg. The volume and pressure go on increasing as the blood from the atrium flows to the ventricle during diastole. At the end of diastole, marked by point B, the ventricle will have a volume of around 120 mL. This volume is called end-diastolic volume. The pressure is slightly raised to 5-7 mmHg. 

Phase II- It is the phase of isovolumetric contraction, and extends between points B and C. At the end of diastole (point B), a slight increase in the ventricular pressure closes the mitral valve, and contraction starts. The ventricle contracts while both mitral and aortic valves are closed. Therefore, the pressure within the ventricle slowly rises without any changes in the volume. 

Phase III- It is the phase of ejection and extends between point C and point D. Point C is the place where the aortic valve opens. The pressure within the left ventricle rises slowly during isovolumetric contraction until it is sufficient to open the aortic valve. Once the aortic valve opens, blood within the left ventricle is ejected into the aorta. This decreases the volume of the left ventricle, while increasing the pressure within the ventricle.

Phase IV- It is the period of isovolumetric relaxation. It extends between points D and A. At the end of the ejection (Point D), the aortic valve closes. However, the ventricular relaxation continues despite closed aortic and mitral valves. Therefore, the ventricular pressure continues to fall while the volume remains the same. The ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 mL of blood left in the ventricle and pressure of about 2 to 3 mmHg.

End-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR)

ESPVR is the maximum pressure that can be developed by the ventricle at the end-systolic volume. It is determined by the line intersecting the upper left corners of the loops. This line can be extended down to the x-axis. The slope of this line is called as ESPVR slope.

questions.text: The image shows the inferior surface of the liver. Which lobe of the liver marked below forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen?
questions.solution:
The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen. The lobe marked as '3' in the above image represents the caudate lobe.

The caudate lobe is visible as a prominence on the inferior and posterior surfaces of the liver. It lies posterior to the porta hepatis and to its right is the groove for the inferior vena cava.

The caudate lobe of the liver has a portal blood supply and hepatic vein drainage independent of the remainder of the liver.

 Other markings:

1- Quadrate lobe

2- Left Lobe 

4- Right lobe 

Shown below are 2 views of the visceral surface of the liver -

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac):

  • It forms the communication between the lesser sac and the greater sac.
  • The roof is formed by the caudate process of the liver
  • The floor is formed by the superior part of the duodenum
  • The posterior wall is the peritoneum covering the subhepatic part of the inferior vena cava
  • The anterior wall is a free edge of lesser omentum containing a bile duct, portal vein, and hepatic artery.
  • It serves as a site for an internal hernia.

Related Pearl: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Body of T12 vertebra

  • Caudate lobe of the liver

Inferior

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text:
A 14-week-old child is brought to your clinic for a routine checkup. Which of the following vaccines should be administered as per National Immunization Schedule?

OPV- Oral polio vaccine
PPV-Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine
fIPV- Fractional-dose inactivated polio vaccine
RVV- Rotavirus vaccine
questions.solution:
This child of 14 weeks should receive 2nd dose of fractional-dose inactivated polio vaccine (fIPV-2).

WHO recommends that all countries using only OPV should add at least one dose of IPV to the national schedule. In order to ensure that all eligible infants receive IPV, a dose-sparing strategy was used to match the supply and demand. This strategy used one-fifth of the IM dose given intradermally.

2 doses of fIPV given intradermally at the 6th and 14th weeks provide higher seroconversion rates than a single full dose of IPV given intramuscularly at 14 weeks.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a high fever and abdominal pain for the past 2 days. He has a history of inflammatory bowel disease. His abdominal radiograph is shown below. Identify the true statements regarding his condition.
  1. It is a common complication of Crohn's disease.
  2. It is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon, with a diameter of >6 cm.
  3. It can be triggered by electrolyte abnormalities and narcotics.
  4. Emergency colectomy is indicated in patients in cases of failed medical therapy.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the radiograph showing a dilation of the colon with loss of haustral folds is suggestive of a toxic megacolon. Statements 2, 3, and 4 correspond with the diagnosis of toxic megacolon.

Toxic megacolon is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon to a diameter of more than 6 cm. It is a rare complication and is associated with severe ulcerative colitis. It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics as they interfere with gut motility. 

It may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Bacterial infection with features of sepsis may also be seen. It can result in perforation. 

Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations.

It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, and bowel rest) and medical therapy, which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

The clinical features include abdominal pain, diarrhoea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and passage of mucus. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Investigations show it elevated C-reactive protein, platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, faecal calprotectin, and faecal lactoferrin. A colonoscopy reveals loss of typical vascular pattern, granularity, and ulceration in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns. Barium contrast enema shows a lead pipe appearance characterised by a smooth-walled colon with complete loss of haustrations.

Extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD:

  • Episcleritis, scleritis, and uveitis
  • Erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Arthropathies, sacroiliitis, ankylosing spondylitis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: A gardener presents with multiple vesicles on the hands and multiple eruptions along the lymphatic distribution. The lesions are limited to cutaneous tissues. On microscopy of tissue biopsy, flower-like clusters of conidia are seen. Which of the following statements is false about this disease?

choices.text: Medlar bodies are seen in this condition
It is caused by a dimorphic fungus
Itraconazole will be effective in this case
It is an example of subcutaneous mycoses

questions.solution:
The presence of multiple vesicles on the hands and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a gardener and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of sporotrichosis caused by Sporothrix schenckii.  In sporotrichosis, medlar bodies will not be seen. Medlar bodies or sclerotic bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection caused by many species. In tissue, the lesions appear as spherical brown cells termed muriform or sclerotic bodies that divide by transverse septation.

S. schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation such as grasses, trees, rose bushes, etc. It occurs in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. The septate hyphae appear very thin and carry flower-like clusters of small conidia borne on delicate sterigmata. Asteroid bodies seen in sporotrichosis consist of a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by radiating extensions of eosinophilic material.

Following traumatic inoculation into the skin as in thorn prick, S. schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous infection. The initial lesion appears following a trauma or thorn prick. The infection then spreads via the lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes. This results in secondary ulcers on the lymph nodes.

Treatment: 

  • Cutaneous form can be treated with oral or topical potassium iodide
  • Lymphocutaneous form – Itraconazole is effective in over 90% of patients with lymphocutaneous infection
  • For disseminated infection, amphotericin B is the drug of choice.

The image below shows the asteroid body seen in sporotrichosis:

Related Pearl: Common names of various fungal infections

Disease

Common name

Sporotrichosis

Rose-thorn or Rose gardener’s disease

Para-coccidioidomycosis

South American blastomycosis

Coccidioidomycosis

Valley fever or desert rheumatism

Blastomycosis

North American blastomycosis, Gilchrist's disease

questions.text:
Identify the correct sequence of the auditory pathway.
  1. Superior olivary nucleus
  2. Cochlear nucleus
  3. Inferior colliculi
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Medial geniculate ganglion
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is 2, 1, 4, 3, 5 (option B).

The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is as follows:

  1. Cochlear division of cranial nerve VIII
  2. Cochlear nucleus
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Medial geniculate body
  7. Auditory cortex

Related Pearl: Central Auditory Pathway

E.Coli - MA (mnemonic)

Eighth nerve 

Cochlear nuclei 

Olivary complex 

Lateral lemniscus 

Inferior colliculus 

Medial geniculate body 

Auditory cortex

Most of the primary auditory cortex is in the temporal lobe, but the association cortices extend over much of the insular lobe and even onto the lateral portion of the parietal lobe.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of Colles fracture 8 months ago comes to the orthopedics OPD. Her DEXA scan shows a T-score of -2.5. What does this score imply?

choices.text: Bone density is 2.5% lower than a person of the same age and gender
Bone density is 2.5 SD below mean than a young healthy female adult
Bone density is 2.5 SD below mean for a person of the same age and gender
Bone density is 2.5 SD above mean for a person of the same age and gender

questions.solution:
A T score of -2.5 implies bone density is 2.5 SD or more below the mean of a young healthy female adult.

The T-score is a comparison of the patient’s bone density with healthy, young individuals of the same sex.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score of -2.5 or lower, 

The Z-score is a comparison with the bone density of people of the same age and sex as the patient.

Osteoporosis is characterized by an abnormally low bone mass/density (vs. osteomalacia - defective mineralization of bone due to vitamin-D deficiency). DEXA scan is done in the following patients to look for bone mineral density and is reported in terms of T-score or Z-score.

  • Females >65 years of age
  • Post-menopausal females under the age of 65 years with risk factors
  • Fracture after the age of 50 years
  • Males >70 years of age

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient, who is on chronic antiarrhythmic drug therapy, presents with hypotension, photosensitivity, and cold intolerance. He also complains of difficulty in getting up from the squatting position. Pulmonary function tests revealed a restrictive pattern of lung disease.  What is the most likely drug implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug implicated in this scenario is amiodarone. Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug.

Amiodarone is used to convert atrial fibrillation and to slow ventricular rate in the treatment of tachyarrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardias, paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), and recurrent VF. It is also used in the treatment of cardiac arrest if epinephrine therapy is not effective.

The clinical spectrum of hypotension; photosensitivity; cold intolerance, which is indicative of hypothyroidism; difficulty in getting up from the squatting position indicative of proximal muscle weakness; and restrictive pattern on PFT, which is indicative of pulmonary fibrosis are all side effects of amiodarone.

The other significant side effects of amiodarone include the following:

  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Optic neuritis
  • Abnormal liver function tests
  • Peripheral neuropathy

The below image shows skin pigmentation in a patient due to prolonged amiodarone therapy.

Other options:

Option A - The side effects of adenosine are short-lived due to rapid transport into the cell and deamination. The side effects seen are transient asystole, transient dyspnea, and rarely transient atrial fibrillation.

Option B - The side effects of digoxin are common and include GI symptoms, visual and cognitive dysfunction, and arrhythmias, typically atrial tachycardia with AV block. Other arrhythmias that can occur are ventricular bigeminy, bidirectional ventricular tachycardia—a rare entity—and AV junctional tachycardias.

Option C - The side effects of quinidine are diarrhea, diarrhea-induced hypokalemia, marked QT prolongation, and a high risk of torsades de pointes at therapeutic or subtherapeutic concentrations. Cinchonism is a syndrome associated with quinidine intake, which includes symptoms of headache and tinnitus.

questions.text: A scientist is trying to develop a drug for a genetic condition. He seeks a drug that could cause epigenetic alteration in the DNA and could prevent the disease or seemingly improve the condition. All the following would include epigenetic modifications, except _______.

choices.text: Altering the gene sequence of DNA
DNA methylation at CpG islands in promoter regions

questions.solution:
Epigenetic changes are heritable chemical changes in gene expression that are not caused by the alteration in the gene sequence. They alter gene expression without mutation.

The term “epigenetics” means “above genetics.” It refers to the regulatory mechanisms that do not change the underlying regulated DNA sequence, but rather change the expression patterns, or function, of the DNA. Epigenetic mechanisms play key roles in the establishment, maintenance, and reversibility of transcriptional states. It can cause both gene activation and inactivation.

Epigenetic modifications include

  1. DNA methylation- It is the covalent addition and subtraction of a methyl group to DNA. Methylation is typically done in cytosine preceding a guanine (CpG) dinucleotides. CpG islands are mainly present in the promoter region.
  2. Histone modifications such as acetylation, deacetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, etc. Acetylation of histone activates transcription, while deacetylation represses transcription.
  3. miRNA- micro RNA or miRNA are approximately 22 nucleotides long. They do not code. They bind to mRNA and inhibit its translation.

Clinical significance of epigenetic mechanisms:

  • Epigenetic modifications, such as histone acetylation and DNA methylation, are reversible, which makes them amenable for application in therapeutic intervention.
  • Histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors and DNA methylation inhibitors are being tested in the treatment of cancer. These agents inhibit transcriptional silencing and thus reverse the chromatin condensation in cancer cells.
  • These modifications include heritable changes such as X-inactivation and genomic imprinting, but they can also result from dynamic post-translational protein modifications in response to environmental influences such as diet, age, and drugs.

Related Pearl: Role of Histones

Types

H3 histones

(H3–H4)2 tetramer has a central role in the formation

of the nucleosome
