questions.text: Which of the following post-mortem changes is a result of hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather?
questions.solution:
Hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather would result in adipocere formation, which is seen in image 4. 

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

  • Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):
    1. Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    2. Cessation of respiration
    3. Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death. It is seen in cellular death:
    1. Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    2. Eye changes
    3. Primary flaccidity of muscles
    4. Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling
    5. Postmortem lividity/Suggillation
    6. Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    1. Putrefaction
    2. Adipocere
    3. Mummification

Adipocere formation (Image 4) is a late sign of death. The transformation is brought about by the gradual hydrolysis and hydrogenation of pre-existing fats, including olein, into higher fatty acids. These higher fatty acids then join with calcium and ammonium ions to produce insoluble soaps, which since they are acidic, prevent putrefactive bacteria. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months. Still, in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 4 to 5 days after death. 

Image 1. Marbling: It is seen when blood in the vessels is hemolyzed to sulfate-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent  36–48 hours after death. It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Image 2. Cadaveric lividity: Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in most superficial layers of the dermis in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6 – 12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in.

Image 3. Mummification: It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air. It is a process of dehydration or drying and shriveling of the cadaver that occurs from the evaporation of water. The natural appearances of the body and general facial features are preserved.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching. Per speculum examination of the vagina is done as shown below. A wet smear with 10% KOH solution shows budding yeast cells. The clinician prescribes an oral medication. What is the likely mechanism of action of the given medication?

choices.text: Forms pores in the fungal cell wall

questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms of curdy white vaginal discharge and the KOH smear showing budding yeast cells are suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis. The oral medication given in this condition is fluconazole which acts by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

Azole group of antifungal are grouped into two types :

  • Imidazole- clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
  • Triazole- Itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole, and isavuconazole

The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impaired conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Therapeutic uses of fluconazole-

  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis can be treated with fluconazole by taking 100–200 mg a day for 7–14 days. Uncomplicated vaginal candidiasis can be effectively treated with a single 150 mg dose. Treatment of candidemia in nonimmunosuppressed patients involves a loading dosage of 800 mg, followed by 400 mg daily.
  • For the first eight weeks of the consolidation phase of the therapy of cryptococcal meningitis in individuals with AIDS, fluconazole is administered.
  • Due to its excellent CSF penetration and significantly lower morbidity than intrathecal amphotericin B, fluconazole is the medication of choice for treating coccidioidal meningitis. Fluconazole is similar to itraconazole in treating various types of coccidioidomycosis.

Other options

Option A- Amphotericin B acts by forming pores in the fungal cell membrane. It has also been found that it forms aggregates that sequester ergosterol from lipid bilayers, leading to fungal cell death. It is indicated in invasive mucormycosis, fungal endophthalmitis following pars plana vitrectomy, and induction therapy in cryptococcal meningitis. 

Option B- Griseofulvin acts by inhibiting microtubule assembly, disrupting the fungal cell division. It is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. It is also effective in treating ringworm of glabrous skin, tinea cruris, tinea corprosis, tinea pedis, and tinea of the hands and beard. 

Option C- Terbinafine acts by inhibiting epoxidation of fungal squalene that reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. It is helpful for treating nail onychomycosis in adults and tinea capitis.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic due to pneumonia. She has had repeated episodes of pneumonia due to Staphylococcus aureus in the past. She also has a history of easy bruising. On examination, she has light skin, silvery hair, and light blue eyes. Multiple bruises are seen on her legs and arms in different stages of healing. On peripheral blood film, the following image is seen. Which of the following defects is present in this patient?

choices.text: Loss of function of LYST gene

questions.solution:
The given clinical features of immunodeficiency fit the description of Chediak Higashi syndrome. A defect in the LYST gene is implicated in the development of Chediak Higashi syndrome.

Chediak Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to loss of function of the LYST gene (Lysosomal trafficking regulator gene)- a protein required for the normal packaging and distribution of granules. This defect results in defective chemotaxis, phagolysosome fusion, degranulation of T-cells and NK cells, and ADP granule function in platelets. Due to the defective fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes, giant granules in the neutrophils are seen. Other features include albinism (due to abnormalities of melanocytes), nerve defects (nerve cell dysfunction), and bleeding (due to platelet dysfunction).

Other Options:

Option A: Defective CD40 ligand is seen in hyper IgM syndrome. In this, there are low levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE. Clinically, patients present with recurrent pyogenic infections, because the level of opsonizing IgG antibodies is low. No giant granules are seen on peripheral blood film along with no signs of albinism. 

Option B: WAS gene mutation is seen in Wiscott-Aldrich syndrome, an X-linked disease characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection. This patient has no history of eczema.

Option D: Defective NADPH oxidase is seen in Chronic granulomatous disease, which is characterized by defects in bacterial killing and renders patients susceptible to recurrent bacterial infection especially by catalase-positive organisms. It is not associated with albinism and platelet dysfunction.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: What is the duration of validity of 17D vaccination?
questions.solution:
17D vaccine (yellow fever vaccine) is valid for a lifetime, beginning 10 days after vaccination. According to the amendment in 2016 to International Health Regulations 2005, the validity of the related international certificate of vaccination against yellow fever has been changed from ten (10) years to the lifespan of the person (traveler) vaccinated.

It is a live-attenuated vaccine derived from the 'Asibi strain', administered subcutaneously. Immunity after a single dose is long-lasting and provides lifetime protection. It is thermolabile. Antibodies and memory T cells have been detected up to 60 years after vaccination, which is why it is considered to offer lifelong immunity. 

Vaccination is compulsory for travel to and from endemic areas.In India, 17D is manufactured at the Central Research Institute, Kasauli.

questions.text: A young woman was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. She opens her eyes to painful stimuli, but her speech is confused. She can localize pain on the right side, but withdraws from pain on the left side. What is her Glasgow Coma Scale score?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of the patient is 11 and her component score is E2V4M5.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury. It has three components: eye-opening, verbal, and motor abilities. Each component is assigned a score, and the total score is presented as a sum of three.

  • Eye-opening: To painful stimulus = 2 
  • Verbal response: Confused = 4
  • Motor response: Localize the pain on the right side = 5

In GCS, the best motor response elicited is considered for scoring. As seen in this patient, if she can localize the pain on the right side but withdraws from pain on the left side, then the motor component of the right side would be considered, and the score would be 5. Therefore, her component score would be E2V4M5 and adding 2+4+5 gives a score of 11.

A GCS score of <8 denotes severe brain injury.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with an ulcer of dimensions 3 x 2 x 0.5 cm near the inner canthus of the right eye. The ulcer has a central scab surrounded by rolled-out edges. Histopathologic examination of the lesion shows peripheral palisading tumor cells. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: UV radiation exposure is a strong predisposing factor
Malignant tumor affecting basal epidermis and pilo-sebaceous skin

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). BCC is a slow-growing, locally invasive, malignant tumor of epithelial cells arising from the basal epidermis and hair follicles. Despite its high prevalence, there is an extremely rare occurrence of metastases.

Mesodermal factors acting as intrinsic promoters are involved in the pathogenesis of BCC.

Risk factors of BCC:

  • The strongest predisposing factor to BCC is UV radiation exposure.
  • Exposure to arsenic compounds, aromatic hydrocarbons, ionizing radiation, and genetic skin cancer syndromes
  • White-skinned people
  • Men are at higher risk than women

Nodular and nodulocystic variants comprise the major types of BCC.

In most cases, BCC occurs on the face. It is only locally malignant. It erodes deeply into local tissues, including cartilage and bones, causing extensive local destruction, hence the name rodent ulcer. It does not spread through blood or lymphatics.

Below images show the gross and microscopic appearance of basal cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

Immunobullous Disorders 
Pemphigus Vulgaris Multiple acantholytic cells (Tzanck cells)
Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with very few inflammatory cells
Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis(TEN) Necrotizing or degenerating basal cells with scattered inflammatory cells and fibroblasts 
Bullous pemphigoid (BP), Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and erosive lichen planus No acantholytic cells ; Many leucocytes
Cutaneous Infections 
Herpes simplex, varicella, herpes zoster Ballooning degeneration and multinucleated giant cells are seen
Molluscum contagiosum Diagnostic intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30-35 microns)
Vaccinia, orf, milker's nodules and variola Acantholytic squamous keratinocytes , eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion called a "Guarnieri body"
 Leishmaniasis Leishman-Donovan (LD) bodiesgrouped together in a typical "swarm of bees" fashion, within large macrophages (Wright's cells)
Bullous Impetigo Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with abundant neutrophils and clusters of coccoid bacteria
Genodermatoses

Basal Cell Carcinoma Clusters of Basaloid cells

 

Image : Tzanck smear , showing three multinucleated giant cells in center.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text: A primigravida, a known case of pre-eclampsia, develops seizures when she was admitted to the labor room at 36 weeks of gestation. What is the loading dose of MgSO4 that should be started in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical picture is suggestive of eclampsia. A loading dose of 4 g IV MgSO4 is administered to control seizures.

The management of eclampsia is guided by the MAGPIE trial-2002 which indicated that MgSO4 halves the relative risk of eclampsia. MgSO4 acts as a neuronal membrane stabilizer and neuroprotector and also blocks calcium influx into the neurons. The MgSO4 regimens for the management of eclampsia and severe pre-eclampsia are as follows:

Regimen

Loading
dose

Maintenance dose

Intra-muscular

(Pritchard)

4 g IV over
3–5 min,

followed by
10 g, deep IM
(5 g in each buttock)

5 g IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock

Intra-venous

(Zuspan/ Sibai)

4-6 g slow IV over 15–20 minutes

1–2 g per hour IV infusion

Magnesium sulfate is continued for 24 hours after the seizure or delivery, whichever is later.

MgSO4 toxicity manifests as loss of deep tendon reflexes, decreased urine output, heart block, pulmonary edema, decreased respiratory rate (<16/minute), oxygen saturation of <95%, and chest pain. Hence, the patient should be continuously monitored for toxicity. The toxicity should be treated by stopping the therapy, monitoring serum urea and creatinine, and 10 mL slow IV calcium gluconate injection.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: A child is being evaluated for respiratory distress. The chest radiograph of the baby is shown below. All the following are true about the condition except:

choices.text: The hernia is anterolateral in location
Scaphoid abdomen is a clinical feature
The hernia is posterolateral in location

questions.solution:
The given chest radiograph depicts Bochdalek hernia, so Option B is the correct answer here. The hernia is posterolateral in location, and not anterolateral.

Bochdalek hernia is the most common variant of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. It occurs due to defective development of the septum transversum. The defect allows the abdominal organs to enter the thoracic cavity. It is more common on the left side. The hernia is posterolateral in location. The child presents with the following clinical features:

  • Respiratory distress
  • Scaphoid abdomen
  • Bowel sounds in the chest
  • Mediastinal shift- Dextroposition of heart 
  • Bilateral lung hypoplasia

Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated. Bag and mask ventilation causes distension of the stomach and limits the expansion of the hypoplastic lungs leading to further respiratory distress.

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)
 

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with a history of chronic cough and wheezing. History taking reveals that he had a lower respiratory tract infection 15 months ago. After ruling out other causes, the pediatrician diagnoses this case as Swyer-James syndrome. This could be most likely due to the late sequelae of which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Swyer–James syndrome is most likely due to late sequelae of adenovirus infection. This condition can also be due to respiratory syncytial virus, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, influenza A, or measles infections.

This condition is also called MacLeod syndrome. The infection can produce pulmonary vascular hypoplasia with subsequent hypoperfusion leading to unilateral hyperlucent lung (refers to underdevelopment of the affected lung). Clinically, children with this syndrome frequently exhibit hemoptysis, wheezing, a chronic cough, and recurrent pneumonia. During exhalation, some individuals exhibit the characteristic mediastinal shift away from the lesion. Bronchography or CT scanning can frequently show bronchiectasis.

Diagnosis is made based on the following triad of findings:

  • Unilateral hyperlucent lung- This occurs due to the trapping of expiratory air
  • Diffusely decreased ventilation in the affected lung
  • Affected lung shows decreased perfusion in angiography/ ventilation-perfusion scan

questions.text: All the following are components of Young's syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Asthma is not usually seen in Young's syndrome.

Young's syndrome is characterized by:

  • Bronchiectasis
  • Sinusitis
  • Obstructive azoospermia

In contrast, Kartagener's syndrome is characterized by

  • Bronchiectasis
  • Sinusitis 
  • Situs inversus

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image is that of Kocher forceps. It can be identified by the presence of serrations in the blade and apposing tooth in the tips.

It is used to hold the gauze for blunt dissection, to hold the resected bowel, and to hold the ribs during rib resection. 

Other options:

Option A - Babcock forceps:

  • The distal part of the distal blade is curved with a triangular opening which allows soft tissues to bulge out.
  • The tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations on it.
  • It has got a lock in the proximal part.
  • It is used to hold any part of the bowel, fallopian tube, appendix, ureter, cord, etc.


Option C - Lane tissue-holding forceps:

  • It has stout and thick distal blades, with an oval opening in each blade.
  • The tips have apposing tooth with a lock in the proximal part of the instrument
  • It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and hold lymph nodes.


Option D - Lister sinus forceps:

  • It has straight long blades with serrations in the tip.
  • It is used to drain pus during Hilton's method of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculi.
  • It is used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with painful ulcers on his penis. Examination revealed lesions with 'kissing ulcers' appearance and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which of the following images represents the microscopic appearance of a smear from these lesions?
questions.solution:
This above clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of chancroid. A smear from the lesion would reveal the presence of the gram-negative coccobacillus Haemophilus ducreyi, showing school of fish/railroad track appearance, as seen in image 1.

Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STI) that is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, a gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with painful genital ulceration along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called "kissing ulcers."

The diagnosis is made clinically and can be supported by school of fish/railroad track appearance on Gram stain (bacilli arranged in small groups, whorls, or parallel chains):

 

Option B: Multinucleated giant cells are seen on Tzanck smear in herpes genitalis. These ulcers are caused by herpes simplex type 2 virus and present as a cluster of vesicles on an erythematous base, with painful inguinal lymph nodes.

Tzanck smear is shown below:

 

Option C: Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly Calymmatobacterium granulomatis). It presents with painless beefy red ulcers. Inguinal lymph nodes are not usually enlarged, but the infection can spread subcutaneously and give the appearance of "pseudo buboes". The diagnosis is made by Giemsa staining, which shows the Donovan bodies. They show bipolar staining ("safety-pin appearance").

The image below shows Donovan bodies in a white blood cell:

 

Option D: Spirochetes are seen on dark-field microscopy in syphilitic ulcers. They are caused by Treponema pallidum and present with a single, painless genital ulcer with painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. 

Darkfield microscopy with spirochetes is shown below:

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text:
Arrange the following skeletal fusions in the ascending order of the ages at which they occur:
  1. Fusion of xiphoid process with the body of sternum
  2. Fusion of the four pieces of the body of sternum
  3. Fusion of greater tubercle with the head of humerus
  4. Fusion of greater cornu with the body of hyoid bone
questions.solution:
The correct order of ages at which the skeletal fusions occur is 3-2-1-4 (option D):

Fusion of greater tubercle with the head of humerus

 5 years

Fusion of the four pieces of the body of sternum

 14-25 years

Fusion of xiphoid process with the body of sternum

 40 years 

Fusion of greater cornu with the body of hyoid bone

  40-60 years

questions.text: A dietician advising a patient regarding diet plans considers the specific dynamic action (SDA) values for proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates. Identify the correct sequence of SDA values in these substrates.
questions.solution:
Among the given options, option C represents the correct sequence of specific dynamic values (SDA) of proteins > lipids > carbohydrates.

Specific dynamic allowance (previously called the thermic effect of food): This refers to the increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food (diet-induced thermogenesis).

The values of SDA are

  • 30% for proteins: This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.
  • 15% for lipids, and 
  • 5% for carbohydrates.

Importance: It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein-rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling.

questions.text:
Match the following Darrow-Yannet diagrams with the fluid shift occurring in the given conditions.
  1. Infusion of 3% normal saline
  2. Infusion of 0.45% normal saline
  3. Infusion of 0.9% Normal saline
  4. Normal
questions.solution:
Option D is correct. 

Diagram 1 - Normal

Diagram 2 - Infusion of 0.9% normal saline

Diagram 3 - Infusion of 0.45% normal saline

Diagram 4 - Infusion of 3% normal saline

Darrow-Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either addition or removal of fluid.

Diagram 1 - Normal extracellular fluid (ECF) and intracellular fluid (ICF) balance.

Diagram 2 - The addition of isotonic saline (0.9% normal saline) to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to an increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Diagram 3 - Hypotonic saline (0.45% normal saline) leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a shift of fluid from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both the compartments become equal. The fluid influx leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ICF as well. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both the compartments.

Diagram 4 - The addition of hypertonic saline to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text:
Match the following visual field defects with the likely site of the lesion:
  1. Right superior homonymous quadrantanopia
  2. Right-sided homonymous hemianopia
  3. Right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
  4. Right inferior quadrantic hemianopia
  5. Left-sided complete anopia
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-B, 3-E, 4-D, 5-A.

Lesion site Fibers affected Visual defect
A - Left optic nerve Left nasal,

Left temporal fibers 		 5. Left-sided complete anopia
B - Left optic tract Left temporal,

Right nasal fibers		 2. Right-sided homonymous hemianopia
C - Left Meyer's loop Left inferior temporal,

Right inferior nasal fibers 

1. Right superior homonymous  quadrantanopia

(Pie in the sky) 
D -Left Baum's loop Left superior temporal,

Right superior nasal fibers		 4. Right inferior homonymous quadrantanopia 

(Pie in the floor)
E -Left visual cortex sparing the macula Left temporal,

Right nasal fibers, except the macular fibers		 3. Right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 65-year-old asthma patient presents with tremors in both hands when he is trying to eat, write, or do some activity. He says that his symptoms worsen with stress and improve on drinking wine. Further questioning revealed that his handwriting has become larger and that his father had similar symptoms.  Which of the following is the most appropriate drug for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of essential tremors, and the most appropriate drug for this patient's condition is primidone.

Essential tremor (ET) is the most prevalent movement disorder. Although it can appear in children, its prevalence increases in people aged over 70 years. It is characterized by high-frequency tremors (6–10 Hz), most commonly involving the upper extremities. These tremors are usually symmetrical and bilateral. These tremors manifest when the person is trying to do some activity and are typically made worse by stress and improved by alcohol. Approximately half the patients with ET have a positive family history.

Severe ET may present as intention tremor characterized by overshoot and slow movements, indicating the cerebellar origin of this disorder. 

The drugs used to treat essential tremors are as follows:

  • Primidone and beta blockers - standard therapy; as beta-blockers (e.g. propranolol) are contraindicated in asthma and bradycardia, primidone is the better choice for this patient 
  • Gabapentin and topiramate- use has not been widespread
  • Botulinum toxin injections for limb or vocal tremors - may result in muscle weakening
  • Surgical treatments targetting the ventro-intermediate (VIM) nucleus of the thalamus - For severe and drug-resistant instances

Note: Essential tremor can be differentiated from Parkinson's disease by the following features: This patient has bilateral tremors on trying to do voluntary activities and his handwriting has become larger. In contrast, in Parkinson's disease, tremors typically begin in one hand, would stop at the onset of voluntary action, and patients usually develop micrographia (small handwriting).

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is found to be hypotonic, with a high forehead, large anterior fontanelle, markedly separated cranial sutures, and hepatomegaly. Further investigations confirmed a diagnosis of the cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome. Which of the following biochemical findings would not be seen in this case?

choices.text: Elevated levels of very long chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
In cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome or Zellweger syndrome, there is a decreased level of plasmalogens.

Zellweger syndrome is caused by mutations in the peroxins (PEX) family of genes. As a result of this, there is a defective transport of the proteins to the peroxisomes. It severely impairs the functions of peroxisomes, resulting in defective beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA), defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

The child presents with

  • Dysmorphic facial features like wide anterior fontanelles markedly separated cranial sutures, epicanthal folds, broad nasal bridge, hypoplastic supraorbital ridges, etc.
  • Profound developmental delay, profound hypotonia with depressed deep tendon reflexes, neonatal seizures, and impaired hearing
  • Calcific stippling of the epiphyses
  • Renal cysts
  • Hepatomegaly

Biochemical findings will show:

  • Accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, phytanic acid, and pipecolic acids
  • Abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids
  • Marked reduction of plasmalogens
  • Elevated levels of plasma phytanic acid

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe, and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding respiratory centers and the regulation of respiration?

choices.text: Spontaneous respiration stops if there is damage to medulla
Stimulation of pneumotaxic centers increases the respiratory rate
Vagotomy causes an increase in the depth of inspiration
Central chemoreceptors are highly sensitive to the intra-arterial and venous H+ concentration

questions.solution:
Central chemoreceptors are sensitive to the H+ concentration of cerebrospinal fluid and brain interstitial fluid.

Respiratory centers of the brain:

  • Pre-Botzinger complex - This is responsible for rhythmic and automatic respiration. It is located in the medulla. Therefore, damage to the medulla results in loss of spontaneous respiration. (Option A)
  • Pneumotaxic centers - The rhythmic discharge produced by the pre-Botziger complex is further modified by the pneumotaxic centers. They are located in the medial parabrachial and Kölliker-Fuse nuclei of the pons. They play a role in switching between inspiration and expiration. Stimulation of the pneumotaxic center results in an increase in the respiratory rate and a decrease in the tidal volume (Option B), Conversely, damage to these centers will result in increased tidal volume and decreased rate of breathing.
  • Vagus nerve - Stretching of the lung results in the generation of impulses in the pulmonary vagal fibers. These signals inhibit further inspiration. Therefore, whenever there is vagotomy, the inspiration is not inhibited and results in increased depth of inspiration (Option D). There will also be prolonged inspiratory spasms that resemble breath-holding (apneusis).

Chemoreceptors of the brain:

Peripheral chemoreceptors - They are located in the carotid and aortic bodies. They are stimulated by a rise in the PCO2 or H+ concentration of arterial blood or a decline in its PO2. The signals are sent through the glossopharyngeal nerve and vagus nerve respectively.

Central chemoreceptors - They are located in the ventral surface of the medulla. They are sensitive to the H+ concentration of cerebrospinal fluid and brain interstitial fluid. H+ and HCO3- present in the blood cannot readily cross the blood-brain barrier, whereas CO2 can readily cross this barrier. Therefore, when there is an increase in pCO2, CO2 crosses the blood-brain barrier. It is then converted to H2CO3, which then dissociates to form H+ and HCO3-. This H+ stimulates the central chemoreceptors.

Related Pearl: Respiratory Centres

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient complains of bilateral lower limb pain described as burning. She is diabetic and has not been compliant with medications. Physical examination shows that the pain is distributed in a stocking-like pattern bilaterally. Her HbA1C is measured to be 8.5%. Which of the following is a first-line drug for the management of the patient's pain?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of diabetic neuropathy. Duloxetine is a selective serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the first-line drugs used in the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

This patient with uncontrolled diabetes suggested by her elevated HbA1C and glove-stocking pattern of pain distribution is highly suggestive of diabetic neuropathy. The pain is commonly characterized as burning pain or tingling. 

Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:

 First-line

  • Duloxetine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
  • Gabapentin, Pregabalin
  • Venlafaxine

Second Line

  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Tramadol
  • Tapentadol

Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.

 Types of diabetic neuropathy

  • Distal symmetric sensory or sensorimotor polyneuropathy
    • Most common type
    • Begins at the toes and slowly moves proximally
    • Presents as tingling, burning, or deep aching pain.
    • Commonly presents in a glove and stocking distribution
  • Autonomic neuropathy
    Presents as abnormal sweating, GI abnormalities, dry eyes and mouth, pupillary abnormalities, dysfunctional thermoregulation, cardiac arrhythmias, postural hypotension, etc.
  • Diabetic radiculoplexus neuropathy (diabetic amyotrophy or Bruns-Garland Syndrome)
    • Presents as low back/ hip/ thigh pain
    • Commonly associated with weight loss

The image below shows the glove-stocking distribution of pain. 

Related Pearl: Sensory Loss In peripheral Neuropathies

Symmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)
  • Diabetes mellitus and other metabolic disorders
  • Drugs and toxins
  • Familial (HSAN), CMT, amyloidosis
  • Inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (GBS and CIDP) 

Asymmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cancer (paraneoplastic)
  • Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Idiopathic sensory neuronopathy (possible GBS variant)
  • Cisplatin and other chemotherapeutic agents
  • Vitamin B6 toxicity
  • Multifocal CIDP, vasculitis, cryoglobulinemia, amyloidosis, sarcoid, infectious (leprosy, Lyme, hepatitis B, C, or E, HIV, CMV), tumor infiltration 
  • Compressive mononeuropathy, plexopathy, or radiculopathy
  • Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus
  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)

questions.text: The given image is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of Heinz bodies and bite cells suggestive of Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.

In Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, after oxidant drug exposure, the peripheral blood smear shows red cells with precipitates of denatured globin which are known as Heinz bodies. 

As the splenic macrophages pluck out these inclusions, bite cells similar to the one in this smear are produced.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with complaints of backache, morning stiffness, and redness of the eyes. An x-ray image of the spine is given below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a young male with backache, morning stiffness, redness of the eye, and the X-ray showing the classical bamboo-spine appearance are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis. All the given options are true, except "sciatica is common". Referred pain in the buttocks and thighs may be mistaken for sciatica and some patients are mistakenly treated for intervertebral disc prolapse.

 

Ankylosing spondylitis commonly involves young male adults. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker.

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints is the earliest and cardinal sign.
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body ‘squaring’
    • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels
    • Long-standing cases are associated with osteoporosis. Wedging of the vertebral bodies produces hyperkyphosis of the spine
  • Progressive bony ankylosis or erosive arthritis may be seen in peripheral joints. 

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis: 

Sacroiliitis on imaging: Active inflammation on MRI highly suggestive of spondyloarthropathy associated sacroiliitis and/or definite radiographic sacroiliitis according to modified New York criteria plus ≥1 Spondyloarthropathy (SpA) feature

              OR

HLA-B27 plus ≥2 other SpA features.

Spondyloarthropathy (SpA) features:

  • Inflammatory back pain
  • Arthritis
  • Enthesitis (heel)
  • Anterior uveitis
  • Dactylitis 
  • Psoriasis 
  • Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis
  • Good response to NSAIDs.
  • Family history of spondyloarthropathy
  • HLA-B27 
  • Elevated CRP

Extra-articular manifestations: Acute anterior uveitis occurs in about 25% of patients. It usually responds well to treatment but may lead to permanent damage including glaucoma if it is not treated appropriately. Others are pericarditis, aortic incompetence, apical lobe fibrosis, generalized osteoporosis, and atlantoaxial joint subluxation.

questions.text: An AIDS patient presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. Skin biopsy reveals proliferating spindle cells in the dermis, with slit-like spaces containing the red cells. Which of the following is not associated with the causative organism of the patient's current presentation?
questions.solution:
The above image shows red-purple macules and plaques, the clinical features, and the biopsy findings are together suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, which is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8). Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by the human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV-1) and not HHV8.

HTLV is a retrovirus, which is the causative agent of adult T-cell leukemia-lymphomas (ATL) as well as a nervous system degenerative disorder called tropical spastic paraparesis.

HHV8 is associated with:

  • Kaposi sarcomas - HHV8 affects the lymphovascular system and presents as pigmented skin lesions. It is the most common HIV-related malignancy and is an AIDS-defining illness. The lesions appear as red-purple macules or raised plaques over the skin, and the biopsy shows spindle cells in the dermis.
  • Primary effusion lymphomas are body-cavity-based lymphomas associated with AIDS. They occur as an effusion in the pleural, pericardial, or peritoneal cavities without the presence of a mass in the cavity.
  • Multicentric Castleman disease causes symptoms like fever, chills, and generalized lymphadenopathy and is seen in patients with or without HIV/AIDS.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does not follow the inheritance pattern shown in the pedigree chart given below?
questions.solution:
The pedigree chart represents autosomal dominant inheritance. This pattern is not seen in von Gierke's disease as it follows autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.

Autosomal dominant disorders are passed on to the offspring when at least one parent is affected. Both males and females can be affected and can transmit the disease. In this pattern, when one parent is affected, every child has a one in two chance of having the disease.

von Gierke disease is a glycogen storage disorder, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It is caused due to deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. The characteristic clinical features include hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

von Hippel–Lindau syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is strongly associated with renal cell carcinoma and pheochromocytoma.

von Recklinghausen disease (neurofibramatosis-1) is an autosomal dominant disorder with variable penetrance. Some of the manifestations of this condition include neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and axillary freckling. It is also associated with Lisch nodules, pheochromocytomas, and pseudoarthrosis.

von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder and presents with easy bruising, increased bleeding from wounds, and heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: Identify the Doppler waveform and the condition associated with it.
questions.solution:
The given Doppler waveform is monophasic, which is seen in severe stenosis of the artery.

A normal artery has a triphasic signal. The waveform becomes biphasic in mild-moderate stenosis and monophasic in severe stenosis.

The image given below shows the normal triphasic signal from an artery.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male patient had a stroke involving the medulla and pons, which led to the complete obliteration of the vagal input to the esophagus. Which of the following changes in esophageal peristalsis are likely to be seen after a few days?

choices.text: Elimination of primary esophageal peristalsis only
Elimination of secondary esophageal peristalsis only
Elimination of both primary and secondary esophageal peristalsis
No change in primary or secondary esophageal peristalsis

questions.solution:
The absence of vagal input to the esophagus will result in the elimination of only primary peristalsis of esophagus. The secondary peristalsis will remain intact due to the activity of the intrinsic myenteric nerve plexus. Within a few days, the excitability of the myenteric plexus increases, resulting in strong secondary peristaltic waves.

There are two types of esophageal peristaltic movements: primary and secondary.

A. Primary peristalsis occurs as a continuation of the peristaltic wave that begins in the pharynx and spreads into the esophagus during the pharyngeal stage of swallowing. It passes from the pharynx to the esophagus, within about 8 to 10 seconds. However, due to the effect of gravity in an upright position, the food passes within 5 to 8 seconds.

B. Secondary peristalsis occurs if the primary peristaltic wave failed to empty the food from the esophagus into the stomach. Secondary peristalsis is initiated by the distension of the esophageal wall by the retained food. Waves continue until all the food is emptied into the stomach. Secondary peristaltic waves are initiated partly by intrinsic neural circuits in the myenteric nervous system and partly by reflexes that begin in the pharynx. 

Control of peristaltic waves: The musculature of the pharyngeal wall and upper third of the esophagus is striated muscle. These regions are controlled by skeletal nerve impulses from the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves.

The musculature of the lower two-thirds of the esophagus is smooth muscle. This region is strongly controlled by the vagus nerves, which act through connections with the esophagal myenteric nervous system.

Effect of obliteration of vagal input to the esophagus: When the vagal nerves are cut, or the vagal input is obliterated by any other cause such as stroke, the primary peristalsis, solely dependent on the vagal innervation, is eliminated. 

However, the intrinsic myenteric nerve plexus of the esophagus becomes excitable within days, causes strong secondary peristaltic waves. Therefore, even after paralysis of the brain stem swallowing reflex, food fed by a tube into the esophagus passes into the stomach due to the secondary peristaltic movements.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old patient was rushed to the casualty with massive hemoptysis. Which of the following are the indications of urgent surgical intervention for massive hemoptysis?

1. Presence of significant cavitary disease
2. Presence of a fungal ball
3. Presence of a lung abscess
questions.solution:
Indications for urgent surgical intervention for massive hemoptysis are the presence of significant cavitatory disease, a fungal ball, a lung abscess, and failure to control the bleeding. So, option C is the correct answer.

Massive hemoptysis is generally defined as the expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 24-hour period.

Treatment priorities in the management of massive hemoptysis:

  • Prevent asphyxiation by achieving respiratory stabilization
  • Localize the bleeding site using flexible/ rigid bronchoscopy 
  • Control the hemorrhage
  • Determine the cause of bleeding
  • Prevent a recurrence

questions.text: At around 11.30 PM, a 45-year-old man is wheeled into the casualty with anginal pain for which the consultant advises nitrates. On administration of nitrates, his BP suddenly drops and the patient goes into sudden hypotension. On probing into his medical history, his wife mentions that he has been taking a drug for erectile dysfunction. What is the likely mechanism of the action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Erectile dysfunction is treated by phosphodiesterase 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil, and tadalafil. PDE-5 inhibitors and nitrates should not be prescribed together due to an increased risk of hypotension.

The corpus cavernosum produces nitric oxide during arousal that stimulates the formation of cGMP. cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle of the corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, engorgement of the corpus cavernosum, and erection. PDE-5 inhibitors enhance the accumulation of cGMP and are, therefore, used in the management of erectile dysfunction.

Drug interactions of PDE-5 and nitrates- PDE-5 inhibitors enhance the accumulation of cGMP by preventing its degradation and therefore cause vasodilation. Since nitrates also act by increasing cyclic GMP mechanism, they can therefore potentiate the effects of PDE-5 inhibitors. Hence, men treated with PDE-5 inhibitors and nitrates are at risk for severe hypotension and syncope.

Adverse effects of PDE-5 inhibitors-

  • The most common side effects reported include headache, flushing, nasal congestion, nasopharyngitis, and dyspepsia. Rare but serious reports of prolonged erections lasting more than 4 hours and priapism (painful erections lasting more than 4 hours) have been reported with PDE5 inhibitors. 
  • Sildenafil and vardenafil also cause retinal PDE-6 inhibition and can result in blurring of vision and blue-green tinting of the vision.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with tingling and weakness in his right hand and left foot for the past 4 days. He is also a known case of asthma and is on treatment.  On examination, you notice that the patient has a purpura over his body. Laboratory investigations reveal marked eosinophilia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mono neuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia in an asthmatic patient is suggestive of Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a necrotizing vasculitis of the small-to-medium-sized vessels and is characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, granuloma formation, and vasculitis.

Common presenting symptoms of this condition are

  • Initial non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss
  • Severe attacks of asthma, allergic rhinitis, sinusitis
  • Mononeuritis multiplex- It is a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two nerve areas. Patients complain of pain, tingling, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas.
  • Skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules

Laboratory investigations will show eosinophilia. They also show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), fibrinogen, or α2-globulins. Some patients may be positive for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Histopathology shows the presence of necrotizing vasculitis, tissue eosinophilia, and extravascular granulomas.

Daily cyclophosphamide and prednisolone, followed by azathioprine or methotrexate, can be used for the treatment. Mepolizumab, a monoclonal antibody against IL-5, is the drug recently approved by the FDA for Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Note: A rare side effect following the use of montelukast and zafirlukast is the development of Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with microscopic polyangiitis can have symptoms of mononeuritis multiplex and cutaneous purpura. However, features of asthma and eosinophilia make microscopic polyangiitis less likely as the diagnosis.

Option B: Polyarteritis nodosa can also present with mononeuritis multiplex and skin lesions, but patients do not have eosinophilia. In addition to this, it does not affect bronchial or pulmonary arteries.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's) also has symptoms of upper respiratory tract infection (sinusitis, septal perforation, otitis media), lower respiratory tract involvement (hemoptysis, dyspnea, and chest discomfort), and glomerulonephritis. However, eosinophilia is not a feature of this disease.

Related Pearl: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are small vessel vasculitides that are mainly caused due to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Therefore, they share common clinical features with some differences.

Features Microscopic polyangiitis Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with neck swelling as shown below. The swelling moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. CT confirms the diagnosis by showing a well-circumscribed lesion with homogenous fluid attenuation, surrounded by a thin, enhancing rim. Which of the following procedures is used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with an image showing a midline swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue with CT findings of well-circumscribed lesions with homogenous fluid attenuation surrounded by a thin, enhancing rim is diagnostic of thyroglossal cyst. The treatment of choice for these patients is the Sistrunk operation.

Thyroglossal duct cyst (TDGC)

The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. Once the gland reaches its position, where isthmus is at the level of the second and third tracheal rings, the tract of thyroglossal duct disappears. A thyroglossal cyst represents the persistence of this track and can be found adjacent to the midline.

Classically, swellings associated with the thyroid move with deglutition. Thyroglossal cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion, and it indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. Although they often occur in children, they may also present in adults, even as late as the 6th or 7th decade.

Diagnosis: 

CT scan commonly confirms the diagnosis by showing well-circumscribed lesions with homogenous fluid attenuation surrounded by a thin, enhancing rim.

FNAC may be used to exclude other causes.

Differential diagnosis: 

  • TGDC is the most common cause of a midline neck mass, followed by dermoid cysts.
  • Dermoid and sebaceous cysts are generally not tethered to underlying structures such as the hyoid bone and tend to be superficial.
  • Branchial cleft cysts are generally associated with the sinus tract or fistula, whereas TGDCs are not.
  • Lipomas are quite superficial and have ill-defined edges.

Treatment:

Sistrunk operation

This operation involves the excision of the entire thyroglossal tract, with the removal of the body of the hyoid bone and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen cecum, together with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: Which of the following strains of Chlamydia are implicated in causing trachoma?
questions.solution:
Serotypes A, B, and C are implicated in the development of trachoma, a form of chronic conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

Trachoma is considered a major cause of blindness in the developing world. It is endemic in nature, mostly affecting children with a female preponderance. The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:

Stage 1: Incipient 

  • Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious.

Stage 2: Established

  • Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring

Stage 3: Cicatrizing

  • Scarring along with active infection

Stage 4: Healed

  • Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet.

Other Options:

Options A and D - Serotypes L1-L3 are implicated in lymphogranuloma venereum.

Option B - Serotypes D-K are implicated in the development of acute inclusion conjunctivitis, genital ulcers, and infantile pneumonia. Acute inclusion conjunctivitis presents with follicular and papillary hypertrophy, which is greater in the lower eyelid, and associated with moderately abundant exudate that is principally composed of neutrophils.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought with loud, raspy, and noisy breathing. His mother also says that his voice has become hoarse over the past 3-4 months. He was born at term through an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of laryngeal papilloma or recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.

It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by human papilloma DNA virus (HPV) types 6 and 11. Squamous papillomas can be seen in children, juvenile papillomatosis (as in this case), and in adults, adult-onset papilloma. 

It is thought that the patients acquire this condition from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus infection during birth. It is usually seen in the supraglottic and glottic regions. Less commonly, the subglottis, trachea, and bronchi may be involved.

Clinically, the patient is typically a young child 3-5 years of age. They may present with hoarseness of voice, stridor, and breathing difficulty. The disease recurs requiring repeated surgical and medical management throughout childhood. Rarely, they may undergo malignant change. 

It is diagnosed using flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and may later be confirmed by direct laryngoscopy or rigid bronchoscopy and biopsy.

Treatment of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis:

  • Surgical management with excision using a CO2 laser
  • Medical management using interferon-alpha has been tried as an adjuvant, but it is associated with significant side effects 

The adult-onset version is usually less severe and does not recur after surgical removal. It affects males more than females and presents between the ages of 30-50 years. 

Other options: 

Option A - Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition of the larynx that manifests at birth and disappears by the age of 2 years. Babies present with stridor on crying that relieves in the prone position. 

The following image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis of laryngomalacia:

 

Option B - Reinke's edema is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. 

The following image shows Reinke's edema:

 

Option C - Vocal cord nodules occur at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords. This occurs due to vocal trauma that happens when the patient speaks in low tones or high intensities for prolonged periods. 

The following image shows a unilateral vocal nodule:

questions.text: A patient in ICU is started on a blood transfusion. Within 20 minutes, the patient develops fever with chills and flank pain. His urine appears red in color. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has a sudden onset of fever with chills, flank pain, and hemoglobinuria soon after starting blood transfusion. The most likely diagnosis is acute hemolytic transfusion reaction. 

It occurs due to the preformed IgM antibodies against the donor red cells. These antibodies cause complement-mediated lysis of red blood cells. The patient will present with fever, abdominal, flank, or back pain, hemoglobinuria, and hypotension.

When it is suspected, the transfusion should be immediately stopped, and the blood bank should be notified about the reaction. The blood bank should evaluate the patient's blood samples for hemolysis and the presence of antibodies. Antibodies can be tested for by direct antiglobulin test (DAT), sometimes called the direct Coombs test. The blood levels of lactate dehydrogenase, indirect bilirubin, and serum haptoglobin should be assessed. 

Non-immunologic reactions:

  1. Fluid overload
  2. Hypothermia
  3. Hypocalcemia due to increased chelation of calcium by citrate
  4. Hyperkalemia due to increased release of potassium from lysed cells
  5. Iron overload
  6. Transient hypotension
  7. Transfusion-mediated immunomodulation- Multiple sittings of transfusion of allogenic blood leads to immunosuppression.

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Immunological Transfusion Reactions             

Reaction
(Onset)

(Seconds-minutes)

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding maple syrup urine disease?

choices.text: Urine, sweat, and cerumen have a characteristic burnt sugar odor
Strict dietary methionine restriction is advised on diagnosis
It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner
Untreated individuals have motor delay, but otherwise normal IQ levels.

questions.solution:
Urine, sweat, and cerumen have a characteristic burnt sugar odor/maple syrup-like odor in maple syrup urine disease (MSUD).

Only branched-chain amino acids need to be restricted; hence, methionine does not need any restriction in diet.

Branched-chain amino acids are

  • Leucine (L)
  • Isoleucine (I)
  • Valine (V)

MSUD is an autosomal recessive disorder in which there is a partial or complete deficiency of branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKD). This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids. These amino acids, particularly leucine and its metabolite accumulate in the blood, causing toxic effects on the brain. Features include feeding problems, vomiting, ketosis, and a characteristic burnt sugar odor/maple syrup-like odor found in urine, sweat, and cerumen.

Infants with untreated classic maple syrup urine disease have significant developmental delay and die within the first few months of life.

Laboratory investigations will show increased levels of branched-chain amino acids in the plasma and urine. Leucine levels are usually higher than isoleucine and valine levels.

Treatment involves restricted intake of branched-chain amino acids using commercially available formulas and judicious supplementation of isoleucine and valine. Very high levels of leucine are removed by hemodialysis.
