questions.text: A filamentous bacterium shows positive Gram staining and hyphae-like branching on microscopy. What is the sequence of the acid-fast staining technique used to identify the same organism?
questions.solution:
The gram-positive, filamentous bacterium, with a hyphae-like branching is Nocardia. The sequence for acid-fast staining for Nocardia is Carbolfuchsin → heat → 4% sulfuric acid → methylene blue.

Nocardia appears as filamentous organisms with extensive hyphae-like branching. They are gram-positive, catalase-positive, and produce urease. They are weakly acid fast because they stain with carbolfuchsin (routine acid-fast stain) and retain when decolorized with 1-4% sulfuric acid instead of the stronger acid-alcohol decolorant.

Acid-fast staining is based on the principle that tubercle bacilli resist decolorization with acids after staining with aniline dyes. This means that once the bacterium is stained, it cannot be decolorized using acids routinely used in the process. Acid-fast organisms usually contain mycolic acid, which is acid fast. The steps to carry out acid-fast staining as modified by Ziehl and Neelsen are as follows:

  1. The slide is stained with carbolfuchsin along with the application of heat.
  2. It is then decolorized with 20% sulfuric acid. Later, methylene blue is used for counterstaining.
  3. The acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin color, while other organisms take up the counterstain.

Option C: Crystal violet → Iodine solution → ethanol → carbolfuchsin is the sequence followed for Gram stain.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text:
Match the following pairs of drugs with their antidotes.
      Drug         Antidote
  1. Heparin 
  2. Dabigatran
  3. Warfarin
  4. Rivaroxaban
  1. Vitamin K
  2. Protamine sulfate 
  3. Idarucizumab
  4. Andexanet alfa
questions.solution:
Option B is correctly matched.

Drug  Antidote
1. Heparin b. Protamine sulfate
2. Dabigatran c. Idarucizumab
3. Warfarin a. Vitamin K
4. Rivaroxaban d. Andexanet alfa


Heparin - Protamine sulfate(1-b) :

Protamine sulfate is indicated for the reversal of heparin overdose. It binds to long heparin molecules with high affinity and neutralizes anticoagulant activity. Therefore, it completely reverses the action of unfractionated heparin but only partially reverses the action of low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH). It has no effect on fondaparinux.

Dabigatran - Idarucizumab (2-c) :

Idarucizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically acts as a reversal agent for dabigatran. It has a 350 times higher affinity for dabigatran than dabigatran for thrombin. Hence, it forms a complex with dabigatran, which is excreted by the kidneys.

Warfarin - Vitamin K (3-a) :

Vitamin K is given orally as well as intravenously to treat warfarin toxicity. It causes the reversal of anticoagulation effects of warfarin by synthesis of vitamin K–dependent coagulation factors (II, VII, IX, X).

Rivaroxaban - Andexanet alfa (4-d) :

Andexanet alfa is a recombinant analog of factor Xa and is used as a reversal agent for oral factor Xa inhibitors like rivaroxaban, edoxaban, and apixaban. It rapidly reverses the action of these drugs and restores thrombin generation. It is given intravenously.

Note:

Ciraparantag is considered a potential reversal agent against all direct anticoagulants, including dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban, as well as heparin and LMWH. This drug is in the early stages of development.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants

2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are seen in tumor lysis syndrome?
  1. Hyperuricemia
  2. Hyperkalemia
  3. Hypokalemia
  4. Hyperphosphatemia
  5. Hypocalcemia
  6. Hypercalcemia
questions.solution:
The correct option is option C: 1, 2, 4, and 5. Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia occur in tumor lysis syndrome.

Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It most commonly occurs after the initiation of chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

TLS is characterized by

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia 
  • Acidosis
  • Acute renal failure

The management of TLS includes aggressive hydration along with allopurinol. Febuxostat a selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, and rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase can be used to treat hyperuricemia. Hypocalcemia is not treated unless it is symptomatic, to avoid metastatic calcifications. Patients with renal impairment are managed with hemodialysis.

questions.text:
Arrange the following cellular events of inflammation in the correct sequence:
  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine-mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of cellular events that occurs during inflammation is as follows: Rolling, Cytokine-mediated integrin activation, Adhesion, Migration.

The recruitment of leucocytes to the site of inflammation is a multi-step process that is mediated by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines. This process can be divided into sequential phases:

  1. In the lumen: margination, rolling and adhesion to the endothelium occurs.
  2. Migration of the leucocytes across the endothelium and vessel wall
  3. Migration in the tissues towards a chemotactic stimulus.

The process of leucocyte recruitment is as follows:

  • Margination: Because of the dilation of the inflamed postcapillary venues, there is stasis of blood flow, and hence, more leucocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface; this process of leucocyte redistribution is called margination.
  • Rolling: The slowed down leucocytes then sense the signals from the endothelium and start rolling on the vessel wall.
  • Cytokine-mediated integrin activation: The attachment of leucocytes to the endothelial cells requires adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. The major families of proteins involved in adhesion and migration are selectins and integrins and their ligands.
  • Adhesions: The weak rolling interactions slow down the leucocytes and allow them to bind more firmly to the endothelium. Chemokines that were produced at the site of injury bind to the endothelial cell proteoglycans. These chemokines then bind to the rolling leucocytes and activate them. This, in turn, converts the ligands for β1 and β2 integrins, VLA-4, and LFA-1 present on the leucocytes to a high-affinity state.
  • This combination of cytokine-induced expression of integrin ligands on the endothelium and increased integrin affinity on the leucocytes leads to firm adhesion of leucocytes to the endothelium at the site of inflammation.
  • Leucocyte migration: This is the movement of leucocytes through the intact endothelium, called transmigration or diapedesis. This occurs in postcapillary venules. This migration occurs through the inter-endothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions such as platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1) or CD31. 

Related Pearl: Principal Mediators of Inflammation and Their Source

Mediator Source

Prostaglandins Mast cells, leukocytes
Leukotrienes Mast cells, leukocytes
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6) Macrophages, endothelial cells, mast cells
Chemokines Leukocytes, activated macrophages
Platelet-activating factor Leukocytes, mast cells
Complement Plasma (produced in liver)

Related Pearl: Various actions of Principal Mediators of Inflammation

Prostaglandins Vasodilation, pain, fever

Systemic: fever, metabolic abnormalities, hypotension (shock)

Note: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a prostaglandin, which is a potent vasoconstrictor

questions.text: A hypertensive male patient presents to you with complaints of tingling sensations over his legs. Investigations revealed an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, negative antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody screening, and fibrinoid necrosis on skin tissue biopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is polyarteritis nodosa. 

Polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing vasculitis of small and medium-sized arteries, especially renal and visceral arteries. Affected individuals usually present with nonspecific symptoms such as fever and weight loss. Other symptoms include arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, abdominal pain, and rashes. Involvement of the renal arteries can manifest as renal failure or hypertension. 

In chronic cases, a biopsy of affected sites such as skin lesions shows fibrinoid necrosis of the vessels under microscopy as shown below. Aneurysmal dilatations up to 1 centimeter of the involved arteries is characteristic.

 

Investigations will show raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP), and leukocytosis. Patients are generally managed with a combination of prednisone and cyclophosphamide. The prognosis in untreated cases is poor.

Other options:

Option B: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, is characterized by granulomatous vasculitis of the respiratory tract along with glomerulonephritis. Symptoms include bloody nasal discharge, hemoptysis, cough, and hematuria. In advanced cases, renal failure can occur. Airway biopsy shows granulomatous inflammation with necrosis. Laboratory findings include positive antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA), raised ESR, and leukocytosis. 

The image below shows a lung biopsy observed under the microscope:

 

Option C: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis), is marked by eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis. It is an ANCA-positive small vessel vasculitis and presents with asthmatic attacks, fever, and weight loss. ESR and CRP are usually elevated. Biopsy shows granulomas with eosinophilic infiltration of tissues as shown below:

 

Option D: Henoch-Schonlein purpura (IgA vasculitis), is a type of small vessel vasculitis commonly seen in children. It is usually preceded by streptococcal pharyngitis. They present with palpable purpura, arthralgia, and hematuria. Mild leukocytosis and raised IgA levels might be seen. A skin biopsy will show immunoglobulin A (IgA) deposition under direct immunofluorescence as shown below:

1. Tsetse fly a. Q-fever

questions.text: A newborn is being assessed for his gestational age. Which of the following is not a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score?
questions.solution:
The cubital angle is not a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded new Ballard score.

The expanded New Ballard score is used to assess the physical and neuromuscular maturity of the newborn and thereby calculate the gestational age.

  • There are six criteria each to assess physical maturity and neuromuscular maturity.
  • The physical maturity and neurologic maturity scores are added to calculate the gestational age.
  • The minimum score is -10 and the maximum score is 50.
  • It is accurate to within 2 wk of actual gestational age
  • Premature infants have low scores while post dated infants have higher scores.

Neuromuscular criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  1. Posture
  2. Square window (wrist)
  3. Arm recoil
  4. Popliteal angle
  5. Scarf sign
  6. Heel to ear

Physical criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  1. Skin
  2. Lanugo
  3. Plantar surface
  4. Breast
  5. Eye/ear
  6. Genitals - male or female

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient is diagnosed to have malignant mesothelioma in his right hemithorax. What is the embryological origin of the layer from which this tumor arises?
questions.solution:
Malignant mesothelioma arises from the mesothelium of the pleura, which originates from the lateral plate mesoderm.

At the end of the third week of embryonic development, the intraembryonic mesoderm differentiates into paraxial mesoderm, intermediate mesoderm, and lateral plate mesoderm. Within the lateral plate mesoderm, a large cavity known as intraembryonic celom is formed. The intraembryonic celom forms the pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities.

The lateral plate mesoderm is divided by the intraembryonic celom to form:

  • Somatopleuric or parietal layer of intraembryonic mesoderm that is in contact with the ectoderm. This forms the parietal layer of peritoneal, pleural, and pericardial membranes.
  • Splanchnopleuric or visceral layer of intraembryonic mesoderm that is in contact with endoderm. This forms the visceral layer of the peritoneal, pleural, and pericardial membranes.

The derivatives of endoderm are epithelium of the larynx, trachea, lungs, digestive tract, hepatocytes, etc.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesoderm

 

Mesoderm derivatives
Paraxial mesoderm
  • Skeletal muscles of the trunk, limbs, head, and neck
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Intrinsic muscles of the tongue
  • Bones: Vertebrae, ribs
  • Dermis of Skin
  • Duramater
Intermediate mesoderm
  • Urinary system: Kidneys, ureters, trigone of the urinary bladder
  • Dorsal part of prostatic urethra (males)
  • Gonads: Testes and ovaries
  • Genital ducts
  • Adrenal cortex
Lateral plate mesoderm
  • Bones: Sternum, limb bones
  • Serous membranes of body cavities: Pleura, pericardium, peritoneum
  • GIT layers: Lamina propria, muscularis mucosae, submucosa, muscularis externa, adventitia
  • Blood cells: Microglia, Kupffer cells
  • Cardiovascular system
  • Lymphatic system
  • Laryngeal cartilages

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with complaints of headache, projectile vomiting, and blurring of vision. CT scan shows a mass lesion in the posterior cranial fossa. His medical records are unremarkable, except for a family history of colon cancer in three of his relatives. What is the most probable syndrome that this patient has?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the family history of colon cancer point to the diagnosis of Turcot syndrome. 

Turcot syndrome is a rare hereditary disorder clinically characterized by the occurrence of primary tumors of the colon and the central nervous system.

Two types of tumors are seen in Turcot syndrome. The first is characterized by childhood cerebellar medulloblastoma caused by mutations in the APC gene. The second type is characterized by gliomas, particularly glioblastoma multiforme, arising in both children and adults and is related to mismatch repair gene mutations.

Familial carcinoma syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them:

  •  Gorlin syndrome: Medulloblastoma and multiple early-onset basal cell carcinomas
  •  Lynch syndrome: Gastrointestinal and genito-urinary tumors and rarely gliomas in the brain
  •  Neurofibromatosis: Schwannoma

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented with complaints of abdominal pain, weight loss, and early satiety for 2 years. Endoscopy was suggestive of gastric cancer. A biopsy of the same is shown below. Which of the following molecular pathophysiological features may be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image showing signet ring cells is suggestive of diffuse-type gastric cancer, which has decreased E-cadherin expression. Cells in diffuse-type gastric cancer have large mucin vacuoles that expand the cytoplasm and push the nucleus to the periphery, which creates a signet-ring cell.

Lauren's system classifies gastric cancer into the following types based on differences in etiology, epidemiology, and pathology:

  • Type I - intestinal
  • Type II - diffuse

Molecular pathologies seen in the intestinal type are as follows:

  • Loss-of-function mutations in the APC gene or in β-catenin
  • Inactivation of p53 (tumor-suppressor gene) and p16 (cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor)
  • Microsatellite instability

Molecular pathologies seen in diffuse-type are as follows: 

  • Loss-of-function mutations in CDH1, leading to decreased E-cadherin
  • Inactivation of p53 and p16

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby is brought by his mother for vaccination. The concept of conjugate and polysaccharide vaccines is explained to her.  Which of the following is incorrect regarding conjugate vaccines?

choices.text: They are not effective in children below 2 years of age
They act via T-cell dependent mechanism

questions.solution:
Option 1 is the incorrect statement. Conjugate vaccines are effective in children below 2 years of age. 

Antigens in polysaccharide vaccines produce antibodies via a T-cell-independent mechanism. Children under 2 years of age do not respond well to such antigens. A stronger immune response and immune memory in young children can be elicited if these polysaccharide antigens are chemically linked or conjugated to a protein that is recognized by T-cells. As conjugate vaccines are serotype-specific, multivalent formulations are required to achieve protection against multiple serotypes. Examples are pneumococcal and meningococcal vaccines.

questions.text: A road traffic accident victim was brought with a suspected spinal injury. On examination, GCS score was E3V4M5, and he was hemodynamically stable. After a day of Foley's catheter insertion, he developed tachycardia and his blood pressure went up to 190/110 mmHg. He also started complaining of a headache and started sweating. At what level is the lesion expected to be?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of autonomic dysreflexia. Among the given options, it is most likely due to a lesion above the level of T6. 

Autonomic dysreflexia is a condition that emerges when the spinal cord is injured above the T6 level. The blood pressure of the patient suddenly rises in response to stimuli like bladder or bowel distension that originates below the level of injury. It is usually accompanied by a severe headache, bradycardia, and facial flushing, along with pallor, cold skin, and sweating in the lower part of the body. This patient is likely to have a blocked Foley's catheter, which can cause bladder distension.

Complications of this condition include intracranial vasospasm or hemorrhage, cardiac arrhythmia, and death.

It is treated with vasodilators to manage acute BP elevation. Clonidine is prophylactically used to reduce hypertension resulting from bladder stimulation.

questions.text: A child presented to emergency with sudden onset of chest tightness, dyspnea, and wheezing while playing with a neighbor's dog. Which of the following is the predominant pathway of inflammation in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of sudden-onset breathlessness on coming into contact with a pet is suggestive of an acute attack of atopic asthma. The predominant pathway of inflammation in this condition is Th2-mediated IgE response mediated by IL-4: Th-2 cell → IL-4 → IgE (option D).

Bronchial asthma is a chronic airway inflammatory disease causing expiratory airflow obstruction that produces symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough. 

The most common form is atopic asthma, which is triggered by exposure to environmental allergens in genetically predisposed individuals. It is caused by a Th2-mediated IgE response. Th2 cells secrete cytokines that promote inflammation by the following mechanisms:

  • IL-4 stimulates the production of IgE
  • IL-5 activates locally recruited eosinophils
  • IL-13 stimulates mucus secretion from bronchial submucosal glands and promotes IgE production by B cells.

Th17 cells contribute by recruiting neutrophils.

Related Pearl: T Helper cells- Types and functions

IFN-γ

IL-4, IL-5, IL-13

IL-17, IL-22

questions.text:
Match the following skin lesions as primary or secondary skin lesions.

A- Primary skin lesion

B- Secondary skin lesion
questions.solution:
The correct option is option C:1-A, 2-B, 3-A, 4-A.
 
Primary lesion is one which is directly related to the disease process. The secondary lesion evolves from the primary lesion. Macules, papules (or plaques), nodules, tumors, wheals, vesicles, bullae, and pustules are primary lesions. Scales, crusts, erosions, ulcers, fissures, and scars are secondary lesions.
 
Image 1

Papule is a primary skin lesion. It is an elevated solid lesion that is less than 1 cm in diameter. The only distinction between a papule and a nodule is the size (nodule >1 cm). 

 

Image 2

Crusts are secondary skin lesions. It consists of dried serum, blood, or pus mixed with epithelial and bacterial debris.

 

Image 3

Pustule is a primary skin lesion. A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. They develop from papules or vesicles or may originate as pustules.

 

Image 4

Purpura presents as a papule, which is a primary skin lesion.

Purpura occurs due to small bleeds from blood vessels into the surrounding skin or mucus membranes. These lesions are initially bright red, then progress to purple, and finally become yellow-brown, before disappearing.

Related Pearl: Primary and Secondary Lesions of Skin

Primary lesions of the skin include:

  • Papule
  • Plaque
  • Wheal
  • Vesicle
  • Bulla
  • Nodule
  • Macule
  • Patch
  • Purpura
  • Pustule

For mnemonic lovers, the following mnemonic might help!

'Predatory Poisonous Wasps Viciously Bit on the Nose of My Patient causing Purulent Pus'

 

Secondary lesions of the skin include:

Mnemonic- 'LEAF SUCKS water'

  • L — Lichenification
  • E — Erosion / Excoriation
  • A — Atrophy
  • F — Fissure
  • S — Scale
  • U — Ulcer
  • C — Crust
  • K — Kind-of-hard to feel (Induration)
  • S — Scar

questions.text:
The lipid profile of a 48-year-old hypertensive male patient is given below. Which of the following antihypertensives would have a beneficial effect on his lipid profile?

Total cholesterol - 320 mg/dL

Low-density lipoproteins - 220 mg/dL

High-density lipoproteins- 40 mg/dL

Triglycerides - 299 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient in the given scenario has a deranged lipid profile. Among the given drugs, prazosin would have a beneficial effect on the lipid profile of this patient as it decreases LDL and triglyceride levels as well as increases HDL levels.

Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 antagonist. It acts by blocking the alpha-1 receptors in the arterioles and veins, thereby decreasing peripheral vascular resistance. It has little or no alpha-2 blocking effect.

Uses:

  • Hypertension
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • In vasospastic disorders like Raynaud's disease

Adverse effects: First-dose phenomenon: Within 30-90 minutes of the initial dose of prazosin or when the dosage is increased, there is marked orthostatic hypotension or syncope. This is known as the first-dose phenomenon. After a few initial doses, tolerance develops to this side effect. Initiating low doses at bedtime is recommended to minimize this phenomenon. Orthostatic hypotension can be a problem with long-term therapy. Other side effects are headache, dizziness, and asthenia.

Other options:

Options A and D- Furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide are diuretics, and they cause derangement of lipid profile.

Option C- Propranolol, being a non-selective beta-blocker, causes derangement of the lipid profile. The release of free fatty acids from the adipose tissue is attenuated in the presence of a non-selective beta-blocker. Non-selective receptor antagonists raise triglycerides, lower HDL cholesterol, and raise LDL cholesterol.

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The peripheral smear done is as shown below, and the Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What diagnosis would this signify in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and peripheral blood smear showing target cells and aniso-poikilocytosis, along with the Mentzer index of less than 13, are suggestive of thalassemia.

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia.

β-Thalassemia arises due to the deficient synthesis of β-chains. Normal adult RBCs have HbA, along with HbA2 and fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in small amounts. There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. 

α-Thalassemia is caused by deficient synthesis of α-chains. It can also present as an α-thalassemia trait, with trivial hematologic abnormalities. Excess of β- and γ-globin chains form Bart hemoglobin (γ4) in fetal life and HbH (β4) after birth. Severe deficiency leads to hydrops fetalis.

Ineffective erythropoiesis leads to bone marrow hyperplasia and extramedullary hematopoiesis, which can involve the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. In β-thalassemia major, anemia manifests 6 to 9 months after birth. HbF levels are markedly elevated. The presence of bony anomalies such as frontal bossing, prominent facial bones, and dental malocclusion is typical.

The image below shows thalassemic facies (frontal bossing and maxillary hyperplasia) in a child with thalassemia major. 

Laboratory findings: Infants with severe β-thalassemia diseases experience increasing anemia following the newborn stage. The RBCs exhibit microcytosis, hypochromia, and target cells. Usually observed are nucleated RBCs, a distinct anisopoikilocytosis, and relative reticulocytopenia. Without transfusions, the Hb level frequently drops to 6 g/dL in a gradual manner.

MCV/RBC count also known as the Mentzer index can be used to distinguish thalassemia trait from iron-deficiency anemia. A Mentzer index of more than 13 is suggestive of iron-deficiency anemia while a value less than 13 points to the β-thalassemia trait. 

Prior to the initial blood transfusion, a high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) sample must be provided to confirm the diagnosis of thalassemia, which is indicated by the absence of HbA and high levels of HbF.

Other options:

Option A: Glossitis, stomatitis, darkening of the skin on the knuckles and terminal phalanges, and enlargement of the liver and spleen are characteristics of megaloblastic anemia. Peripheral smear in megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils (shown below).

Option B: Iron-deficiency anemia has a Mentzer index of more than 13. Peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia along with target cells.

Option D: Megaloblastic anemia has a particular subtype called pernicious anemia. It is caused by insufficient vitamin B12 absorption through the gastrointestinal pathway, leading to vitamin B12 insufficiency. Macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils are frequent observations in the peripheral smear associated with megaloblastic anemia. Neutrophil hypersegmentation is an early symptom of the disease and typically occurs beyond 3 to 5 lobes.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease

Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with the passage of blood-colored urine, pain during micturition, and increased frequency of urination for the last 2 days. After further investigations, he is diagnosed with acute hemorrhagic cystitis caused by adenovirus. Which of the following characteristics correctly describes this causative agent?
questions.solution:
This is a case of acute hemorrhagic cystitis, which is caused by adenovirus—a naked double-stranded DNA virus. 

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis is a viral urinary tract infection. It presents with cystitis and gross hematuria. 

Adenovirus types 7, 11, 34, and 35 are the common serotypes associated with this disease and can be recovered from the blood and urine of patients with hemorrhagic cystitis. 

Other illnesses caused by adenoviruses include

  • Respiratory tract - Tonsillitis, pharyngitis, pneumonia
  • Eyes - Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Gastrointestinal tract - Acute viral gastroenteritis 
  • Urinary tract - Acute hemorrhagic cystitis 

Related Pearl: Enveloped and non-enveloped viruses

questions.text: Which of the following infants would not be considered high risk as per the NACO guidelines?

choices.text: An infant born to HIV-positive mother who is not on ART
An infant born to a mother with maternal viral load not done after 32 weeks of pregnancy
An infant born to a mother with maternal viral load not suppressed after 32 weeks of pregnancy
An infant born to a mother who is newly identified as HIV-positive 11 weeks after delivery

questions.solution:
An infant born to a mother who is newly identified as HIV-positive within 6 weeks of delivery should be considered as high risk, as per the NACO guidelines.

 High-risk infants include

  • infants born to HIV-positive mothers who are not on ART
  • maternal viral load not done after 32 weeks of pregnancy
  • maternal viral load not suppressed after 32 weeks of pregnancy
  • mother is newly identified HIV-positive within 6 weeks of delivery

Low-risk infants are infants born to mothers with suppressed viral load (<1000 copies/mL) done any time after 32 weeks of pregnancy up to delivery

According to the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO), antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be given to all pregnant women, including during labor hours and breastfeeding. They are started on a triple-drug ART. ART should be given irrespective of the CD4 count and clinical stage, and treatment should be continued lifelong.

Immediate care of HIV-exposed infants includes wiping of baby's mouth and nostrils, handling of infants with gloves, immediate cord clamping, and initiation of feeding. An infant born to an HIV-positive mother should be breastfed exclusively or by replacement feeds exclusively for 6 months of age.

Infants should receive ARV prophylaxis. A single drug or dual drug regimen is followed depending on the risk of transmission, which can be low or high risk.

  • Low-risk infants are those born to mothers with a low viral load which is detected after 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery. 
  • High-risk infants are those born to HIV-positive mothers, not on ART, with viral load not estimated beyond 32 weeks, viral load not suppressed after 32 weeks, or diagnosed with HIV within 6 weeks of delivery.
HIV Risk  ARV prophylaxis Duration
Low-risk infants Syrup nevirapine or Syrup zidovudine

 Birth to 6 weeks of age irrespective of feeding 
High-risk infants Syrup nevirapine + syrup zidovudine

If exclusive replacement feeding: Birth to 6 weeks

If exclusive breastfeeding: Birth till 12 weeks

questions.text: An infant is brought with the following lesion on the scalp. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows cup‐shaped crusts/scutula around hair follicles, which is suggestive of favus.

Kerion is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis. The most common causative organisms of kerion are Trichophyton verrucosum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation. It presents as an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair.

Note: Scarring alopecia is seen in favus and kerion while non-scarring alopecia is seen in ectothrix and endothrix.

Ectothrix is a mild inflammatory type in which dull grey-coated broken hairs are seen.

Endothrix is a non-inflammatory type in which black dots form around swollen hair shafts. 

Tinea capitis is of four types: 

Type of Infection  Causative fungus 
Endothrix (infection inside shaft)
  • Trichophyton tonsurans
  • T. violaceum
  • T. schoenleinii
  • T. yaoundei
  • T. soudanense
Ectothrix (infection outside shaft)
  • Microsporum audouinii
  • M.canis
  • M.equinum
  • M.ferrugineum
Favus 
  • T. schoenleinii
Kerion 
  • T. verrucosum
  • T. mentagrophytes

Other Options:

Option D: Seborrheic dermatitis, or cradle cap in infants, presents with greasy, yellow scales, often without hair loss. Below is an image of the same.

questions.text: A 21-year-old college student is brought to the doctor by his family because he was repeatedly caught trying to peep into female dressing rooms. He says that he derives sexual pleasure from this act of observing women getting undressed. What is this type of perversion called?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a person deriving sexual pleasure by observing women getting undressed is highly suggestive of scoptophilia.

Scoptophilia, or voyeurism, is a type of sexual perversion where the person derives sexual pleasure by observing unsuspecting victims while they are naked, getting dressed, or engaging in sexual activity. A person who frequently has such cravings or behaviours is known as a voyeur/peeping Tom.

The victim is typically a total stranger. Sexual pleasure is typically derived from masturbation, either while witnessing the act or later when one remembers the incident. This kind of perversion usually occurs in the case of severe sociopathic personality disorder.

Other options:

Option A: Frotteurism refers to the sexual gratification achieved by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person. This behaviour often occurs in busy and crowded places. It is predominantly described in men.

Option C: Exhibitionism is the urge to expose genitals to a stranger or unsuspecting person.

Option D: Algolagnia is sexual pleasure derived from inflicting pain (active algolagnia) or enduring pain (passive algolagnia).

questions.text: What is the ideal retention period for the method of excreta disposal shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a septic tank, it’s a water-tight tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment. The ideal retention period for septic tank is 24hrs.

Capacity of 20-30 gallons per person is recommended for household septic tanks. Length of the tank is twice the breadth.

Minimum air-space of 30cm should be there between the level of liquid in the tank and under-surface of the cover.

questions.text: Which of the following remains unaffected in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The respiratory rate remains unaffected during pregnancy.

Changes in respiratory physiology occurring during pregnancy:

Parameters that increase:

  • Tidal volume
  • Inspiratory capacity
  • Minute ventilation

Parameters that decrease:

  • Functional residual capacity
  • Expiratory reserve volume
  • Residual volume
  • Total lung capacity

Parameters that remain unaffected:

  • Respiratory rate
  • Vital capacity
  • Inspiratory reserve volume

Functional residual capacity and residual volume decrease progressively during pregnancy due to the elevation of the diaphragm. Airway conductance is increased and total pulmonary resistance reduced, possibly as a result of progesterone.

(Mnemonic: TIM increases in pregnancy)

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

∼1.2 L

questions.text: Which of the following cell-in-cell structures represents entosis?

choices.text: Natural killer cell in tumor cell
Epithelial cell in another epithelial cell

questions.solution:
An epithelial cell in another epithelial cell is a cell-in-cell structure that represents entosis.

Entosis is a type of homotypic invasion where a cell of one type enters another cell of the same type, resulting in a cell-in-cell structure. A typical example is the invasion of an epithelial cell into the cytoplasm of another epithelial cell. Entosis represents suicidal but non-apoptotic cell death, which is different from apoptosis or other types of programmed cell death. 

The host cell forms a vacuole around the inner cell, which deforms its own organelles, including the nucleus. The inner cell can survive in the host cell for 12 hours or longer and is eventually digested by the outer cell via an autophagosomal mechanism or escape from the outer cell. It differs from the endocytic (phagocytosis/ pinocytosis) type of cell death where the outer cell actively engulfs the inner cell. 

Other options:

Option A: Neutrophil in megakaryocyte is an example of emperipolesis, a cell-in-cell structure in which a leukocyte is the inner cell. It usually involves immune cells but is also observed in tumor cells.

Option B: Natural killer cell in tumor cell is an example of emperitosis, a type of emperipolesis in which the invading immune cell is cytotoxic.

Option C: T lymphocyte in hepatocyte is an example of enclysis. It is a type of endocytic process (outer cell engulfs the inner cell) where CD4+ T lymphocytes are engulfed by hepatocytes.

questions.text: A man presents with headache, fever, and neck stiffness for the last 1 month. On examination, the sign shown in the image below is positive. CSF analysis reveals lymphocytic predominance with low glucose levels. A cobweb coagulum is formed when CSF is left standing. What is the therapy of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The scenario of a positive Kernig's sign, as shown in the image, and CSF analysis findings of lymphocytic predominance with low glucose level and cobweb formation suggest tubercular meningitis. The therapy of choice for this patient is isoniazid + rifampin + pyrazinamide+ ethambutol. 

Kernig's sign is elicited with the patient in supine position. The thigh and knee are flexed over the abdomen. The examiner then tries to passively extend the knee joint. There is severe pain during extension due to meningeal irritation.

Tubercular meningitis is a type of subacute meningitis. It is caused due to the hematogenous dissemination of the bacilli into the brain parenchyma. These bacilli form tubercles. The tubercles undergo caseating necrosis and release the tubercular antigens in the subarachnoid space, leading to inflammation of the meninges. They predominantly involve the basal portion of the brain.

Symptoms include headache, neck stiffness, features of cranial nerve palsies such as facial weakness, downward and outward positioning of the eyes, diminished vision, double vision, and hearing loss. Signs include papilledema, Kernig's sign, and Brudzinki's sign of meningeal irritation.

It is treated with fixed-dose combinations of isoniazid (5 mg/kg/d), rifampin (10 mg/kg/d), pyrazinamide (30 mg/kg/d), ethambutol (15 mg/kg/d), and pyridoxine (50 mg/d) for a period of 6 months. It can be extended by 3-6 months in cases of tubercular meningitis. Also, in HIV-negative patients with TB meningitis, dexamethasone (12–16 mg/d) is recommended for 6 weeks. In India, tuberculosis is managed with a fixed-dose combination and daily dosing of medications.

Other options:

Option B: Ceftriaxone + vancomycin is the initial treatment of choice for acute meningitis due to Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Option C: Ampicillin is the treatment of choice for meningitis due to Listeria monocytogenes and is given for at least 3 weeks.

Option D: Liposomal amphotericin B + flucytosine is used for chronic meningitis due to Cryptococcus neoformans (in patients with no immunosuppression).

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of seizures. On examination, she has a port-wine stain on her face. CT scan showed characteristic tram-track calcifications in the cerebral cortex. Which of the following is not an ocular finding commonly associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome. Optic nerve glioma is not an ocular finding associated with the Sturge-Weber syndrome, it is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. 

The characteristic features of Sturge-Weber syndrome include port-wine stain on the face, a history of seizures, and tram-track calcifications in the cerebral cortex. The ocular findings commonly associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome are choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia, and ipsilateral glaucoma.

Important ocular manifestations in neurofibromatosis type 1 include:

  • Eyelid plexiform neurofibroma- S-shaped deformity of the upper lid, with a 'bag of worms' like texture.
  • Optic nerve glioma - A pilocytic astrocytoma that typically occurs in young children.
  • Bilateral Lisch nodules are hamartomas that develop during the second–third decades.
  • Spheno-orbital encephalocele - due to dysplasia of the greater wing of the sphenoid

The various neurocutaneous syndromes and their ocular manifestations are as follows:

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with a 6-month history of a non-healing genital ulcer. Examination revealed a solitary ulcer measuring 3cm x 2cm on the labia majora. No lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy revealed nests of malignant squamous epithelium with prominent central keratin pearls surrounded by a chronic inflammatory infiltrate. Which of the following is not considered a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of squamous carcinoma of the vulva, and HPV 11 infection is not considered a risk factor.

Infection with HPV types 16, 18, 31, 33, and 45 are known to be associated with the risk of the development of vulvar carcinoma. HPV 16 infection is the most common. HPV 6 and 11 cause most cases of genital warts but are seldom linked to cancer and are known as low-risk HPV.

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most frequent vulvar carcinoma, followed by malignant melanoma. Patients present with pruritis and a visible lesion that may be ulcerated, bleeding, warty, raised, or pigmented. There may be other clinical entities, such as preinvasive neoplasia (vulval intraepithelial neoplasia - VIN), infection, chronic inflammatory disease, and granulomatous disease.

On histopathological examination, the tumor shows classic features of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, such as squamous cells, intercellular bridges, and eosinophilic keratin pearls. Nests of invasive tumor cells are surrounded by chronic inflammation.

Risk factors for vulvar carcinoma: 

  • Age: The risk of vulvar cancer increases with age; the highest incidence is seen in women over 70 years of age.
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV)- HPV 16 is the most commonly associated type, but HPV types 18, 31, 33, and 45 are also known risk factors.
  • HSV infection (usually in a smoker)
  • Smoking
  • Chronic immunosuppression - HIV infection, transplantation patients
  • Lichen sclerosus- chronic vulvar inflammatory disease and can be considered a precursor lesion, usually in older women
  • Other genital cancers: Women with cervical cancer might have a higher risk of vulvar cancer  
  • Progression from VIN

The images below show Stages IA, IB, 2, 3, 4A, and 4B of vulvar carcinoma in order:

Related Pearl: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

 

Related Pearl: Staging of Vulval Cancer (FIGO)

Stage Features
I Tumor confined to vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm , confined to the vulva or perineum, with negative nodes
II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with negative nodes
III Tumor of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IIIA i) With 1 lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm) or,
  ii)1-2 lymph node micrometastases(<5mm)
IIIB i) With 2 or more lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm), or
  ii) 3 or more lymph node micrometastases (<5 mm)
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread
IV Tumor invades other regional structures (upper 2/3rd urethra, upper 2/3rd vagina) or distant structures
IVA Tumour invades any of the following:
  i) Upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  ii) Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IVB Any distant metastasis including pelvic lymph nodes

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in the right knee for the past few months. On examination, there is tenderness in the affected part with a reduced range of motion. A radiographic study revealed a solitary lytic lesion at the distal end of the femur and the microscopic appearance of the lesion is shown below. Which of the following is not an x-ray finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and microscopic appearance are suggestive of osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor and they are purely radiolucent.

Microscopically they are composed of mononuclear cells with macrophages. They are more common between the age of 20-40 and typically affect the metaphyses of long bones with a preponderance for the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius and proximal humerus.

Important X-ray features of a GCT:

  • A solitary, possibly lobulated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Eccentric location, most often subchondral
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex
  • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance
  • No calcification within the tumor
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

 

 

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like distal ulna, clavicle, proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

questions.text: A study is done to identify the association between the COVID-19 vaccine and developing severe COVID-19 disease. The scientists collected data from 2 groups of 1000 individuals each, sampled based on vaccinated and unvaccinated status. These individuals were followed up to look for the development of severe disease. Which of the following would be the best parameter to find the association?
questions.solution:
In this study, the sample population is classified on the basis of exposure (vaccinated) and non-exposure (unvaccinated) and it follows the individuals until the development of the disease, which makes it a cohort study. The best parameter to find the association in this cohort study is relative risk.

Relative risk is the ratio of the incidence of disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed. It is a direct measure of the strength of the association between suspected cause and effect in a cohort study. 

Other options:

Option A: The incidence rate is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time. It is not a measure of the strength of the association in cohort studies.

Option B: Prevalence refers specifically to all current cases (old and new) existing at a given point in time. It is also not a measure of the strength of the association in cohort studies.

Option C: The odds ratio, also known as a cross-product ratio, is used to measure the strength of the association between risk factors and outcomes in case-control studies. A case-control study categorizes the population into cases (having disease/exposure) and controls (not having disease/exposure).

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: Which of the following tumor markers is least useful in assessing dysgerminoma?
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is not a useful marker for dysgerminoma; it is a marker for endodermal sinus tumors. Dysgerminoma secretes placental alkaline phosphatase, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG.

Dysgerminoma is a type of germ cell tumor corresponding to the testis's seminoma. It does not secrete either male or female sex hormones. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is usually used to monitor these patients for disease recurrence.

Endodermal sinus tumor/ Yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen in premenarchal girls. Schiller-Duval bodies are pathognomonic in histopathology. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is commonly produced by this tumor and is used as a tumor marker.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text:
A patient presents to you with a 25-day history of hearing voices that ask him to jump from the 10th floor of his building. He has a labile mood. On further probing, he reveals that he had lost his mother a month back in an accident that happened before his eyes. Which of the following statements is true for his condition?
  1. The diagnosis is schizophrenia
  2. His condition is likely to be brief psychotic disorder
  3. Complete remission usually occurs
  4. Negative symptoms are part of the diagnostic criteria
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with auditory hallucinations in a patient with a history of witnessing a traumatic event is highly suggestive of the diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder.

For a diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder, the symptoms should have lasted for at least a day but less than a month. It should not be associated with a mood disorder, substance abuse disorder, or psychotic disorder due to an underlying medical condition. It may also occur following a traumatic life event. It is commonly seen in women, young people, and those with existing personality disorders. The criteria for diagnosis is the same as that for schizophrenia but without negative symptoms.

Clinical features include delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized speech. At least one of these symptoms of psychosis is required for diagnosis. Other signs like disorganized or catatonic behavior, emotional volatility, bizarre behavior, and screaming may also be seen.

Brief psychotic disorder is classified into the following subtypes:

  • After a stressor
  • Without a stressor
  • Postpartum onset

The diagnosis is usually retrospective, as the diagnosis requires complete remission of symptoms, which usually occurs in a month. There is an eventual complete return to the premorbid level of functioning.

Management includes hospitalization and psychotherapy. The involvement of the family is also recommended. Antipsychotics and benzodiazepines are also used.

Schizophrenia is a disorder characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms, and catatonic behavior. At least two of the first three symptoms should be present for a duration of one month. Continuous signs of disturbance should be seen for at least 6 months.

questions.text:
A 1-week-old infant with ambiguous genitalia presents with hypertension. The infant is diagnosed with congenital adrenal hyperplasia with 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. Which of the following findings will you see in this infant?

(ACTH- Adrenocorticotrophic hormone)
questions.solution:
Decreased androgen levels are seen in congenital adrenal hyperplasia with 17α-hydroxylase enzyme deficiency.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is an autosomal recessive disorder where adrenal steroid hormone synthesis is affected. There are many variants of CAH depending on enzyme deficiency. The most common enzyme deficiency is the 21-hydroxylase enzyme. 

Given below is the pathway and enzymes involved in adrenal steroid synthesis:

In the above image, we understand that 17 alpha-hydroxylase is required for the conversion of pregnenolone to 17 hydroxy pregnenolone and progesterone to 17 hydroxy progesterone. Pregnenolone and progesterone are further converted to cortisol and androgens. Therefore deficiency of this enzyme will lead to reduced levels of cortisol and androgens. The accumulated pregnenolone and progesterone lead to increased synthesis of aldosterone.

Patience will present with ambiguous genitalia due to a deficiency of androgens. Excessive aldosterone will lead to increased sodium retention, hypertension, and hypokalemia. Cortisol deficiency stimulates the pituitary and increases ACTH secretion, leading to adrenocortical hyperplasia. The ability to synthesize corticosterone from its precursor deoxycorticosterone is preserved in these patients.

Treatment:

  • It includes glucocorticoid replacement with hydrocortisone to control hypertension by suppressing deoxycorticosterone synthesis. 
  • Removal of intra-abdominal testes or orchidopexy to prevent malignant transformation and appropriate sex hormone replacement therapy at puberty depends on the sex of rearing.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency 11β-hydroxylase deficiency 3β-HSD deficiency

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

 ↑ in aldosterone ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone  ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Sestamibi scan is the imaging of choice for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism.

Sestamibi is a monovalent lipophilic cation. It shows passive diffusion across cell membranes and accumulates in mitochondria. Because of its accumulation in the mitochondria, there is a difference in the rate at which it gets washed out depending on the number of mitochondria in each tissue. 

In parathyroid adenomas, there is a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content.

The three protocols for sestamibi scanning:

  • Single-isotope dual-phase scan
  • Dual-isotope subtraction imaging
  • Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT)

SPECT is commonly used because of its improved spatial resolution. Sestamibi combined with CT can be used to detect smaller parathyroid tissues. It can also detect ectopic glands in the mediastinum or in the deeper cervical region.

Other imaging modalities for parathyroid localization:

  • Ultrasonography:
    • It is inexpensive and noninvasive.
    • Mediastinal parathyroid tissue cannot be detected because USG cannot penetrate the sternum or clavicles.
  • Four-dimensional CT: 
    • It has a very high sensitivity. 
    • Increased radiation exposure and use of contrast are potential disadvantages.
  • Selective venous sampling for PTH:
    • It can be used for the exact localization of adenomas.

questions.text: A man presents with pain behind the right ear. He had recurrent episodes of suppurative otitis media. The area behind his right ear is erythematic and tender. An x-ray confirms the diagnosis of cholesteatoma. Surgery is planned and the following instrument is used. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Mollison mastoid retractor. It is self-retaining and hemostatic. It is used in mastoidectomy after incision and elevation of flaps to retract soft tissues. 

Jansen self-retaining mastoid retractor is also used in mastoidectomy and is similar to Mollison retractor.

 

Joll retractor (shown below) is a self-retaining retractor used in thyroid surgery.

 

Lempert’s endaural retractor - Used for endaural approach. Two lateral blades retract the flaps and a third central blade with holes retracts the temporalis muscle. The body of the retractor can be fixed to the central blade by its hole.

questions.text: An outbreak of Zika virus infection was reported by the WHO. Which of the following is not a mode of transmission of this virus?
questions.solution:
Zika virus is not transmitted through respiratory droplets.

Zika virus (RNA virus) is a flavivirus transmitted primarily by infected mosquitoes of the Aedes genus, mainly the Aedes aegypti.

Other modes of transmission include 

  • Materno-fetal or intrauterine transmission
  • Sexual intercourse, due to the exchange of body fluids
  • Blood/blood products transfusion
  • Organ transplantation is also a potential mode of transmission of Zika virus

The majority of the people infected with this virus are asymptomatic. Few develop mild symptoms like fever, conjunctivitis, rash, myalgia, arthralgia, malaise, and headache. It has been reported to trigger Guillain-Barre syndrome, myelitis, and encephalitis in older children and adults.

Zika virus infection during pregnancy is known to cause congenital Zika syndrome, a condition characterized by severe defects in the newborn, including microcephaly. The image below shows various modes of transmission of the Zika virus.

 

There is no specific treatment available for this disease. Adequate hydration and rest are advised, along with analgesics and antipyretics for pain and fever.

questions.text: Hemoglobin levels were measured in 200 pregnant women. The results showed a mean hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL with a standard deviation of 0.5 g/dL. Assuming that the distribution is normal, how many women will have hemoglobin levels <9.5 g/dL?
questions.solution:
In the given population, 5 women will have hemoglobin (Hb) levels < 9.5 g/dL.

In a normal distribution, the distribution of values around the mean is as follows:

  • 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 SD of the mean. 
  • 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 SD of the mean. 
  • 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 SD of the mean.

In a normal distribution, 2 SD from the mean will have 95% of the participants. Therefore, 95% of pregnant women will have Hb levels of 10.5±2*0.5 = 10.5±1 =  9.5-11.5 g/dL.

The remaining 2.5% of women will have Hb >11.5 g/dL and 2.5% of women will have Hb level <9.5 g/dL.

2.5% of 200 = 5. Hence, 5 women will have Hb of <9.5 g/dL.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: Which of the following patients would you diagnose with hypertensive emergency?

choices.text: 50-year-old man with a blood pressure of 162/104 mmHg with no other complaints
47-year-old hypertensive, not responding to treatment with enalapril, thiazide, and beta blockers
55-year-old woman with a blood pressure of 200/140 mmHg with papilledema
60-year-old man with a blood pressure of 188/120 mmHg without any target organ damage

questions.solution:
Patient 3 has a BP of >180/110 mmHg along with papilledema. This is a case of severe hypertension associated with fundoscopic changes (flame hemorrhages, papilledema), which is suggestive of malignant hypertension.

Microangiopathy, DIC, and encephalopathy may also be present. Fibrinoid necrosis of arterioles and small arteries is seen. 

Option A: This patient suffers from hypertension. Since BP <180/110 mmHg, it is not hypertensive urgency or emergency.

Option B: The patient has a blood pressure of >140/90 mmHg despite taking three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic. This is a case of resistant hypertension, and it is more common in patients aged >60 years than in younger patients. Resistant hypertension may be related to pseudo hypertension (high office blood pressure and lower home blood pressure), nonadherence to therapy, and identifiable causes of hypertension including obesity and excessive alcohol intake.

Option D: The patient has BP >180/110 mmHg and no end-organ damage. This is a case of hypertensive urgency. Target organ damage is absent in hypertensive urgency but is present in a hypertensive emergency. 

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) 2019 guidelines for hypertension management

According to the AHA hypertension guidelines, 2019, pharmacologic treatment for hypertension is recommended

  • In patients who have ≥10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk, when BP ≥ 130/80 mmHg 
  • In patients who have <10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk when BP ≥ 140/90 mmHg

ASCVD risk is calculated using a calculator provided by the American Heart Association.

2. Dietary sodium restriction

  • Total NaCl (salt) intake - <6g/day

3. Enhanced potassium intake 3.5 - 5g/day -4/5 mmHg
4. DASH dietary pattern  high in vegetables, fruits, low-fat dairy products, whole grains, poultry, fish, and nuts and low in sweets, sugar-sweetened beverages, red meats, and saturated and total fat. -11 mmHg

questions.text: A final-year student is asked to assess the motor functions of a hemiplegic patient. He asks the patient to dorsiflex and invert both his feet. Which of the muscles marked in the given image performs both these movements?
questions.solution:
The tibialis anterior, which is marked as "4" in the image, produces both dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot. It is identified as the muscle that lies immediately adjacent to the tibia and is the most medial muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. 

Tibialis anterior:

Origin - Lateral condyle and lateral surface of the tibial shaft, anterior surface of the interosseous membrane, the deep surface of the deep fascia, and the intermuscular septum between itself and extensor digitorum longus

Insertion - Medial and inferior surface of the medial cuneiform and adjoining part of the base of the first metatarsal.

Nerve supply - It is innervated by the deep fibular nerve, L4 and L5

Actions - Dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot. The muscle is most active during activities in which both these movements are combined, such as walking.

Other options:

Option A: According to electromyographic research, the fibularis tertius or peroneus tertius works with the extensor digitorum longus and tibialis anterior to produce dorsiflexion of the foot and along with fibularis brevis to produce eversion of the foot.

Option B: The lateral four toes are extended by the extensor digitorum longus. It is an ankle dorsiflexor that synergistically acts with the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, and fibularis tertius. It aids in tightening the plantar aponeurosis by working with the extensor hallucis longus.

Option C: Extensor hallucis longus dorsiflexes the foot and extends the great toe.

The dorsiflexors of the foot are shown in the image given below:

The plantar flexors of the foot are shown in the image given below:
