questions.text: A 20-year-old man sustains burns in a house fire. On examination, the medical officer concludes that he has deep second-degree burns over his back and bilateral legs. Which of the following best describes the patient's burns?

choices.text: Extends through most of the dermis with intact capillary refill
Extends through most of the dermis with loss of capillary refill
Extends completely through dermis with loss of capillary refill
Extends completely through dermis with intact capillary refill

questions.solution:
Deep second-degree burns involve the epidermis and the reticular dermis and have no capillary refill or the skin does not blanch on pressure.

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First-degree burns (superficial burns): In this, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (partial-thickness burns): In this, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided into superficial or deep:
    • Superficial partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched.
    • Deep partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and most of the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and some sensation is preserved. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure.
  • Third-degree burns (full-thickness burns): In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis, entire dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard, leathery feel, with the absence of sensation.

 

Related Pearl: Degrees of Burns

  First-degree Second-degree (superficial partial thickness) Second-degree (deep partial thickness)

Third-degree (full thickness)

 Fourth-degree (full thickness)
Depth Epidermis Epidermis + superficial dermis Epidermis + most of the dermis (most skin appendages destroyed) Entire dermis + subcutaneous tissue Involves connective tissue, muscle, possibly bone
Colour/texture Red Red, edematous, and blistered Pale, mottled Hard, leathery Pale, dry, charred
Blanchable (capillary refill)  Yes Yes No No No
Pain Painful Painful Painful (only on pinprick) No No
Healing 5-10 days; no scar 10-14 days; no or minimal scar  4-8 weeks, often with scarring and contractures Prolonged, with scarring and contractures, requires skin grafting Requires skin grafting or even amputation.

questions.text:
A couple presented to the infertility clinic as they have been unable to conceive for more than a year. The lady has no abnormalities in her laboratory reports. The semen analysis report of her husband is given below. Which of the following findings indicates a diagnosis of asthenospermia?

Appearance: Opalescent
Volume: 2 mL
pH: 7.5
Fructose: present
Sperm concentration: 14 million/mL
Morphology: 35% normal
Motility: 20% motile
No sperm agglutination was seen.
questions.solution:
The semen analysis finding of 20% motility (option B) indicates a diagnosis of asthenospermia.

Asthenospermia refers to decreased sperm motility. Normally, at least 50% of them should show progressive motility. Causes of asthenospermia include prolonged abstinence, anti-sperm antibodies, a genital tract infection, or varicocele.

Various semen abnormalities include:

An acidic pH or lack of fructose: indicates an obstruction in the efferent ductal system.

A low semen volume reflects incomplete specimen collection, short abstinence interval, partial vas deferens obstruction, or retrograde ejaculation.

Oligospermia is defined by a sperm concentration of <15 million/mL, concentrations of <5 million/mL are considered severe oligospermia.

Azoospermia (absence of sperm in semen) occurs due to outflow tract obstruction as a result of congenital absence of vas deferens, infection, vasectomy, or non-obstructive causes like testicular failure.

Teratospermia or teratozoospermia refers to abnormal sperm morphology.

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves provides preganglionic secretomotor innervation to the parotid gland?
questions.solution:
The glossopharyngeal (CN IX) nerve provides preganglionic secretomotor innervation to the parotid gland.

The secretomotor pathway of the parotid has 3 components 

  1. Preganglionic fibers: Originate in the inferior salivary nucleus ⇒ pass through the glossopharyngeal nerve ⇒ tympanic branch⇒ tympanic plexus ⇒ lesser petrosal nerve
  2. Relay: The lesser petrosal nerve relays in the otic ganglion.
  3. Postganglionic fibers: Pass through the auriculotemporal nerve to reach the gland.

Note - The sensory innervation to the parotid gland is also derived from the auriculotemporal nerve. However, the parotid fascia (derived from the investing layer of deep cervical fascia) has sensory innervation from the great auricular nerve (C2, C3). 

Clinical significance - In the event of the removal of the parotid gland (abscess, tumor), secretomotor fibers are prone to injury. Their subsequent regeneration during the healing process may cause them to innervate nearby sweat glands and cutaneous blood vessels. This abundant cross-innovation between the greater auricular nerve and the auriculotemporal nerve leads to Frey syndrome. The patient experiences sweating over the face while chewing or by the smell of the food. 

Related Pearl: Functional components of cranial nerves

  • Preganglionic fibres to ciliary ganglion - GVE
Trochlear: CN-4
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (SO)- GSE
Trigeminal: CN-5
  • Sensation from the face - GSA
  • Motor to 1st arch - Br E (SVE)
Abducent: CN-6
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (lateral rectus)- GSE
Facial: CN-7
  • General sensory from ear - GSA
  • Special (taste) sensation - Br A
  • Motor to 2nd arch - Br E
  • Parasympathetic to submandibular and pterygopalatine ganglia - GVE
Vestibulocochlear: CN-8
  • Hearing/balance - SSA
Glossopharyngeal: CN-9
  • Sensory from pharynx/tongue – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • General sensation from ear – GSA
  • Parasympathetic to otic ganglion - GVE
  • Motor to 3rd arch - Br E
Vagus: CN-10
  • Sensory from ear - GSA
  • Sensory from pharynx/larynx – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • Parasympathetic ganglia in thorax/abdomen - GVE
  • Motor to 4th/6th arch - Br E
Accessory: CN-11

  • Motor to sternocleidomastoid and trapezius - GSE
Hypoglossal: CN-12

abbr.

A - afferent , E - efferent , Br - Branchial (word special (derived from branchial arches) can also be used instead of branchial, but due to confusion with special sensory (carrying special senses) its better avoided), V - Visceral, G - General, CN - cranial nerve,  SO - superior oblique muscle.

questions.text: While examining a patient with 12 weeks of amenorrhea who presented with vomiting and vaginal bleeding, you find that the cervical os is open and that the uterus is 16 weeks in size. The patient also has abnormally high levels of serum β-hCG (>1 lakh mIU/mL). Which of the following is likely to be seen on ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with 12 weeks of amenorrhea, vaginal bleeding, and large-for-date uterus, with abnormally elevated HCG levels points towards a diagnosis of molar pregnancy, and a snowstorm appearance is characteristically seen on ultrasound in such cases. It is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces.

A molar pregnancy occurs due to the fusion of one sperm with an empty ovum or the fusion of 2 sperms simultaneously with an ovum. It may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG. 

Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

  • Complete moles occur due to the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes. In about 90% of the cases, the genetic material of one sperm is duplicated, resulting in a diploid 46,XX karyotype. In the remaining 10% of the cases, the empty egg is fertilized by two sperms, resulting in a diploid karyotype, which is either 46,XX, or 46,XY.
  • Partial moles occur due to the fertilization of an egg with two sperms. The karyotype is usually triploid (69,XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92,XXXY). It is associated with an increased risk of persistent molar disease but is not associated with choriocarcinoma.

The definitive management after diagnosis is suction and evacuation, after making the cervix favorable. 

The given images show the development of hydatiform mole and snowstorm appearance on USG, respectively:

 

Other options:

Option A: Necklace appearance on ultrasound is seen in polycystic ovary disease. Multiple cysts (12 or more) of 2–9 mm size are located peripherally along the surface of the ovary, giving it this appearance. It is shown in the image below:


Option B: Ring-of-fire appearance is seen on color Doppler in ectopic pregnancy on the periphery of the adnexal mass. It is shown in the image below:

 

Option D: Double decidual sac sign on ultrasound is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac. It is shown in the image below:

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked

questions.text: A very tall patient presented to surgery OPD with thyroid swelling. On physical examination, long, slender fingers and toes were noted. A neuroma was present in the buccal mucosa. Laboratory reports reveal elevated calcitonin levels with increased urinary catecholamine excretion. The gene mutation responsible for this syndrome is located on ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of MEN 2B syndrome, which is caused by germline mutations in the RET proto-oncogene located on chromosome 10.

MEN 2B comprises

  • Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC; thyroid swelling with elevated calcitonin),
  • Pheochromocytoma (increased excretion of urinary catecholamines),
  • Oral mucosal neuromas,
  • Marfanoid habitus (a very tall patient who has long, slender fingers and toes suggests marfanoid habitus).

Note:

  • MEN 1 is caused by a germline mutation in the MEN1 gene (menin protein), a tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 11.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text:
Which of the following structures pass through the marked foramen?
  1. Inferior petrosal sinus
  2. Spinal accessory nerve
  3. Vagus nerve
  4. Hypoglossal nerve
  5. Middle meningeal branch of the occipital artery
  6. Deep petrosal nerve
questions.solution:
The marked foramen is the jugular foramen. Option B is the correct answer. The structures passing through it are as follows:

  1. Inferior petrosal sinus
  2. Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery
  3. Glossopharyngeal Nerve - IX
  4. Vagus Nerve - X 
  5. Spinal Accessory Nerve - XI
  6. Sigmoid Sinus continuing as internal jugular vein
  7. Middle meningeal branch of the occipital artery

 The hypoglossal nerve passes via the hypoglossal canal.

The deep petrosal nerve carries postganglionic sympathetic fibers from the pterygopalatine ganglion. It then joins with the greater petrosal nerve to form the nerve of the pterygoid (Vidian) canal.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency room and was diagnosed with an arrhythmia. The duty doctor tried to manage it by performing a carotid sinus massage. A normal pacemaker potential curve is shown in the image below. Identify the change expected to be seen in this curve after carotid sinus massage.
questions.solution:
The change expected to be seen in this patient after carotid sinus massage is a decrease in the slope of phase 4 of the pacemaker potential curve.

Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver that is used to treat arrhythmias by activating the baroreceptor mechanism. The carotid sinus contains baroreceptors that get activated on physical manipulation. This mechanism, via the nucleus tractus solitarius, sends parasympathetic vagal efferents to the heart.

Phases of pacemaker potential:

  • Phase 0- Upstroke. It is due to the influx of Ca2+ ions by the opening of voltage-gated L-type channels.
  • Phase 3- Downstroke. It is due to the efflux of K+ leading to repolarization.
  • Phase 4- Prepotential. Because of ongoing K+ efflux, hyperpolarization sets in. This makes the channel more permeable to Na+ ions and since these Na+ channels are activated during hyperpolarization they are referred to as funny currents (Ih/If). They form the first half of the pre-potential. The second half of prepotential is completed by the opening of the voltage-gated T-type Ca2+ channel.

In the clinical scenario, due to vagal stimulation, the parasympathetic cholinergic fibers to the SAN are stimulated. This leads to a decreased slope of phase 4. This occurs by two mechanisms-

  1. Vagal stimuli→ acetylcholine released→ M2 receptor stimulated→ slowed depolarising effect of funny Na+ (If) channel→ decreased slope. 
  2. Vagal stimuli→ acetylcholine released→ M2 receptor stimulated → decreased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)→ decreased firing of T-type Ca2+ channel → decreased slope.

On the other hand, the response to sympathetic stimuli is that of an increased slope of the pacemaker potential. This effect is mediated by two mechanisms-

  1. Sympathetic stimuli → norepinephrine released → β1 receptor → increased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) → rapid opening of L-type Ca2+ channels → increased slope. 
  2. Sympathetic stimuli → norepinephrine released → increases the depolarising effect of funny Na+ (If) channel→ increased slope. 

The image given below shows the effect of sympathetic and parasympathetic stimuli on the pacemaker potential:

Related Pearl: Pacemaker potential

questions.text: Desmoid tumors are associated with _________.
questions.solution:
Desmoid tumors are associated with colonic polyps.

Desmoid tumor, also known as fibromatosis, aggressive fibromatosis, or desmoid-type fibromatosis, is an uncommon neoplasm that occurs sporadically or as part of an inherited syndrome. It is most notably associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Gardner syndrome, an autosomal dominant syndrome of GI adenomatous polyps or adenocarcinoma, osteomas, and skin and soft tissue tumors.

These tumors arise from fibro-aponeurotic tissue and typically are manifested as a slowly growing mass. They present as firm, non-painful, non-tender masses in the abdominal wall, shoulder, hip and limbs, mesentery, and pelvis. They are also associated with trauma, pregnancy, and oral contraceptive usage.

Magnetic resonance imaging is the preferred modality of imaging for diagnosis.  

Core needle biopsy is required to establish the diagnosis. It reveals well-differentiated bundles of spindle cells with an abundant collagenous matrix. The tumors typically stain positive for β-catenin.

Tumor resection with wide margins is the standard care. Radiation therapy is used as adjuvant therapy after surgical resection.

Tamoxifen and NSAIDs are used as first-line medical therapy. Other systemic treatment options are low-dose chemotherapy, tyrosinase kinase inhibitors, and full-dose chemotherapy. 

Cytotoxic chemotherapy has also been used to treat patients with aggressively growing, symptomatic, or life-threatening desmoid tumors.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text:
Prompt surgical management would be indicated in a patient with Sheehan syndrome if there is _______.
  1. Significant visual loss
  2. Progressive visual loss
  3. Cranial nerve palsy
  4. Hypopituitarism
  5. Loss of consciousness
questions.solution:
Significant or progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness are considered indications for urgent surgical decompression in patients with Sheehan syndrome (option B- 1, 2, 3, or 5).

Pituitary apoplexy is a hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it is called Sheehan syndrome. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk of hemorrhage and infarction. 

Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to a deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to a deficiency of gonadotropins). Because deficiencies of some or all pituitary-responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult, Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years.

The acute presentation of pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency, is characterized by a sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits, and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS hemorrhage, and death.

Other features are:

  • Loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH

Treatment is by hormone replacement: First, glucocorticoids and, later, thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin, and growth hormones are given. If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement, or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out.

questions.text:
Which of the following laboratory findings are seen in von Willebrand disease?
  1. Decreased platelet count
  2. Reduced von Willebrand factor
  3. Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time
  4. Prolonged bleeding time 
  5. Prolonged prothrombin time
questions.solution:
The laboratory findings seen in von Willebrand disease are 2, 3, and 4 (option D):

  • Reduced von Willebrand factor
  • Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time
  • Prolonged bleeding time

von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. It occurs due to quantitative or qualitative defects in the von Willebrand factor (vWF).

vWF is produced by endothelial cells and megakaryocytes. It plays a role in the adhesion of platelets to the endothelium when the blood vessels are injured. It also binds to factor VIII in blood, increasing its half-life. Therefore, vWF is crucial for both platelet plug formation and coagulation cascade.

vWD presents with increased bruising and excessive bleeding from wounds. It also leads to epistaxis and heavy menstrual bleeding.

Patients with vWD have normal platelet counts. However, defective platelet function results in prolonged bleeding time. Deficiency of vWF leads to factor VIII deficiency, resulting in prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) as this assay assesses the function of the intrinsic pathway (factors XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen).

The prothrombin time (PT) assay assesses the function of extrinsic pathways—factors VII, X, V, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen. It is not elevated in vWD.

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

questions.text: A young male patient came to the hospital with complaints of right-sided loin pain. The urine microscopy image is shown below. Which of the following is used in the treatment of these renal calculi?
questions.solution:
Urinary microscopy of the patient shows hexagonal crystals, which are suggestive of cystine stones. D-penicillamine can be used for treating cystine stones.

The basis of using D-penicillamine here is that it reacts with cystine to form a soluble salt that reduces the formation of cystine. It is a potentially toxic drug and should only be used if hydration and alkalinization fail.

Other options:

Option A: Acetohydroxamic acid may be considered for the treatment of struvite stone. It is a urease inhibitor. Urease enzyme generates ammonia from urea, elevating the pH of the urine and favoring the production of triple phosphate stones. However, it has to be used with caution due to the potential side effects.

Option B: Neutral orthophosphates halt the growth of existing oxalate calculi.

Option C: Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, can be used to decrease uric acid production. Hence, it can be used in the treatment of uric acid renal calculi.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A man presents with severe vomiting. Homicidal poisoning is suspected as the vomitus appears luminous and emits a garlicky odor. Which of the following is most likely to be the poisoning agent?
questions.solution:
Luminous vomitus that gives off a garlicky odor is highly suggestive of white/yellow phosphorous poisoning.

White/yellow phosphorous is a waxy and translucent material that becomes luminous in the dark. It has a garlicky odor and taste. It gets oxidized on exposure to air, emits white fumes, and gets ignited at 34°C. It is highly toxic.

It is used in fertilizers, vermin-killers, rodenticides, fireworks, and gunpowder.

Stages of acute poisoning:

First stage: Intake causes severe abdominal discomfort, throat and abdominal pain, extreme thirst, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Excreta and breath have a garlic-like smell. Luminescent feces and vomit are characteristically seen. Skin contact results in second and third-degree burns that are deeply painful and take a long time to heal.

Second stage: This is a 2-3 days symptom-free period.

Third stage: There is hematemesis, enlargement of the liver, jaundice, pruritus, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and nausea. Shock, hepatic failure, injury to the central nervous system, hematemesis, and renal insufficiency are all potential causes of death.

Red phosphorus is characteristically odorless and is non-luminous.

Arsenic and thallium may also be associated with a garlicky odor; they are not characteristically associated with luminous vomitus.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text:
Match the following triage tags with the appropriate traumatic conditions.
Triage tag Condition
1. Black A. Flail chest
2. Red B. Pelvic fracture
3. Green C. Extensive third-degree burns
4. Yellow D. Sprain of the ankle
questions.solution:
The correct option is Option C: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

Triage tag Patient
1. Black C. Extensive third-degree burns
2. Red A. Flail chest
3. Green D. Sprain of the ankle
4. Yellow B. Pelvic fracture

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment.

It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. It provides maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a disaster situation. It lessens the burden on medical facilities.

The internationally accepted four-color coded system is used commonly:

  • Red - First (I) priority; Immediate attention or transfer; Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given early
  • Yellow - Second (II) priority; Urgent, Critical, likely to survive if treatment is given within hours
  • Green - Third (III) Non-urgent; Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
  • Black - Last (0) Unsalvageable; Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text:
Match the syndromes given in column A with the structures involved given in column B. (CN- cranial nerve, CST- corticospinal tract)
Column A Column B
1. Weber syndrome A. CST, medial lemniscus, hypoglossal nerve
2. Medial medullary syndrome B. CN III, ventral midbrain, CST, red nucleus
3. Millard–Gubler syndrome C. CN VIII, CN IX and CST
4. Benedikt syndrome D. CN III, ventral midbrain, CST
  E. CN VI, CN VII, ventral pons
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-A, 3-E, 4-B.

Important syndromes in the brainstem are

Midbrain

  • Weber syndrome- It affects cranial nerve (CN) III, ventral midbrain, and corticospinal tract. Patients will have contralateral hemiplegia and paralysis of the third cranial nerve.
  • Benedikt syndrome- It affects CN III, ventral midbrain, corticospinal tract, and red nucleus. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, third nerve palsy, intention tremor, and cerebellar ataxia.
  • Top of basilar syndrome- It affects occipital lobes, midbrain oculomotor nuclei, cerebral peduncle, medial and temporal lobe, and thalamus. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, cortical blindness, oculomotor deficits, memory difficulty, and contralateral sensory deficit.

Pons

  • Milard Gubler syndrome- It affects CN VI, CN VII, and ventral pons. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, CN VI and CN VII palsies.
  • Clumsy hand syndrome- It affects the corticospinal tract. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, dysarthria, and facial weakness.
  • Foville syndrome- It affects CN VII, ventral pons, and paramedian pontine reticular formation. Patients will have ipsilateral CN VII palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, gaze palsy to the side of the lesion.

Medulla

  • Medial medullary syndrome- It affects the corticospinal tract, medial lemniscus, and hypoglossal nerve. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, loss of position and vibratory sensation, and ipsilateral tongue paresis. 
  • Lateral medullary syndrome- It affects the spinothalamic tract, trigeminal nucleus, cerebellum and inferior cerebellar peduncle, vestibular nuclei, and nucleus ambiguus. Patients will have ataxia, dysphagia, hemisensory loss, facial weakness, and Horner syndrome.

Brown Sequard syndrome is the hemisection of the spinal cord. Patients present with ipsilateral weakness, ipsilateral loss of position sense, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presented with oliguria, hypertension, and facial puffiness for 3 days. The urine is positive for albumin. He had a history of throat infection 2 weeks back. He has been diagnosed with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. On renal biopsy of this patient, what findings will be seen on the following investigations, respectively?

1. Light microscopy

2. Electron microscopy

3. Immunofluorescence

choices.text: 1. Focal proliferation of mesangium,  2. Subepithelial humps,  3. Granular IgG, C3
1. Diffuse proliferation of mesangium,  2. Subepithelial humps,  3. Granular IgG, C3
1. Cresenteric proliferation,  2. No deposits,  3. No immune deposits
1. Diffuse proliferation of mesangium,  2. Subepithelial humps, 3. Linear IgG, C3

questions.solution:
The renal biopsy of a patient with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis will show the following findings (Option B)-

1. Diffuse proliferation of mesangium on light microscopy
2. Subepithelial humps on electron microscopy
3. Granular IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence 

Poststreptococcal GN (PSGN) is uncommon before the age of 3 years and most prevalent in kids between the ages of 5-12 years. The patient typically develops an acute nephritic syndrome 

  • 1 to 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis, or
  • 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma

From asymptomatic microscopic hematuria with normal renal function to gross hematuria with acute renal failure, the severity of kidney involvement varies. Patients may experience different levels of edema, hypertension, and oliguria depending on the extent of the renal involvement.

Laboratory findings: More than 90% of patients see a considerable reduction in serum C3 levels during the acute phase, which lasts 6 to 8 weeks before returning to normal. In order to confirm the diagnosis, evidence of preceding streptococcal infection is required. The antistreptolysin O titer frequently rises following pharyngeal infections. The anti-deoxyribonuclease B level is the most effective single antibody titer to demonstrate cutaneous streptococcal infection.

Microscopic findings in PSGN-
  • Light microscopy- Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial and endothelial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration.
  • Immunofluorescence- Granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and in the mesangium.
  • Electron microscopy- Primarily, subepithelial humps are seen. Subendothelial deposits in early disease stages can be seen.

Below is the image shows enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy:

 

The image below shows granular deposits of IgG and complement C3:

 

The image below shows subepithelial humps:

questions.text:
At an eye camp, a 75-year-old man, who is a chronic smoker and has hypertension and a BMI of 35 kg/m2, presents with complaints of diminishing vision over the past 25 years in the right eye. His visual acuity is 6/36, and the anterior segment appears normal. The OCT image obtained is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

OCT- Optical coherence tomography
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the OCT image showing drusen are suggestive of dry or non-exudative age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Drusen are the earliest visible clinical signs of AMD. They are composed of lipids, amyloid, complement factors, and associated cellular components.

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD), a degenerative disorder of the macula, is characterized by the presence of drusen and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) changes. It is the most common cause of permanent central vision loss in the elderly.

Risk factors:
  • Age
  • White race
  • Family history
  • Smoking
  • Hypertension
  • Cardiovascular diseases
  • Obesity
  • Aspirin intake 

There are two types of ARMD:

  • Dry AMD (non-exudative, non-neovascular) is the most common form, comprising around 90% of the diagnosed cases. It is initially characterized by macular drusens, which later progresses to geographical atrophy. Geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry AMD. 
  • Wet AMD (exudative, neovascular) is much less common than the dry type, but it is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss. It presents with painless progressive visual loss over months, central scotoma, and the fundoscopy showing sub-retinal hemorrhage near the macula (Option D).

Treatment:

Dry AMD: No effective treatment is available. Antioxidants like lutein and zeaxanthin are given as prophylaxis.

Wet AMD: Treatment depends on the location of the choroidal neovascularization membrane.

  • For extrafoveal membrane – laser photocoagulation
  • For subfoveal and juxta foveal treatment options are as follows:
    • Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF
    • Photodynamic therapy – dye used is verteporfin followed by exposure to light from the diode
    • Transpupillary thermotherapy

The image below shows drusens in the macular area in dry macular degeneration:

Option A: Cystoid macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. Patients may complain of blurring, distortion, and micropsia. In clinically established cases, the macula will show a 'honeycomb' appearance on ophthalmoscopy due to multiple cystoid spaces. Optical coherence tomography image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces and foveal depression. In advanced cases, a lamellar macular hole may develop.

Given below is an OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces in CME:

Option B: Macular hole is a partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina of the foveal region. It could be idiopathic or caused due to trauma or CME. There is a decrease in vision, typically around 6/60 for full-thickness holes. FFA shows early foveal hyper fluorescence without a leak.

The OCT image of the macular hole is given below, which shows a full-thickness hole in the foveal retina:

questions.text:
Which of the following malignancies are correctly matched with their corresponding chromosomal translocations?

1. Mantle cell lymphoma- t(11;14)  
2. Follicular lymphoma- t(14;18)
3. Ewing sarcoma- t(11;22)
4. Burkitt's lymphoma- t(18; 8)
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair of malignancies and their corresponding chromosomal translocations are 1, 2, 3 (option D):

  • Mantle cell lymphoma- t(11;14)  
  • Follicular lymphoma- t(14;18)
  • Ewing sarcoma- t(11;22)

The translocation seen in Burkitt lymphoma is usually t(8;14); however, t(2;8) or t(8;22) may also be seen. All the translocations involve the MYC gene on chromosome 8, leading to increased levels of MYC protein.

questions.text: As a PHC medical officer, you see a 25-year-old man, who has come with painful lesions as shown below. On further probing, he tells you that he had vesicles on his penis 2 days back and that he is allergic to penicillin. On examination, he has bilateral tender lymphadenopathy. Which kit will you use to treat him?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of multiple, grouped painful ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy in this patient points to a diagnosis of herpes genitalis infection by HSV-2. It is treated with a red kit.

The red kit or kit 5 is meant for genital ulcer disease - herpetic. It contains acyclovir 400 mg tablets to be taken TDS for 7 days.

Chancroid is a close differential diagnosis, which presents with multiple, soft painful ulcers and unilateral tender lymphadenopathy. However, vesicles are not seen in chancroid and the ulcers are deeper with ragged undermined edges.

History of drug allergy to penicillin is relevant only when the patient presents with the primary chancre of syphilis. In such a case, they would need to be treated with a blue kit instead of a white kit.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Which of the following skeletal muscle relaxants exhibit the following response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine exhibits the above-given response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade.

Train of four protocol is one of the methods used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade. It is done by stimulating the ulnar nerve with a stimulus and watching the contractile responses in the adductor pollicis muscle. Four successive stimuli of 2Hz strength are given at fixed time intervals and the response achieved is plotted as a graph.

  Non-depolarizing blockers Depolarizing blockers
Fade phenomenon  Present 

Phase 1: Absent

Phase 2: Present 
Mechanism

Initial stimulus: Amount of Ach released is large enough to compete with the drug at the motor endplate causing maximal contraction of the muscle.

Successive stimuli: Amount of Ach released is insufficient to compete with the drug and results in sequentially diminished contractions

Phase 1: No competition between Sch and Ach. Sch acts like Ach at its receptors, but is not as easily metabolized by acetylcholinesterases resulting in persistent depolarisation. 

Phase 2: When the dose of Sch is increased maximally, it also exhibits a fade phenomenon.
